NEWLY IDENTIFIED GENETIC RESOURCES OF AFLATOXIN RESISTANCE AND HIGH IRON CONTENT WILL BE USED IN THE BREEDING PROGRAMS TO RELEASE NEW GERMPLASM LINES AND HYBRIDS, WHICH IS THE BEST TRANSFER OF TECHNOLOGY FROM THE LAB TO FIELD WITH BOTH PRODUCTS AND KNOWLEDGE NOT ONLY IN GHANA BUT ALSO IN OTHER DEVELOPING COUNTRIES. THE FVSU FACULTY AND STUDENTS, AND PU FACULTY WILL TOUR THE UDS CAMPUS AND RESEARCH LABORATORIES, PARTICIPATE IN FARM TOURS, MEET WITH SMALLHOLDER FARMERS, ORGANIZE WORKSHOPS, AND PARTICIPATE IN OUTREACH ACTIVITIES. STUDENTS AND FACULTY FROM THE UDS WILL VISIT FVSU TO GAIN EXPOSURE TO RESEARCH, TEACHING, AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES. INTERACTION OF THESE STUDENTS AND FACULTY, AND MENTORING BY FVSU, PU, USDA-ARS, AND UDS FACULTY WILL ENHANCE FACULTY RESEARCH AND TEACHING SKILLS AS WELL AS STUDENTS' LEARNING EXPERIENCES. STUDENTS WILL HAVE A COMPARATIVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE AGRICULTURAL, SOCIAL, AND CULTURAL VALUES OF GHANA WITH THOSE OF THE U.S. THEY WILL ALSO BE ABLE TO APPRECIATE THE GROWING INTERCONNECTIVITY OF IDEAS AND VIEWPOINTS OF PEOPLE AROUND THE WORLD, AS OPPOSED TO MERELY RECOGNIZING DIFFERENCES.

THE GLOBAL POPULATION IS EXPECTED TO RISE FROM A CURRENT LEVEL OF ~7.7 BILLION TO ~9.7 BILLION BY 2050. TO MEET FUTURE NEEDS AND TO BE ABLE TO SUSTAIN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION, AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND ITS APPLICATIONS NEED TO USE ALL EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES ONE OF WHICH IS ASSISTED REPRODUCTIVE TECHNOLOGIES (ARTS). GROWTH IN SMALL RUMINANT (SHEEP AND GOAT) PRODUCTION HAS GAINED TREMENDOUS INTEREST IN THE USA OVER THE LAST FEW DECADES, PARTICULARLY IN THE SOUTHEASTERN U.S. SMALL RUMINANTS HAVE POTENTIAL FOR MEAT AND MILK PRODUCTION AS WELL AS IN BIOMEDICAL AND REPRODUCTIVE RESEARCH. ARTS PARTICULARLY AI AND IVEP IS STILL NOT-WELL-DEVELOPED IN SHEEP AND GOAT COMPARED TO CATTLE AND THERE IS A ROOM FOR FURTHER IMPROVEMENT. A STRONG, WELL-TRAINED WORKFORCE IN THE AGRICULTURAL AND BIOMEDICAL SCIENCES IS ESSENTIAL TO PROVIDE THE RESOURCES NECESSARY TO FEED THE GROWING POPULATION AND HELPING PEOPLE TO ALLEVIATE THEIR HEALTH ISSUES. THIS EFFORT REQUIRES INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS THAT WILL COME FROM A WORKFORCE WITH A DIVERSE BACKGROUND. TO THIS END, THE PROPOSED PROJECT SEEKS TO ESTABLISH ARTS RESEARCH AND TEACHING FACILITY AT FORT VALLEY STATE UNIVERSITY TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS TO BE TRAINED AND ACQUIRE SKILLS IN THESE TECHNOLOGIES. THIS WILL GIVE THEM THE CAPABILITIES TO COMPLETE THEIR UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE DEGREES IN AGRICULTURAL AND BIOMEDICAL SCIENCES AND ULTIMATELY PURSUING A CAREER IN EMBRYOLOGY, ANDROLOGY, ANIMAL REPRODUCTION, HUMAN FERTILITY, OR BIOTECHNOLOGY. ANOTHER RESEARCH GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO UTILIZE ARTS ESPECIALLY AI AND IVEP TO IMPROVE THE REPRODUCTIVE POTENTIAL AND PRODUCTION IN SMALL RUMINANTS.

WHILE THERE IS A KNOWN SHORTAGE OF FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES (FCS) EDUCATORS AND PROFESSIONALS ACROSS THE NATION; ESPECIALLY WITH UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS, THERE IS A DEMAND FOR HIGHLY SKILLED FCS PROFESSIONALS WHO POSSESS THE INTELLECTUAL CAPITAL AND LEADERSHIP POTENTIAL TO IMPROVE THE WELL-BEING OF CHILDREN, YOUTH, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITIES.TO ADDRESS THIS ISSUE, THE FCS 21ST CENTURY WORKFORCE SHOULD INCLUDE A WELL-TRAINED AND DIVERSITY OF FCS PROFESSIONALS. THIS PROPOSED PROJECT GOAL IS TO ENHANCE EDUCATIONAL, COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIPS AND RECRUITMENT EFFORTS TO INCREASE UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENT ENROLLMENT IN FCS PROGRAMS AND CAREER PATHWAYS.TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL, THE PROJECTS' TARGETED OBJECTIVES WILL:1) INCREASE THE PERCENTAGE (10%) OF STUDENTS SUCCESSFULLY RECRUITED INTO FCS AT NCAT; AND 2) INCREASE THE APPLICATION RATE OF DAVIDSON-DAVIE COMMUNITY COLLEGE AND LEXINGTON SENIOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS TO FCS AT NCAT BY 30%.A LEADERSHIP TRAINING MODEL WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH COMMUNICATION, CRITICAL THINKING, INTERPERSONAL AND PROBLEM- SOLVING SKILLS AND CULTURAL COMPETENCIES.THE PROJECT SUPPORTS THE AMERICAN ASSOCIATION OF FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES INITIATIVES: SAY YES TO FCS, FCS SUCCESS, AND FCS DAY.IT WILL ALSO ADD TO FCS'S BODY OF KNOWLEDGE WHICH WILL BE INFUSED IN THE LEADERSHIP MODEL.FIFTY STUDENTS WILL RECEIVE MENTORING FROM THE PROJECT TEAM AND THE ADVISORY COUNCIL AS THEY MOVE THROUGH VARIOUS CAREER PATHWAYS TO DEGREE PROGRAMS, GRADUATE PROGRAMS, OR CAREERS IN THE FCS PROFESSION.THE OVERALL PROPOSAL ALIGNS WITH CBG PROGRAM GOAL OF ENHANCING THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES PROFESSIONAL WORKFORCE IN ATTRACTING AND EDUCATING STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS.

CALF PRECONDITIONING PROGRAMS PROMOTE CALF GROWTH, ENHANCE IMMUNE FUNCTION AND MINIMIZE STRESS DURING WEANING. THESE PROGRAMS UTILIZE HIGH-QUALITY PASTURES AND GRAIN SUPPLEMENTS AND RANGE FROM 45 TO 60 DAYS AFTER WEANING. HOWEVER, PAST RESEARCH HAS SHOWN THAT CORN-BASED DIETS RESULT IN ENDOTOXIN BUILDUP IN THE RUMEN, RESULTING IN A SUBCLINICAL INFLAMMATORY STATE THAT CAN BE DETRIMENTAL TO CALF PERFORMANCE AND HEALTH. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS THE POTENTIAL BENEFITS OF ACTIVE DRY YEAST (ADY) SUPPLEMENTATION ON POST-WEANING CALF HEALTH AND GROWTH PERFORMANCE, AND TO OPTIMIZE A PRE-CONDITIONING MANAGEMENT PROTOCOL THAT IMPROVES THE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE OF FLORIDA COW-CALF PRODUCERS IN THE BEEF SUPPLY CHAIN. WE WILL TEST THIS IDEA BY: 1) COMPARING CALF WEIGHT GAIN, RUMEN FERMENTATION PARAMETERS AND BLOOD ENDOTOXIN LEVELS DURING THE PRECONDITIONING PROCESS, 2) DETERMINING THE EFFECTS OF ADY SUPPLEMENTATION ON BLOOD CYTOKINE AND METABOLOMICS PROFILES AND THEIR CORRELATIONS TO CALF HEALTH AND SUBSEQUENT PRODUCTIVITY, 3) DISSEMINATING THE RESEARCH FINDINGS TO PRODUCER AND RESEARCH COMMUNITY. THESE FINDINGS WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO MANAGEMENT PROTOCOLS THAT OPTIMIZE CALF HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY IN FLORIDA COW-CALF SYSTEMS.

THE FOOD INDUSTRY IS AMONG THE LARGEST AND FASTEST-GROWING, PRIVATE-SECTOR EMPLOYER WITH HIGH-TECH PAYING JOBS IN THE UNITED STATES, CONTRIBUTING BILLIONS OF DOLLARS TO THE GROSS NATIONAL PRODUCT, YET STUDENT ENROLLMENT IN FOOD SCIENCE AND RELATED FIELDS HAS BEEN DECLINING NATIONWIDE, ESPECIALLY AMONG AFRICAN AMERICANS. HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES AND 1862 INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER LEARNING PRODUCE MANY MINORITY GRADUATES FROM LIFE SCIENCE PROGRAMS, YET ONLY ABOUT 5% ARE IN THE FOOD SCIENCE PROFESSION. FURTHERMORE, IT HAS BEEN WELL DOCUMENTED THAT STRESS AND LACK OF SLEEP HAVE AN INFLUENCE ON EMPLOYEES' MOTIVATION, PERFORMANCE, AND JOB RETENTION. HOWEVER, LIMITED STUDIES HAVE INVESTIGATED THE IMPACT OF STRESS AND SLEEP AMONG DIVERSE POPULATIONS OF FOOD STAKEHOLDERS. THE AIMS OF THIS PROPOSAL ARE: 1) TO PROVIDE MASTER'S LEVEL STUDENTS HOLISTIC TRAINING IN FOOD SAFETY (I.E., GRADUATE LEVEL RESEARCH PROJECTS, SERVSAFE CERTIFICATION, AND HACCP PRINCIPLES), EXTENSION AND OUTREACH OPPORTUNTIES (I.E., COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND TRAING), AND EDUCATION ON THE IMPACT OF SLEEP AND STRESS RELATED TO OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY; 2) TO PROVIDE DELAWARE FOOD STAKEHOLDERS (E.G., FARMERS, PREPARERS, RESTAURANT STAFF) TRAINING IN FOOD SAFETY (I.E, SERVSAFE CERTIFICATION, HACCP), AND EDUCATION ON THE EFFECTS OF SLEEP AND STRESS RELATED TO OCCUPATIONAL PERFORMANCE AND RETENTION; 3) TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE DATA ON THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN SLEEP, STRESS, AND FOOD SAFETY AMONG DELAWARE FOOD STAKEHOLDERS.

CLEAN FRESH WATER IS CRITICAL TO ENVIRONMENTAL AND HUMAN HEALTH, AND MANDATED BY THE CLEAN WATER ACT (CWA). THE CWA REQUIRES MONITORING THE HEALTH OF STREAMS AND RIVERS, WHICH IS A KEY OBJECTIVE OF GOVERNMENTAL AND NONGOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES. TO MEASURE THE HEALTH OF FLOWING WATERS, AGENCIES USE AQUATIC INSECTS CALLED MAYFLIES (EPHEMEROPTERA), STONEFLIES (PLECOPTERA), AND CADDISFLIES (TRICHOPTERA), OR EPT, BECAUSE OF THEIR DIVERSITY AND SENSITIVITY TO POLLUTED WATER. TRADITIONAL EPT BIOMONITORING METHODS RELY ON THE COLLECTION AND IDENTIFICATION OF THESE ANIMALS UNDER A MICROSCOPE BASED ON THEIR MORPHOLOGY. THIS PROCESS IS TIME CONSUMING, REQUIRES YEARS OF SPECIALIZED EXPERTISE, AND CAN FAIL TO ACHIEVE SPECIES-LEVEL TAXONOMIC RESOLUTION. NEWER METHODS USING DNA TO IDENTIFY MANY ORGANISMS SIMULTANEOUSLY, CALLED METABARCODING, HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO REVOLUTIONIZE BIOMONITORING BY SAVING TIME AND MONEY AND INCREASING TAXONOMIC RESOLUTION. THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE TWO BROAD TYPES OF METABARCODING METHODS, BULK SAMPLE METABARCODING AND ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) METABARCODING, AGAINST MORPHOLOGICAL METHODS. THIS WILL HAPPEN IN STREAMS IMPACTED BY AGRICULTURE AND THOSE DEVOID OF AGRICULTURAL IMPACTS IN NORTH FLORIDA'S OCHLOCKONEE RIVER BASIN USING FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION PROTOCOLS. THE PROJECT WILL EVALUATE STREAM HEALTH AND AGRICULTURAL IMPACTS, SURVEY THE EPT OF THE BASIN, AND IDENTIFY THE MOST EFFECTIVE METABARCODING METHOD FOR ASSESSING WATER QUALITY. THE OVERARCHING GOALS ARE TO BUILD INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY IN WATERSHED RESEARCH BY IDENTIFYING THE BEST PERFORMING MOLECULAR BIOMONITORING METHOD RELATIVE TO MORPHOGICAL METHODS. THE RESULTS WILL INFORM THE ADOPTION OF THE OPTIMAL MOLECULAR BIOMONITORING METHODS MOVING FORWARD.

IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE, DEMAND FOR MORE SUSTAINABLE AND ECO-FRIENDLY FOOD PRODUCTS CONTINUE TO RISE. THIS TREND IS EVIDENT IN THE GLOBAL VITICULTURE INDUSTRY AS CONSUMERS INCREASE THEIR AWARENESS OF AGRICULTURAL IMPACTS ON THE ENVIRONMENT. WINE AND GRAPE PRODUCTION IN THE SOUTHERN U.S. IS BASED SOLELY ON UNIQUE VARIETIES OF MUSCADINE AND AMERICAN HYBRID BUNCH GRAPES THAT CAN TOLERATE THE HIGH LEVEL OF BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC STRESSORS, THAT INCLUDES HIGH HUMIDITY AND TEMPERATURE, ERRATIC RAINFALL, BACTERIAL AND FUNGAL PATHOGENS, AND DAMAGING INSECTS FOUND IN THE SOUTHERN U.S. REGION. THESE PRESSURES REQUIRE THE APPLICATION OF NUMEROUS PESTICIDES FOR A SUCCESSFUL SEASON. AS A RESULT, MORE SUSTAINABLE PRACTICES HAVE YET TO BE DEMONSTRATED EFFECTIVE FOR THE INDUSTRY'S ADOPTION. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO UTILIZE NEW CLIMATE SMART MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND EMERGING VITICULTURE TECHNOLOGIES AT FLORIDA A&M UNIVERSITY'S (FAMU) CENTER FOR VITICULTURE AND SMALL FRUIT RESEARCH (CVSFR) IN ORDER TO CONTROL NEW EMERGING PESTS IN SOUTHERN VINEYARDS. THE COMBINATION OF ARBUSCULAR MYCORRHIZAL FUNGI (AMF) AND ENTEROPATHOGENIC NEMATODES (EN), COMBINED WITH UNDER VINE VEGETATION (UVV), WILL INCREASE SOIL MICROBIAL BIODIVERSITY, GRAPEVINE HEALTH, WINE QUALITY, AND LOWER THE IMPACT OF AGROCHEMICALS ON THE ENVIRONMENT REDUCING INPUT COSTS AND INCREASING GROWER PROFITS. RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO PRODUCE A CLIMATE SMART PRODUCTION GUIDE FOR SOUTHERN GRAPES FOR DISSEMINATION TO THE INDUSTRY AND STAKEHOLDERS. AT THE SAME TIME, THE PROJECT WILL TRAIN UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE RESEARCHERS WITH PRACTICAL EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AND TECHNOLOGICALLY ADVANCED PROFICIENCY TO SUPPLEMENT A DIVERSE AND SPECIALIZED VITICULTURE WORKFORCE.

THE PROPOSED RESEARCH PROJECT WILL ADDRESS A PRESSING NATURAL RESOURCE ISSUE ASSOCIATED WITH SHORTLEAF PINE'S (PINUS ECHINATA MILL.) DECLINING NATURAL REGENERATION ACROSS ITS BROAD GEOGRAPHIC RANGE IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE. UNDERSTANDING PATTERNS IN SHORTLEAF PINE'S NATURAL REGENERATION FROM A LARGE-SCALE PERSPECTIVE IS A NECESSARY STEP TOWARDS MAINTAINING THE SUSTAINABILITY AND DIVERSITY OF THE SOUTHERN FOREST ECOSYSTEM. USING SPATIALLY-EXPLICIT MODELS, WE WILL BUILD QUANTITATIVE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN OCCURRENCES OF SHORTLEAF PINE SEEDS, SEEDLINGS, AND A VARIETY OF METRICS (E.G., SEED PRODUCTION, SOIL, TOPOGRAPHY, CLIMATE, AND MOISTURE AVAILABILITY) TO IDENTIFY KEY DRIVING FACTORS LIMITING SHORTLEAF PINE REGENERATION UNDER VARYING OVERSTORY DENSITY. SAMPLING SITES WILL BE SELECTED FROM LARGE SPATIAL GRADIENTS ACROSS THE SPECIES' RANGE, WITH AN INITIAL FOCUS ON STANDS REPRESENTING NATURAL SHORTLEAF PINE HABITATS IN THE MIXED FORESTS OF CUMBERLAND PLATEAU. FOREST INVENTORY AND ANALYSIS (FIA) DATA WILL BE USED TO SUPPLEMENT OUR FIELD DATA. WE EXPECT THAT THE PROJECT WILL GENERATE VALUABLE INFORMATION FOR FOREST LANDOWNERS AND AUTHORITIES TO PRIORITIZE CONSERVATION EFFORTS OF SHORTLEAF PINE AT THE REGIONAL AND NATIONAL LEVELS. EQUALLY IMPORTANT IS THAT THE FACULTY AND STAFF AT ALABAMA A&M UNIVERSITY (AAMU) WILL HAVE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT THROUGH ENGAGEMENT IN RESEARCH AND TEACHING. FURTHERMORE, THE PROJECT WILL ENHANCE STUDENT PARTICIPATION IN RESEARCH AT AAMU, THEREBY SUSTAINING AAMU'S COMMITMENT TO CAPACITY BUILDING IN FOREST SCIENCE FOR STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS.

THIS EFFORT ALLOWS CSU TEACHING FACULTY TO SOLICIT NIFA FUNDING TO STRENGTHEN EDUCATIONAL CAPACITY AND PARTICIPATE IN NIFA RESEARCH.FIRST, THIS EFFORT PROPOSES TO ENHANCE UAS TEACHING CAPACITY AT CSU BY DEVELOPING NEW UAS COURSE AND INCORPORATING NEW UAS MODULES INTO EXISTING GIS, REMOTE SENSING, AND PRECISION AGRICULTURE COURSES. IT MEETS THE URGING NEEDS OF TEACHING UAV ON CAMPUS IN RESPONSE TO THE FAST EVOLVING CAPACITIES OF UAS AND ITS BROAD APPLICATIONS IN AGRICULTURE RELATED AREAS. THE PROPOSED UAS CURRICULA AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS ARE DESIGNED TO TEACH STUDENTS FROM THE BASICS OF UAS TECHNOLOGIES TO ADVANCED BID DATA ANALYTICS. LEARNING WILL BE SOLIDIFIED WITH HANDS-ON LEARNING PRACTICE ON EQUIPMENT AND SOFTWARE WITHIN AND BEYOND CLASSROOMS.SECOND, NOT ONLY DOES THIS EFFORT ENHANCE TEACHING CAPACITY OF EXISTING ACADEMIC FACULTY IN THE EMERGING AREAS UAS TECHNOLOGIES AND ITS APPLICATIONS IN AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, AND NATURAL RESOURCES, BUT PLANS TO BRING IN NEW TEACHING PERSONNEL FOR FACULTY DEVELOPMENT TO CSU. THIS EFFORT WILL ENRICH UAS RELATED CURRICULUM, EXPAND DEGREE OFFERING, AND IMPROVE STUDENT RECRUITMENT, RETENTION, AND MATRICULATION IN STEMA AND 1890 LAND GRANT INSTITUTIONS.THIRD, THIS EFFORT INTENDS TO BUILD UP THE RESEARCH CAPACITY OF UAS THERMAL IMAGING AND SENSING FOR AGRICULTURE AND ENVIRONMENTAL STUDIES AT CSU. THAT IS, THIS RESEARCH WILL I) EXPLORE THE USAGE OF UAS THERMAL IMAGING AND SENSING FOR STUDYING SURFACE TEMPERATURE, VEGETATION, AND ENERGY BUDGET FOR AGRICULTURE, II) INCREASE THE KNOWLEDGE OF UAS-BASED SURFACE ENERGY BUDGET STUDY, III) APPLY UAS THERMAL IMAGERY FOR CROP HEALTH AND IRRIGATION, AND VI) EXPLORE UAS DATA ANALYTICS WITH ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE AND MACHINE LEARNING.FOURTH, THIS EFFORT AIMS TO ENHANCE UAS SYSTEMS AND ACQUIRE UAS THERMAL SENSORS FOR CLASSROOM TEACHING AND FIELD EXPERIMENTS, THROUGH WHICH, STUDENTS WILL GAIN FIRST-HAND EXPERIENCE IN USING UAS FOR MONITORING, PROCESSING, AND DELIVERING REAL TIME INFORMATION,IN TACKLING THE REAL WORLD PROBLEMS AND PROVIDING SCIENCE-BASED, DATA-DRIVEN DECISIONS FOR PRECISION CROP AGRICULTURE, PRECISION LIVESTOCK FARMING, AND OTHER GEOSPATIAL APPLICATIONS.AT LAST, THIS EFFORT PROVIDES LEARNING AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES OF UAS FOR STUDENTS. EACH SUMMER EIGHT TO TEN STUDENTS WILL BE RECRUITED IN TWO-WEEK SUMMER INTENSE WORKSHOP DURING THE THREE YEARS PERFORMANCE PERIOD. THREE UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCHERS WILL BE ENGAGED IN FACULTY RESEARCH AND PARTICIPATE IN FIELD EXPERIMENTS AND UAS IMAGE ANALYSES. STUDENTS WILL GAIN KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE IN UAS AND BECOME COMPETENT IN FUTURE CAREER.IN SUMMARY, THIS EFFORT BUILDS EDUCATION AND RESEARCH CAPACITY OF UAS TECHNOLOGY AND BIG DATA INTELLIGENCE AT CSU IN RECOGNITION OF THE CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES IN NATION AND AROUND THE WORLD. THIS EFFORT ENHANCES INSTITUTIONAL AND COLLEGE'S DECLARED MISSION OF PROMOTING STEM EDUCATION, AND FITS SEAMLESSLY INTO INSTITUTIONAL AND COLLEGE STRATEGIC PLANS OF INCREASING DEGRE,E OFFERING AND GRADUATE STUDY.

DEVELOPING AN ECONOMICAL AND RELIABLE BLENDED VEGETABLE OIL AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO SUNFLOWER OIL IS NECESSARY TO MITIGATE THE IMPACT OF THE GLOBAL SUNFLOWER OIL SHORTAGE. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AN APPROPRIATE BLENDED VEGETABLE FRYING OIL AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO TODAY'S STANDARD HIGH-COST SUNFLOWER OIL WITHOUT CHANGING THE UNIQUE FLAVOR PROFILE AND STABILITY OF FRIED FOODS, ADDRESSING BOTH THE GLOBAL SHORTAGE OF SUNFLOWER OIL AS WELL AS FOOD SECURITY CONCERNS. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO DEVELOP AND FORMULATE APPLICABLE VEGETABLE OIL BLENDS THAT HAVE AN IDEAL FATTY ACID PROFILE FOR A DEEP-FAT FRYING OIL. OBJECTIVES WILL BE ACHIEVED BY BLENDING READILY AVAILABLE VEGETABLE OILS BASED ON THEIR FATTY ACID COMPOSITION, DETERMINING THE FLAVOR STABILITY AND QUALITY OF VEGETABLE OIL FORMULATIONS USING POTATO CHIP AS THE TEST MEDIUM, AND EVALUATING THE CONSUMER ACCEPTANCE OF FORMULATED VEGETABLE OILS THROUGH SENSORY TESTING OF POTATO CHIPS FRIED IN THE FORMULATED OILS.THE RESULTING ALTERNATIVE OIL BLEND WILL SERVE TO REDUCE THE HIGH DEMAND OF SUNFLOWER OIL CAUSED BY DISRUPTIONS IN THE GLOBAL SUPPLY CHAIN AND IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF FRIED FOOD PRODUCTS. FURTHERMORE, THIS PROJECT WILL PROMOTE RESEARCH IN THE AREA OF PLANT-BASED FOOD PRODUCTS, PROVIDING HANDS-ON FOOD PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT EXPERIENCES TO THE STUDENTS AT FORT VALLEY STATE UNIVERSITY (FVSU). THE OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED AS A GUIDELINE TO DEVELOP NEW OILSEED CULTIVARS FOR FRYING OIL, ACCUMULATE THE KNOWLEDGE OF DEEP-FAT FRYING APPLICATIONS, AND BROADEN THE APPLICATION TO OTHER FRIED FOOD PRODUCTS CONTAINING VEGETABLE OILS. THROUGH MEETING THESE OBJECTIVES, FVSU WILL UTILIZE CUTTING-EDGE TECHNOLOGIES TO EXPAND THE RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL CAPABILITIES IN THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES PROGRAM.

CUTICLE AND SUBERIN ARE PRODUCED AND CHANGED IN HIGHER PLANTS DURING NORMAL DEVELOPMENT AND IN RESPONSE TO STRESSES, INCLUDING WATER LOSS, WOUNDING, AND PATHOGEN INFECTIONS, ETC. DESPITE THEIR UBIQUITOUS PRESENCES IN DIFFERENT PLANT SPECIES, THE REGULATION OF THE CUTICLE AND SUBERIN BIOSYNTHESIS AND DEPOSITION TO THE PLANT SURFACE AS WELL AS THEIR FUNCTIONAL MECHANISMS IN PLANT DEFENSE ARE LARGELY UNKNOW. TOMATO PLANTS ARE IMPORTANT CROPS IN THE U.S.A AND WORLD-WIDE. MORE THAN 30% OF TOMATO YIELDS COULD BE LOST DURING THE PATHOGEN INFECTIONS AND POSTHARVEST STORAGE. THE DEFECTS OF CUTICLE IN TOMATO FRUITS COULD LEAD TO THE ENHANCED WATER LOSS AND REDUCED TOLERANCE TO BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC STRESSES IN BOTH GROWING SEASON, HARVEST, AND POST-HARVEST STORAGE STAGES. OUR SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) TO EXPLORE CRISPR GENOME EDITING SYSTEM FOR TOMATO PRODUCTION WITH THE MODIFIED CUTICLE FORMATION AND STRUCTURES; 2) TO SYSTEMICALLY EXAMINE THE ROLES OF THE TARGETED GENES IN CUTICLE FORMATION FORTHEIR RELATED FUNCTIONS IN BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC STRESSES IN TOMATO PLANTS; 3) TO TRAIN 1890 FACULTY AND UNDER-PRIVILEGED STUDENTS IN THE APPLICATION OF THE BIOCHEMICAL, MOLECULAR, AND CELLULAR BIOLOGY AND GENOME EDITING TECHNOLOGY FOR THE ACADEMIC AND RESEARCH ENHANCEMENT. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT ALIGNS WELL WITH THE NIFA CBG PROGRAM IN THAT IT ADVANCES OUR KNOWLEDGE ON SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AS WELL AS THE NEXT GENERATION AGRICULTURE WORK FORCE TRAINING BY TWO-INSTITUTE COLLABORATION.

BLUEBERRIES (VACCINIUM SECTION CYANOCOCCUS) HAVE A HIGH CONCENTRATION OF PHENOLIC COMPOUNDS AND ANTHOCYANINS, WHICH ARE REPORTED TO PROTECT AGAINST CARCINOGENICITY, AND CARDIOVASCULAR AND NEURODEGENERATIVE CHANGES RELATED TO THE AGING PROCESS. DUE TO THESE BENEFITS, CONSUMER DEMAND FOR BLUEBERRIES HAS BEEN STEADILY INCREASING. BLUEBERRY PLANTS HAVE STRINGENT GROWTH CONDITIONS AND ARE EXTREMELY SENSITIVE TO TEMPERATURE FLUCTUATIONS. SINCE THE GLOBAL MEAN TEMPERATURE CONTINUES TO INCREASE AT A RAPID RATE, HEAT STRESS IS EXPECTED TO BECOME AN EVEN MORE CRITICAL THREAT TO BLUEBERRY CULTIVATION THAN IT IS TODAY. IN SUCH CONDITIONS, THE PERFORMANCE AND ADAPTABILITY OF THE HIGHBUSH BLUEBERRY WILL BE CHALLENGED. THEREFORE, GENETIC IMPROVEMENT OF BLUEBERRY CULTIVARS FOR HIGH-TEMPERATURE STRESS (HTS) TOLERANCE IS CRUCIAL TO SUSTAINING BLUEBERRY CULTIVATION AND PRODUCTION IN THE FUTURE. THE SOUTHERN BLUEBERRY SPECIES SUCH AS V. DARROWII GROW IN RELATIVELY WARMER CONDITIONS AND ARE A GREAT RESOURCE FOR IDENTIFYING HTS-RESPONSIVE GENES. EARLIER, WE EVALUATED AN INTERSPECIFIC (V. DARROWII &TIMES; V. CORYMBOSUM) F2 POPULATION (260 PLANTS) FOR HTS TOLERANCE TRAITS FOR TWO YEARS. IN ADDITION, WE HAVE THE GENOTYPE DATA OF THE POPULATION, RECENTLY DEVELOPED DIPLOID REFERENCE GENOME ASSEMBLY, AND TRANSCRIPTOME DATA OF THE PARENTAL LINES SUBJECTED TO HEAT STRESS. IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL DEVELOP A GENETIC LINKAGE MAP AND IDENTIFY QUANTITATIVE TRAIT LOCI (QTLS)/GENES FOR HTS TOLERANCE TRAITS. WE WILL PERFORM TRANSCRIPTOME PROFILING OF BULKED F2 PROGENIES AND IDENTIFY DIFFERENTIALLY EXPRESSED GENES FOR HTS TOLERANCE TRAITS. THE HTS-TOLERANT F2 PLANTS WILL BE CROSSED WITH TETRAPLOID BLUEBERRY CULTIVARS TO IMPROVE THEIR HTS TOLERANCE. IN ADDITION, THE STUDENTS FROM DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY WILL BE TRAINED IN MODERN PLANT BREEDING METHODS AND MOLECULAR BIOLOGY TECHNIQUES.

THERE IS AN ONGOING NEED FOR UP-TO-DATE INSTRUMENTATION AND A FEED PROCESSING AND FORMULATION FACILITY AT AAMU TO ENHANCE TEACHING AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING FOR THE ANIMAL BIO-HEALTH SCIENCE (ABHS) STUDENTS. THE FACILITY WILL BE EQUIPPED WITH THE RESOURCES NECESSARY TO TRAIN STUDENTS ON IDENTIFYING SUSTAINABLE ALTERNATIVE FEED INGREDIENTS TO USE IN MANIPULATING ANIMAL DIETS THAT ARE FED TO REDUCE FEED COSTS, IMPROVE FEED EFFICIENCY, ENHANCE ANIMAL PERFORMANCE, AND REDUCE GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS, PARTICULARLY TO DECREASE METHANE EMISSIONS IN RUMINANT ANIMALS. ADDITIONALLY, THE ABHS CURRICULUM INCLUDES FAS 352 - FEEDS & FEEDING. HOWEVER, THE COURSE IS UNDERDEVELOPED AND CURRENTLY LACKS THE CAPACITY TO PROVIDE LABORATORY EXERCISES TO SUPPORT THE REQUISITE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES NEEDED FOR STUDENT ENGAGEMENT AND COMPETITIVENESS. THUS, IF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS FUNDED, IT WILL SERVE AS A BASIC FOUNDATION FOR HANDS-ON STUDENT LEARNING WITH THE FOLLOWING ANTICIPATED IMPACTS: (I) STIMULATE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING ON UTILIZING ALTERNATIVE FEED INGREDIENTS TO FORMULATE ANIMAL FEED; (II) TO AUGMENT FACULTY PREPARATION IN FEED DEVELOPMENT AND ITS IMPACT ON FEED AND NUTRITION TEACHING; (III) GROW THE CAPACITY FOR COLLABORATION WITH GOVERNMENT AGENCIES AND THE ANIMAL INDUSTRY; AND (IV) INCREASE RETENTION IN THE ABHS PROGRAM. OVER 120 STUDENTS WILL DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM CURRICULAR ACTIVITIES, AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND LEADERSHIP TRAINING DURING THE LIFE SPAN OF THE PROJECT. ULTIMATELY, THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ENABLE AAMU TO GRADUATE STUDENTS WHO ARE PREPARED TO ADDRESS NIFA STRATEGIC GOALS. DATA GENERATED WILL BE USED TO PURSUE COMPETITIVE GRANTS OFFERED BY USDA AND OTHER FUNDING SOURCES.

CREATE NEW REVENUES FOR AGRICULTURAL CROPS PRODUCED AT THE LIMITED RESOURCE FARMSPROVIDE THE COMMUNITY WITH LATEST INFORMATION THAT WILL BOOST THE ACCESS TO SAFE, AFFORDABLE, NUTRITIONALLY ADEQUATE DIETS FOR WEIGHT CONTROL AND GOOD HEALTHSKILL AND CAREER OPPORTUNITIES TO YOUTH AND COLLEGE STUDENTSPROVIDE SOLUTIONS TO INDUSTRIALIZE STEVIA PRODUCTION, PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT AND MARKETINGIMPROVED EXTENSION TECHNOLOGY SUPPORT SYSTEMBRIDGING RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS

THIS PROJECT IS AN INTEGRATED PILOT PROGRAM ADDRESSING THE ISSUE OF OBESITY PREVENTION. WE WILL DO THIS BY IDENTIFYING THE SPECIFIC GENOMIC-MATCHED PERSONALIZED NUTRITION PLAN AND BODY COMPOSITION IN INDIVIDUALS TO ASSIST MINORITY POPULATIONS IN ADOPTING HEALTHY LIFESTYLE CHOICES. OBESITYHAS BECOME THE FOCUS OF PUBLIC HEALTH, AS ALMOST TWO-THIRDS OF US ADULTS HAVE A BMI HIGHER THAN 25KG/M2 (OVERWEIGHT). A SEDENTARY LIFESTYLE AND GENETICS SIGNIFICANTLY CONTRIBUTE (40-70%) TO OBESITY DEVELOPMENT. THIS IS ALSO A CAUSE OF DIABETES, HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE, ELEVATED BLOOD LIPID LEVELS, AND CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES. SIGNIFICANT ADVANCES HAVE BEEN MADE IN UNDERSTANDING THE SCIENTIFIC RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN DIETARY INTAKEAND DISEASE PREVENTION. THE DEVELOPMENT OF GENOMICS TECHNOLOGIES INITIATED A NEW GENERATION IN MEDICINE AND NUTRITION. EVERY INDIVIDUAL IS GENETICALLY UNIQUE AND PHENOTYPICALLY DISTINCT. NUTRIGENOMICS IS DEFINED AS THE INTERACTION BETWEEN NUTRITION AND AN INDIVIDUAL'S GENETIC PATTERN. THE INTERACTIONS AND IDENTIFICATION OF DIET-GENE WILL PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO DEVELOP A PERSONALIZED DIETARY INTERVENTION THAT WILL LEAD TO EVIDENCE-BASED LIFESTYLE CHANGES FORACHIEVING OPTIMAL HEALTH. DEVELOPING PERSONALIZED NUTRIGENOMIC FOOD WILL DEPEND ON ANINDIVIDUAL'S NUTRITIONAL AND GENETIC TESTS TO ASCERTAIN THE PREDISPOSED CONDITIONS. BASED ON THE NUTRITIONAL AND GENETIC RESULTS, A PERSONALIZED PLAN OF DIETARY NUTRITION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITIES CAN BE ADOPTED TOPREVENT OBESITY. ACCURATE BODY COMPOSITION ASSESSMENT IS AN ESPECIALLY VITAL COMPONENT OFRESEARCH ON OBESITY AND THE EFFECTS OF DISEASE PROCESSES ON HEALTH. AN INNOVATIVE INTERVENTIONPROGRAM CALLED SIMPLY MY HEALTH (SMH) WILL BE INITIATED AT CENTRAL STATE UNIVERSITY TO PROVIDEA HEALTHIER LIFESTYLE.

SILPHIUM INTEGRIFOLIUM (SILFLOWER) IS A NATIVE NORTH AMERICAN PRAIRIE PLANT, UNDERGOING DOMESTICATION BY THE LAND INSTITUTE (TLI) AS A PERENNIAL OILSEED CROP, WHICH ATTRACTS DOZENS OF POLLINATOR SPECIES AND HAS AN ANTICIPATED POTENTIAL FOR INCREASED HONEY PRODUCTION. THIS IS MAINLY DUE TO THE FACT THAT IT BLOOMS LATE, FROM MID-SUMMER TO AUTUMN, WHEN FORAGE FOR HONEYBEES TENDS TO BE MORE SCARCE. CENTRAL STATE UNIVERSITY (CSU), IN COLLABORATION WITH TLI, PROPOSE TO TEST THE ABILITY OF A SILFLOWER AS A PERENNIAL CROP IN OHIO. IT IS HYPOTHESIZED THAT INTEGRATED SILFLOWER PRODUCTION WITH MANAGED HONEYBEES WILL INCREASE THE PRODUCTION OF HONEY, AS WELL AS LEAD TO A HIGHER YIELD OF SEED FROM THE CROP. WITH SUPPORT FROM TLI, TEST PLOTS WILL BE SET UP AT CSU'S RESEARCH STATION AND MIRROR SITES, BOTH WITH AND WITHOUT HONEYBEE HIVES. PROJECT PARTNER SITES INCLUDE REGENERATIVE FARMING OPERATIONS AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES. MANAGED HONEYBEES NOT IN THE VICINITY OF THE SILFLOWER PLOTS WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE STUDY FOR COMPARISON. ADDITIONAL FARMS WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE STUDY, BOTH WITH AND WITHOUT HONEYBEES. CSU AND TLI WILL COMBINE CROP, HONEYBEE, SOCIAL, AND ECONOMIC DATA GATHERED THROUGH THE PROJECT, WHICH WILL BE USED TO INFORM MIDWESTERN FARMERS AND BEEKEEPERS ON THE BENEFITS OF PERENNIAL CROPS FOR IMPROVING YIELDS AND PROFITS, WHILE INCREASING THE SUSTAINABILITY OF BOTH INDUSTRIES. SCIENTISTS WILL EXCHANGE BETWEEN INSTITUTIONS FOR CAPACITY BUILDING AND RESULTS WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP TOPICS FOR CONTINUING COLLABORATIVE PROJECTS.

ALABAMA AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL UNIVERSITY [AAMU], AND ALCORN STATE UNIVERSITY [ASU], TWO U.S. INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER LEARNING, HAVE BEEN AT THE FOREFRONT OF PRODUCING BACCALAUREATE OR HIGHER DEGREE LEVEL MINORITY GRADUATES IN FOOD, AGRICULTURE, HUMAN, AND NATURAL SCIENCES [FAHNS]. THEIR INVESTMENTS IN HUMAN CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT AND ACADEMIC PROGRAMS INCLUDE GLOBAL COLLABORATIONS TO PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH WORKFORCE EXPERIENCES OUTSIDE OUR BORDERS.AAMU AND ASU ARE COLLABORATING TO INITIATE AND ESTABLISH A FOOD, AGRICULTURE, HUMAN, AND NATURAL SCIENCES [FAHNS] STUDY ABROAD INTERNSHIP PROGRAM WITH INSTITUTIONS IN RWANDA AND SUBSEQUENTLY WITH OTHER SUB-SAHARAN AFRICAN INSTITUTIONS IN THE FUTURE TO ENGAGE FACULTY AND STUDENTS IN INTERNATIONAL INTERNSHIPS OPPORTUNITIES.THE PROPOSED PROJECT ALIGNS WITH OUR RESPECTIVE COLLEGES OF AGRICULTURE'S STRATEGIC PLANS TO SUPPORT FACULTY SCHOLARLY EFFECTIVENESS IN AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND EDUCATION WITH INTERNATIONAL INSTITUTIONS. THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE ESPECIALLY MINORITY U.S. STUDENTS WITH INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES IN FOOD, AGRICULTURE, HUMAN, AND NATURAL SCIENCES IN A NON-TRADITIONAL STUDY ABROAD DESTINATION (SUB-SAHARA AFRICA) WHERE LESS THAN 5% OF OUR STUDENTS ACQUIRE INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURE EXPERIENCES. THE BENEFITS OF INTERNATIONAL EXPERIENCES INCLUDE INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF OTHER CULTURES, WORLD GEOGRAPHY, CULTURAL RELATIVISM, AND GLOBAL INTERDEPENDENCE. A GOAL OF OUR PROJECT IS TO ENGAGE FACULTY AND STUDENTS AT OUR PARTNER INSTITUTIONS TO EXPAND THEIR INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY INTERNATIONALLY. THIS INITIATIVE IS IMMINENTLY NEEDED DUE TO THE SIGNIFICANT UNDER-REPRESENTATION OF MINORITIES IN FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES. OUR COLLABORATIONS WILL STRENGTHEN OUR EFFORTS OF DEVELOPING A GLOBALLY ENGAGED WORKFORCE TO TACKLE GLOBAL PROBLEMS AS MEMBERS OF THE WORLD COMMUNITY. THE PROJECT IS LIKELY TO HAVE SIGNIFICANT IMPACTS ON THE PARTICIPATION OF STUDENTS IN AGRICULTURE AT OUR INSTITUTIONS. THE PARTICIPATING STUDENTS WILL ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS AND WILL BE ENCOURAGED TO PURSUE ACADEMIC AND/ OR INTERNATIONAL CAREERS IN AGRICULTURE AND RURAL DEVELOPMENT. WE WILL BENEFIT FROM OUR COLLABORATIONS, AS WE WILL DEVELOP LONG LASTING RELATIONSHIPS THAT CREATE THE CONDITIONS FOR JOINT GLOBAL PROJECTS.

THE LONG- TERM IMPACT OF THE RECRUITMENT ACTIVITY CAN ONLY BE MEASURED IN TERMS OF THE CHANGES IN STUDENTS' ENROLLMENT ANNUALLY AND AT THE END OF THE PROJECT LIFE AND BEYOND. STUDENT AND CLASSROOM TEACHER WHO PARTICIPATE IN THE PROGRAM TO DETERMINE THEIR PERCEPTION, ATTITUDE TOWARD AND LEVEL OF KNOWLEDGE GAINED.STUDENTS' DROPOUTS WILL BE DOCUMENTED AND INVESTIGATED AT THE END OF THE ACADEMIC YEAR. CHANGES IN GRADUATION RATE AND THE IMPROVEMENT IN GPA AT THE END OF THE SCHOOL YEAR WILL ALSO INDICATE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE RETENTION STRATEGIES OF THE PROGRAM.IT SHOULD BE NOTED THAT NO MATTER HOW WELL STRUCTURED A CURRICULUM THAT SUPPORT AGRICULTURE SCIENCE EDUCATION MAY BE OR HOW ENTHUSIASTIC THE STAFF, UNLESS IN THE END STUDENT'S ENROLLMENT IS INCREASED AND THE EXPERIENCES OF THE STUDENTS ARE CHANGED SO THAT EDUCATIONAL OUTCOMES IMPROVE, THE WORK CANNOT BE CONSIDERED SUCCESSFUL. ?

THE PROJECT AIMS TO PERFORM GENETIC ANALYSIS WITH TRAITS INVOLVING NUTRACEUTICAL, TASTE AND FLAVOR (NTF) FROM THE CROSSES INVOLVING HABANERO PEPPERS AND EXPOSE OUR STUDENTS TO GLOBALLY IMPACTED GENOMIC TOOLS COMBINED WITH BREEDING PROGRAMS. FOR DECADES, PEOPLE HAVE BEEN COMPLAINING ABOUT THE NTF OF IMPROVED VARIETIES BECAUSE THE NTF-PRODUCING METABOLITES ARE NOT SELECTED FOR DURING BREEDING. WHEN GROWERS ARE PAID SOLELY BASED ON THE QUANTITY OF WHAT THEY PRODUCE, THE FOCUS OF BREEDERS HAS BEEN YIELD AND RESISTANCE. IN GENERAL, CONSUMER PREFERENCE HAS NEVER BEEN PART OF CULTIVAR DEVELOPMENT. IN THIS PROJECT, THE CONSUMER PREFERENCE TRAITS SUCH AS NTF ARE GENETIC ANALYSIS'S PRIMARY GOAL. CONSUMERS WANT NUTRITIOUS AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS, ESPECIALLY FRUITS, AND VEGETABLES, THAT TASTE AND SMELL GOOD. THEREFORE, THE PRIMARY CHALLENGE IS TO DETERMINE HOW TO PROVIDE HIGH-QUALITY PRODUCTS TO CONSUMERS WITHOUT COMPROMISING THE YIELD AND RESISTANCE TRAITS THAT GROWERS DEMAND.

THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO DEVELOP SPECIALTY WINTER SQUASHES BY PERFORMING MARKER ASSISTED SELECTION FOR ENHANCED FLAVOR AND NUTRACEUTICALS INVOLVING C. MAXIMA DIVERSE HORTICULTURE GROUPS TO CATER TO THE DEMAND OF CONSUMERS LOOKING FOR NEW AND INTERESTING VARIATIONS. WINTER SQUASH FRUIT SHAPES VARY FROM BANANA TO DRUM-SHAPED, TOP-SHAPED, FUSIFORM, AND OBLATE, WITH RIND COLORS RANGING FROM RED-ORANGE TO PINK-ORANGE, NEARLY WHITE, BLUISH-GRAY, INTENSE GREEN, AND BLACK-GREEN. OUR MAIN GOAL IS TO DEVELOP PREBREEDING LINES THAT ARE NUTRACEUTICALLY ENRICHED AND ENHANCED FOR FLAVOR COMPOUNDS. WE AIM TO CHARACTERIZE C. MAXIMA GERMPLASM POOLS AND ADVANCE INTERSPECIFIC CROSS DERIVATIVES OF C. MOSCHATA X C. MAXIMA TO IDENTIFY NOVEL SQUASH CULTIVARS ENHANCED FOR FLAVOR, RESISTANCE, AND OTHER NUTRACEUTICAL TRAITS.

HIGH TEMPERATURES AND DROUGHT EVENTS ARE ABIOTIC STRESSES OF PLANTS THAT CAUSE SERIOUS YIELD REDUCTION IN THE SOUTHEASTERN USA, AS WITNESSED BY THE 2022 SUMMER SEASON IN TENNESSEE. SPECIES FROM THE LEGUME FAMILY SUCH AS BEANS AND COWPEAS (GENERA PHASEOLUS AND VIGNA) CAN FIX NITROGEN AND PRODUCE HIGH AMOUNTS OF PLANT PROTEINS FOR NUTRITIOUS FOOD. HOWEVER, THEIR TOLERANCE TO HOT AND DRY WEATHER IS VARIABLE AND AS HERBACEOUS PLANTS LOWER THAN FOR THE SHRUB AND TREE LEGUME SPECIES TO WHICH THEY ARE RELATED. THE GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH PROJECT IS TO ELUCIDATE THE FINE SCALE ADAPTATION TO DROUGHT AND HEAT OF FOUR LEGUME SPECIES IN REAL TIME USING A NOVEL PHENOTYPING PLATFORM FROM THE COMPANY PLANT-DITECH THAT CAN MEASURE BIOMASS PRODUCTION AND WATER USE EFFICIENCY THROUGHOUT KEY PERIODS OF LEGUMES' GROWTH CYCLES. RESEARCH TO ADDRESS ABIOTIC CONSTRAINTS ARE RELEVANT TO THE USDA AND 1890S MISSIONS AND SUSTAINABILITY OF ECOSYSTEMS AND CLIMATE SMART AGRICULTURE IN THE REGION. THE PD/PI FOR THIS PROJECT HAS ONE OF THE FEW LEGUME GENOMICS/BREEDING PROGRAMS THAT IS EVALUATING ABIOTIC STRESS TRAITS AND THE PROPOSED TECHNOLOGY WILL SUPPORT VARIETAL IMPROVEMENT. OVERALL THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE PD/PI'S GENETICS RESEARCH AND TEACHING THROUGH ADVANCED PLANT PHYSIOLOGY RESEARCH. THE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT GRANT WILL HAVE A GROUP OF UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA (UF) HOSTS AND COLLABORATORS. THE RESEARCH AND TEACHING ACTIVITIES SUPPORT THE STRATEGIC COLLEGE-WIDE AND DEPARTMENTAL GOALS OF DEVELOPING WORLD-CLASS PLANT BIOTECHNOLOGY AND BREEDING PROGRAMS AT TSU AND UF, RESPECTIVELY. THE UF CENTER HAS THE ADVANTAGE OF BEING FULLY INTEGRATED FROM GENETICS TO PLANT PHYSIOLOGY AND TO BE ONE OF ONLY A FEW LOCATIONS WITH DITECH INSTALLED IN THE USA. THE TECHNOLOGICAL IMPROVEMENTS MADE BY THE PD WILL BE TAUGHT IN PLANT BREEDING AND GENETICS CLASSES WHICH HE TEACHES TO UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS AT TSU. THE OUTPUTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE APPLIED AND FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH INTO PLANT PHYSIOLOGY OF LEGUMES FACING DROUGHT STRESS UNDER HOT AND DRY CONDITIONS.

CRAPEMYRTLE (LAGERSTROEMIA SP.) IS ONE OF THE TOP-SELLING DECIDUOUS FLOWERING SHRUBS AND ARE DOMINANT LANDSCAPE PLANTS THROUGHOUT THE SOUTHERN UNITED STATES (CHAPPELL ET AL. 2012). CRAPEMYRTLES ARE USED IN LANDSCAPING AND ENVIRONMENTAL DEVELOPMENT BY PUBLIC PLANNERS, PRIVATE BUSINESSES, AND HOMEOWNERS ALIKE. ACCORDING TO THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, THE NATIONAL AGRICULTURAL STATISTICS SERVICE CENSUS OF HORTICULTURAL SPECIALTIES FOUND THAT ANNUAL CRAPEMYRTLE SALES WERE $69 MILLION IN 2019. THIS MAKES CRAPEMYRTLE A LUCRATIVE CROP WITH HIGH AESTHETIC VALUE THROUGHOUT THE REGION. MANY FACTORS INFLUENCE THE PROFITABILITY OF THE CRAPEMYRTLE INDUSTRY, INCLUDING CONSUMER DEMAND FOR COLOR, THE COSTS OF PRODUCTION, AND PEST MANAGEMENT EXPENDITURES.CRAPEMYRTLES ARE THREATENED BY SEVERAL KEY INSECT PESTS. CRAPEMYRTLE APHID [CMA, TINOCALLIS KAHAWALUOKALANI KIRKALDY (HEMIPTERA: APHIDIDAE)] IS ONE OF THE ECONOMICALLY SIGNIFICANT PESTS THAT NEGATIVELY IMPACTS THE APPEARANCE AND GROWTH PERFORMANCE OF CRAPEMYRTLE (HERBERT AND MIZELL III 2006, FRANK 2019). FOLIAR FEEDING BY APHIDS STUNTS GROWTH AND DISTORTS LEAVES. THE APHIDS ALSO REDUCE THEAESTHETIC QUALITY OF PLANTS BY SECRETING HONEYDEW, WHICH RESULTS IN OUTBREAKS OF SOOTY MOLD ON FOLIAGE. FOLIAR FEEDING BEETLES, INCLUDING JAPANESE BEETLE (POPILLIA JAPONICA NEWMAN) AND FLEA BEETLES (ALTICA SPP.), CAN REDUCE GROWTH AND AESTHETIC VALUE OF PLANTS IN PRODUCTION AND LANDSCAPE. IN 2004, A NEW INSECT PEST OF CRAPEMYRTLE WAS FOUND INFESTING PLANTINGS IN RICHARDSON, TEXAS. LIKE THE CRAPEMYRTLE APHID, CRAPEMYRTLE BARK SCALE [CMBS; ACANTHOCOCCUS LAGERSTROEMIAE KUWANA], FEEDS ON THE PLANT VASCULAR TISSUE, BUT DOES SO THROUGH THE BARK INSTEAD OF THE FOLIAGE (CHAPPELL ET AL. 2012, FRANK 2019). HEAVY INFESTATIONS RESULT IN LEAF ABSCISSION AND BRANCH DIEBACK. CMBS ALSO PRODUCES COPIOUS AMOUNTS OF HONEYDEW, WHICH RESULTS IN UNSIGHTLY SOOTY MOLD ON THE FOLIAGE AND AREAS SURROUNDING THE PLANT.CRAPEMYRTLES CAN ALSO BE NEGATIVELY IMPACTED BY DISEASES. POWDERY MILDEW (PM), CAUSED BY THE FUNGUS ERYSIPHE LAGERSTROEMIAE, IS THE MOST WIDESPREAD AND DAMAGING DISEASE OBSERVED IN CRAPEMYRTLE. IT OCCURS MOST OFTEN ON YOUNG, ACTIVELY GROWING PLANT TISSUES, REDUCING GROWTH. ANOTHER COMMON DISEASE OF CRAPEMYRTLE IS CERCOSPORA LEAF SPOT (CLS), CAUSED BY THE FUNGUS PSEUDOCERCOSPORA LYTHRACEARUM HEALD AND WOLF. RESISTANCE TO BOTH PATHOGENS HAS BEEN EVALUATED IN MANY OF THE OLDER CRAPEMYRTLE CULTIVARS, WITH THE IDENTIFICATION OF PM RESISTANCE BEING HISTORICALLY IMPORTANT TO PLANT BREEDING PROGRAMS.CURRENTLY, IN TENNESSEE, THE MOST IMPORTANT INSECT PEST OF CRAPEMYRTLE IS THE APHID. PREVIOUS STUDIES ON THE SUSCEPTIBILITY OF CRAPEMYRTLES TO CMA ATTACK HAVE INDICATED THAT PLANT PARENTAGE (L. INDICA VERSUS L. INDICA &TIMES; L. FAURIEI) AND MATURE PLANT HEIGHT (DWARF, MEDIUM, OR TALL) CAN PREDICT CMA RESISTANCE (ALVERSON AND ALLEN 1992, MIZELL AND KNOX 1993, PETTIS ET AL. 2004). GREATER CMA POPULATIONS HAVE BEEN OBSERVED ON L. INDICA &TI,MES; L. FAUREI CULTIVARS THAN ON CULTIVARS OF THE SPECIES L. INDICA (HERBERT ET AL. 2009, MIZELL III & KNOX 1993), INDICATING THAT SUSCEPTIBILITY TO CMA MAY BE PLEIOTROPIC (RIBEIRO ET AL. 2021). DWARF PLANTS WERE MORE RESISTANT TO CMA THAN MEDIUM OR TALL PLANTS (HERBERT ET AL. 2009, MIZELL III & KNOX 1993). CRAPEMYRTLE BARK SCALE ARRIVED IN TENNESSEE IN 2013 IN MEMPHIS AND HAS BEEN SLOWLY MOVING EAST INTO MAJOR CITIES. IT IS NOT YET PRESENT IN THE NURSERY PRODUCTION REGION OF MIDDLE TENNESSEE. TO DATE, RESISTANCE TO CMBS HAS NOT BEEN REPORTED IN ANY COMMERCIALLY AVAILABLE CULTIVAR OF CRAPEMYRTLE IN THE USA. ONLY THE TROPIC SPECIES L. SPECIOSA HAS SHOWN ANY RESISTANCE TO CMBS IN TRIALS (WU ET AL. 2021).THE MAIN PATHOGEN OF CONCERN TO CRAPEMYRTLE IN TENNESSEE IS POWDERY MILDEW. INCORPORATING POWDERY MILDEW RESISTANCE INTO CRAPEMYRTLE HAS BEEN A FOCUS OF BREEDERS FOR DECADES. CULTIVARS WITH PURE L. INDICA GENETICS TEND TO BE MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO POWDERY MILDEW. THE US NATIONAL ARBORETUM PIONEERED THE RELEASE OF L. INDICA &TIMES; L. FAURIEI HYBRIDS WITH POWDERY MILDEW RESISTANCE. MOST POPULAR CULTIVARS CURRENTLY ON THE MARKET HAVE SOME LEVEL OF POWDERY MILDEW RESISTANCE (CHAPPELL ET AL. 2012). HOWEVER,AS MENTIONED PREVIOUSLY, RESISTANCE TO POWDERY MILDEW MAY COME AT THE COST OF APHID SUSCEPTIBILITY, AND VICE VERSA.ON THE PRODUCTION SIDE, THIS RESEARCH PROPOSAL WILL FOCUS ON THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN HOW RESISTANCE TO CMA AND POWDERY MILDEW IS EXPRESSED UNDER TWO DIFFERENT GROWING CONDITIONS: GREENHOUSE (CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT) AND FIELD CONTAINER PRODUCTION (OPEN-AIR). WE WILL ALSO CONSIDER HOW MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS MAY CHANGE BASED ON PRODUCTION STAGE (PROPAGATION OR FINISHING) AND MANAGEMENT OPTIONS (CONVENTIONAL CHEMICALS OR BIOLOGICAL CONTROLS). WHILE HOST PLANT RESISTANCE CAN BE A GREAT TOOL FOR PEST MANAGEMENT, THERE MAY BE NEGATIVE EFFECTS AS WELL. FOR EXAMPLE, PLANTS WITH SOME LEVEL OF RESISTANCE TO APHIDS DUE TO HIGHER LEVELS OF TOXIC COMPOUNDS MAYINADVERTENTLY RESULT IN NEGATIVE FITNESS COSTS ON NATURAL ENEMIES THAT CONSUME THEM. THESE MULTI-TROPHIC INTERACTIONS WILL BE EXPLORED FURTHER IN THIS GRANT.

CLIMATE CHANGE HAS LED TO AN INCREASE IN HEAT WAVES, WHICH CAN NEGATIVELY IMPACT PLANT PRODUCTIVITY. MOLECULAR AND GENOME EDITING TOOLS CAN BE USED TO DEVELOP NEW CROPS THAT CAN TOLERATE HIGHER TEMPERATURES AND ACCESS DEEPER SOILS FOR WATER AND NUTRIENTS. HOWEVER, DELIVERING RECOMBINANT DNA INTO PLANT CELLS REMAINS CHALLENGING, AND THE PROCESS OF BREEDING NEW CULTIVARS IS TIME-CONSUMING. RESEARCHERS FROM TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY, TUSKEGEE UNIVERSITY, AND UC BERKELEY PROPOSE TO USE CARBON NANOPARTICLES AS NOVEL CARRIERS FOR DELIVERY OFFOREIGN DNA INTO PLANT CELLS. THEY PLAN TO INVESTIGATE THE COMBINATION OF NANO-DELIVERY WITH THE BIOLISTIC APPROACH AND OPTIMIZE THE SPEED BREEDING PROTOCOLS TO ACCELERATE PLANT MATURITY AND RECOVERY OF HOMOLOGOUS TRANSGENIC PLANTS. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE USDA PRIORITY AREA OF GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY AND AGRICULTURAL BIOSECURITY AND ADVANCES KNOWLEDGE ON THE USE OF NOVEL DNA DELIVERY SYSTEMS TO GENERATE PLANTS WITH NOVEL TRAITS. ADDITIONALLY, IT CAN FREE UP RESOURCES FOR OTHER RESEARCH ACTIVITIES AND FITS INTO THE CENTRALIZED RESEARCH SUPPORT SYSTEMS NEED OF THE CBG.

THIS RESEARCH FOCUSES ON THE MECHANISMS UNDERLYING THE LOSS OF OAK DOMINANT FORESTS IN THE EASTERN US. A SUSTAINED DECLINE IN OAK RECRUITMENT WILL BE BOTH ECOLOGICALLY AND ECONOMICALLY DEVASTATING DUE TO THE OUTSIZED IMPORTANCE OF THIS TREE GENUS. THE ROLE OF PLANT-SOIL FEEDBACKS HAS BEEN LARGELY IGNORED AS A LIKELY MECHANISM FOR EXACERBATING THE DECLINE OF OAKS AS MESOPHYTIC SPECIES SUCH AS RED MAPLE INCREASE IN ABUNDANCE IN THESE FORESTS. THE FEEDBACK BETWEEN PLANTS AND THEIR MICROBIAL COMMUNITY HAS COME TO THE FOREFRONT OF BOTH PLANT AND FOREST ECOLOGY IN THE LAST FEW DECADES WITH RESEARCH SHOWING LARGE IMPACTS ON COMMUNITY DYNAMICS IN MANY ECOSYSTEMS. IN ONLY THE LAST 5 YEARS, HAVE WE BEGUN TO DISCOVER THAT THE TYPE OF MYCORRHIZAL SYMBIONT ASSOCIATED WITH A PLANT MAY DRASTICALLY INFLUENCE THEIR INTERACTIONS WITH THE SOIL MICROBIAL COMMUNITY AS WELL AS OTHER NEIGHBORING PLANTS. WE PROPOSE THAT AS MESOPHYTIC TREE SPECIES (LARGELY ASSOCIATED WITH ARBUSCULAR MYCORRHIZAL FUNGI) INCREASE IN ABUNDANCE THERE IS CONCOMITANT DECLINE IN SOILS ASSOCIATED WITH ECTOMYCORRHIZAL FUNGI (CRITICAL TO OAK SEEDLING ESTABLISHMENT) EXACERBATING THE DECLINE OF SEEDLING ESTABLISHMENT AND RECRUITMENT. THE COMPLEMENTARY GREENHOUSE- AND FIELD-BASED EXPERIMENTAL WORK WILL COMPLEMENT THE CONTINUATION OF LONG-TERM (> 45 YEARS) MAPPED FOREST STANDS THAT ARE EXPERIENCING A DECLINE IN OAK AND HICKORY ADULTS AS MESOPHYTIC TREES HAVE INCREASED DRAMATICALLY IN ABUNDANCE. THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH CAPACITY AT 1890 LAND GRANT UNIVERSITIES AS WELL AS INSTRUCTION BY SUPPLEMENTING A COURSE ON FOREST ECOLOGY AND MANAGEMENT AT TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY.

THE NUTRITION AND FOOD MANAGEMENT (NFM) PROGRAM IN THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES AT SOUTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY (SCSU) REQUIRES UPDATES TO THE CURRENT FOOD AND NUTRITION LABORATORIES AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF A SIMULATION LABORATORY TO TRAIN THE NEXT GENERATION OF DIETITIANS, FOOD SCIENTISTS AND FOOD MANAGERS. SOUTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY IS THE ONLY HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGE/UNIVERSITY (HBCU) IN SOUTH CAROLINA WITH A DIDACTIC PROGRAM IN DIETETICS ACCREDITED BY THE ACCREDITATION COUNCIL FOR EDUCATION IN NUTRITION AND DIETETICS FOR MORE THAN TWENTY YEARS. THE NUTRITION AND FOOD MANAGEMENT (NFM) PROGRAM CURRENTLY SERVES EIGHTEEN STUDENTS WHO ELECTED TO ATTEND AN HBCU. THE GOAL OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO ENHANCE THE NFM PROGRAM BY ALLOWING POTENTIAL AND CURRENT STUDENTS TO TRAIN ON STATE-OF-THE-ART EQUIPMENT THAT IS COMPARABLE TO CURRENT INDUSTRY STANDARDS. THE PROJECT WILL ACCOMPLISH THESE THREE OBJECTIVES: 1) TO EQUIP THE NFM LABORATORIES WITH NEW AND UP-TO-DATE EQUIPMENT; 2) TO DEVELOP A DIETETIC SIMULATION LAB FOR STUDENTS TRAINING TO BECOME REGISTERED DIETITIANS; AND 3) TO BUILD THE CAPACITY OF CULTURAL DIVERSITY IN NFM PROFESSIONS. THE PROJECT WILL BE CARRIED OUT OVER A TWO-YEAR PERIOD TO PURCHASE AND INSTALL APPROPRIATE COMMERCIAL EQUIPMENT AND CONDUCT ALTERATIONS FOR THE SIMULATION LABORATORY TO SATISFY THE NEEDS FOR EACH OF THE LABORATORIES. YEAR ONE WILL INCLUDE EQUIPMENT SELECTION, PURCHASE, AND INSTALLATION OF EQUIPMENT FOR THE COMMERCIAL LABORATORY. IN ADDITION, REGISTRATION AND TRAVEL ARRANGEMENTS WILL BE PAID FOR A STUDENT TO ATTEND THE FOOD AND NUTRITION CONFERENCE AND EXPO (FNCE) IN DENVER, CO IN 2023. YEAR TWO WILL INCLUDE EQUIPMENT SELECTION AND THE PURCHASE AND INSTALLATION OF EQUIPMENT AND ALTERATIONS OF THE SIMULATION LABORATORY. SUBSEQUENTIALLY, AS THE LABORATORIES ARE ENHANCED AND REFLECTIVE OF INDUSTRY STANDARDS, THE CURRICULA AND MATERIALS IN THE NFM PROGRAM WILL BE REVISED, UPDATED AND ENHANCED TO ENSURE STUDENTS ARE WELL PREPARED FOR EMPLOYMENT OR GRADUATE STUDIES. ?

THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OF STUDENTS IN THE DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SCIENCES THROUGH STATE-OF-THE-ART EQUIPMENT AND TECHNOLOGY UPGRADES. THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO ENHANCE TEACHING BY INTEGRATING MODERN EQUIPMENT AND TECHNOLOGY THAT WILL BOOST LEARNING OUTCOMES AND PRODUCTIVITY WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT AND ON THE NATIONAL SCENE. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO (1) EVALUATE, IMPROVE AND ENHANCE THE EXISTING CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTER LABORATORY BY ADOPTING THE USE OF TECHNOLOGY TO SUPPORT COURSE REQUIREMENTS RELATED TO CHILD STUDY AND OBSERVATION (STATE-OF-THE-ART LABORATORY); (2) ENHANCE THE EXISTING QUANTITY FOODS LAB BY ADDING UP-TO-DATE TECHNOLOGY AND EQUIPMENT; ADOPTING THE USE OF SPSS SOFTWARE TECHNOLOGY FOR ANALYZING QUANTITATIVE DATA AND NVIVO TO ANALYZE QUALITATIVE DATA THAT WILL SUPPORT STUDENTS' RESEARCH PROJECTS IN ALL HUMAN SCIENCES PROGRAMS WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT; (3) ENHANCE THE EXISTING JEWELL KING HOSPITALITY SUITE 233 BY ADDING UP-TO-DATE EQUIPMENT; AND (4) USE THE UPGRADED FACILITIES TO MARKET ALL PROGRAMS WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SCIENCES, INCLUDING THE FOOD SERVICE RESTAURANT MANAGEMENT/ HOSPITALITY TOURISM MANAGEMENT, AND THE FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES RELATED AREAS.

DRY BEANS (PHASEOLUS VULGARIS) ARE ONE OF THE MOST WIDELY PRODUCED AND AVAILABLE SUSTAINABLE FOODS IN THE WORLD. WHILE DRY BEANS CONTAIN HUGE QUANTITIES OF ESSENTIAL NUTRIENTS, THE UTILIZATION IS LIMITED BY THE PRESENCE OF ANTINUTRITIONAL FACTORS (ANFS) THAT CONTRIBUTE TO REDUCING THE BIOAVAILABILITY OF NUTRIENTS. THERMAL PROCESSING, WHICH HAS BEEN USED TO REDUCE ANFS, CAN AFFLICT ESSENTIAL NUTRIENTS CONTENTS AND REDUCE ITS BIOAVAILABILITY, NUTRITIVE VALUE AND FUNCTIONAL PROPERTIES. NON-THERMAL PROCESSING SUCH AS HIGH-PRESSURE PROCESSING (HPP) AND COLD PLASMA (CP) ARE TWO NOVEL TECHNOLOGIES FOCUSED ON DECONTAMINATION OF MICROORGANISMS TO IMPROVE FOOD SAFETY. HOWEVER, A LARGE GAP EXISTS REGARDING HPP AND CP UTILIZATION TO ASSIST IN THE EXTRACTION OF BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS, REDUCE ANFS AND IMPROVE FUNCTIONAL CHARACTERISTICS OF FOODS. THIS FORMS THE BASIS OF OUR RESEARCH.

EDAMAME AND FOOD-GRADE SOYBEANS ARE IMPORTANT FOR FOOD, SMALL OR ORGANIC FARMING AND URBAN AGRICULTURE. ECONOMICALLY THEY ALSO PLAY A ROLE IN INTERNATIONAL TRADE. MORE AND MORE PEOPLE HAVE REALIZED THE HEALTH BENEFITS OF EDAMAME AND SOY FOOD, RESULTING IN AN INCREASED CONSUMPTION OF EDAMAME AND SOY FOOD. DEMAND FOR EDAMAME AND SPECIALTY SOYBEANS HAS SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASED AND PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY FOR PRODUCERS, ESPECIALLY SMALL FARMERS, TO INCREASE THEIR INCOME. HOWEVER, ABOUT 70% OF THE EDAMAME CONSUMED IN THE US MARKET IS IMPORTED FROM OVERSEAS, AND MOST OF THE EDAMAME VARIETIES GROWN IN THE UNITED STATES WERE DEVELOPED OUTSIDE OF USA AND NOT WELL ADAPTED TO THE LOCAL ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS AND CROP MANAGEMENT PRACTICES.TO DATE VERY LIMITED EFFORTS HAVE BEEN DEDICATED TO EDAMAME BREEDING IN THE USA PLANT BREEDING PROGRAMS. THEREFORE, EFFORT AND INVESTMENT TO RESEARCH IN THIS AREA WILL SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE THE BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH OF PLANT SCIENCE AT THE HOST INSTITUTION AND BEYOND.THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT AND BEYOND IS TO STRENGTHEN THE CAPACITY OF GENETIC IMPROVEMENT BY INTEGRATING MULTIPLE-DISCIPLINARY AND MULTIPLE-INSTITUTIONAL COLLABORATION. FOR THIS GOAL, THE SUPPORTING OBJECTIVES AND ACTIVITIES INCLUDE:1) ENHANCE BREEDING MATERIALS AND INTRODUCE NEW SOYBEAN GERMPLASM THAT POSSESS DESIRED CHARACTERISTICS FOR USE OF EDAMAME AND DUAL-PURPOSE SOYBEANS; 2) EVALUATE AND IDENTIFY PROMISING EDAMAME AND DUAL-PURPOSE SOYBEAN LINES ADAPTED TO SOUTH ATLANTIC STATES; 3) CONDUCT SEED INCREASE, LARGE-PLOT AND HIGH-TUNNEL TRIALS OF SUPERIOR LINES SELECTED TO RELEASE NEW VARIETIES FOR PRODUCTION; 4) ANALYZE GENOMIC VARIATION AND GENETIC RELATIONSHIP OF BREEDING LINES FOR RELEASE AND FURTHER USES; AND 5) DEVELOP EDUCATIONAL TRAINING MATERIALS AND CONDUCT PRODUCER TRAINING ON EDAMAME PRODUCTION, VALUE-ADDED PROCESSING, AND MARKETING.CLASSICAL PLANT BREEDING TECHNIQUES AND NEW APPROACHES WILL BE USED TO ACCOMPLISH THE PROJECT. THESE METHODS INCLDUE BUT NOT LIMITED TO CROSS BREEDING, FIELD OBSERVATION/ASSESSMENT, LAB AND EQUIPMENT ANALYSIS, HIGHTHROUGHPUTPHENOTYPING ANDGENOTYPING WITHSINGLE NUCLEOTIDE POLYMORPHISM (SNP) MARKERS. REPLICATED RANDOMIZED COMPLETE BLOCK DESGN (RCBD) WILL BE USED FOR THE FIELD EXPERIMENTS, AND THE TRIALS WILL BE CODUCED UNDER MULTIPLE ENVIRONMENTS (YEARS AND LOCATIONS). ACOLLABORATION TEAM INTEGRATED WITH MULTIPLE DISCIPLINES AND ORGANIZATIONS, CONSISTING OF PLANT BREEDER, GENETICS, PATHOLOGIST, FOOD SCIENTIST, AGRICULTURAL EXTENSION SPECIALISTS,AND MARKETING PEOPLE,WILL EXECUTE THIS PROJECT. THROUGH SUCH COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS, THIS PROJECT WILL SCIENTIFICALLY ADDRESS THE PROBLEMS AND CHALLENGES IN EDAMAME/SPECIALTY SOYBEAN BREEDING AND PRODUCTION. IT WILL LEAD TO AND BE VALUED BY ENHANCED BREEDING BASIS, MORE VARIETIES AND GERMPLASM LINES DEVELOPED. IT WILLENRICHG BREEDING RESERVOIR, EXPEDITE BREEDING PROGRESS AND EXPAND GENETIC BASIS IN THE CROP. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO HELP BUILD A MULTI-DISCIPLINARY AND MULTI-IN,STITUTIONAL COLLABORATION, ESPECIALLY A COLLABORATION BETWEEN PLANT BREEDING AND EXTENSION AS WELL AS PRODUCTION, AND THUS FACILITATE TRANSFORMATION AND APPLICATION OF RESEARCH ACHIEVEMENTS (E.G., NEW CROP VARIETIES).THE ANTICIPATED IMPACTWILL ALSO INCLUDE GENERATING NEW KNOWLEDGE IN BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH, PROVIDING ALTERNATIVES/OPTIONS FOR GROWERS TO INCREASE INCOME, AND HELPING STUDENTS DEVELOP COLLABORATION, COMMUNICATION AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS. THUSTHE PROJECT WILL SIGNIFICANTLY ENHANCE THE ABILITY AND OPPORTUNITIES OF FUTURE RESEARCH AND STUDENT TRAINING IN PLANT SCIENCES AND RELATED FIELDS AT VSU, AND ALSO IT IS HIGHLY RELEVANT TO THE GOALS OF THE CBG PROGRAM. ULTIMATELY, IT WILL BE BENEFICIAL TO THE U.S. AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND HIGHER EDUCATION IN GENERAL.

FOOD SAFETY PRACTICES AND RAPID, LOW-COST PATHOGEN DETECTION TECHNOLOGIES ARE NEEDED TO DETECT CONTAMINATION OF LEAFY GREENS (LGS) IN SOILLESS SYSTEMS. THIS INTEGRATED PROJECT WILL DEVELOP EFFECTIVE/EFFICIENT PROCEDURES TO RAPIDLY DETECT LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES (LM) PRE-/POST-HARVEST IN SOILLESS SYSTEMS USING A NOVEL APTAMERIC-NANOSENSOR. POTENTIAL LM DETECTION INTERFERENTS WILL BE RESOLVED BY ITERATIVE ASSAY ADAPTATIONS. NANOSENSOR DETECTION PERFORMANCE WILL BE VALIDATED USING STANDARD METHODS. COMPARISON OF SYSTEM FACTORS (NUTRIENT SOLUTION QUALITY, PLANT ROOTS/SHOOTS, AND MICROBIOME QUALITY) FROM CONTROLLED RESEARCH AND SOILLESS LGS PRODUCER SYSTEMS WILL BE USED TO REVEAL KEY FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO GROWTH/SURVIVAL AND LM DETECTION INTERFERENTS. USING MACHINE LEARNING, WE WILL ADAPT/MODIFY THE NANOSENSOR AND SMART-PHONE TECHNOLOGIES TO DEVELOP A COST-EFFECTIVE, RAPID LISTERIA MONOCYTOGENES DETECTION SYSTEM FOR USE BY PRODUCERS. DOSE CHALLENGE INOCULATION AND MICROBIAL COMMUNITY TRIALS WILL REVEAL RELATIVE CONTAMINATION RISKS AND EFFECTS OF PREVENTIVE CONTROLS ON PATHOGENS AND MAINTENANCE OF SYSTEM PRODUCTIVITY. UMES AND DSU FACULTY AND STUDENTS WILL BE TRAINED IN PATHOGENS DETECTION, SOILLESS SYSTEM QUALITY CONTROLS, THUS GAINING REAL-WORLD EXPERIENCES IN FOOD SAFETY, MICROBIOME RESEARCH, AND SAFE FOOD PRODUCTION. UMES AND DSU WILL DEVELOP/DELIVER E-LEARNING WORKSHOPS ON PRE-/POST-HARVEST PRODUCE SAFETY FOR STUDENTS IN PREPARATION FOR PROFESSIONAL POST-GRADUATE POSITIONS. DELMARVA GROWERS WILL BE TRAINED IN BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, AND PRE-/POST-HARVEST FOOD SAFETY PREVENTIVE CONTROLS FOR SOILLESS SYSTEMS. TRAINING/TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN GOOD AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, GOOD HANDLING PRACTICES, AND FOOD SAFETY PLANS WILL BE PROVIDED TO LIMITED-RESOURCE PRODUCE GROWERS/MARKET MANAGERS SERVING 1890 INSTITUTION COMMUNITIES. THUS, THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD CAPACITY AT UMES AND DSU IN SAFE SOILLESS LGS PRODUCTION.

MICROALGAE ARE IDENTIFIED AS AN ATTRACTIVE SOURCE FOR PRODUCTION VARIOUS TYPES OF HIGH-VALUE MOLECULES AND BIOFUEL, HOWEVER THE POTENTIAL OF MICROALGAE AS A SOURCE OF BIOENERGY IS NOT YET ECONOMICALLY FEASIBLE, DUE TO THE LOW YIELDS OF BIOMASS AND LIPIDS. IN THIS REGARD, INTEGRATION THE BIOREFINERY PATHWAYS WITH BIOFUEL PRODUCTION FOR THE RECOVERY OF THE HIGH-VALUE MOLECULES COULD SIGNIFICANTLY DECREASE THE PRODUCTION COST OF THE SYSTEM. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH AND INTRODUCE AN OPTIMIZED AND COST- EFFECTIVE MICROALGAL PLATFORM FOR SIMULTANEOUS PRODUCTION OF HIGH VALUE BIOACTIVE MOLECULES AND BIOFUEL. THESE RESULTS WILL FULFILL THE VITAL KNOWLEDGE GAP IN INTRODUCING A COST-EFFECTIVE ENGINEERED MICROALGAL PRODUCTION PLATFORM UNDER SMART-FARMING CONDITIONS. OUR PROJECT IS LINKED TO NIFA AND USDA MAJOR GOALS TO 1. ADVANCE THE CULTURAL DIVERSITY OF THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES SCIENTIFIC AND PROFESSIONAL WORKFORCE BY ATTRACTING AND EDUCATING MORE STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS, 2. STRENGTHEN LINKAGES AMONG THE 1890 INSTITUTIONS, OTHER COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES, USDA, OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES, AND PRIVATE INDUSTRY, AND 3. ENHANCE AND STRENGTHEN THE QUALITY OF TEACHING/EDUCATION, RESEARCH, AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS AT THE 1890 INSTITUTIONS TO ESTABLISH THEM AS FULL PARTNERS IN THE U.S. FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES HIGHER EDUCATION SYSTEM. THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD CAPACITY AT DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY (DSU) BY EXPANDING THE ABILITY OF DSU AND FACULTY AND STUDENTS TO CONDUCT RESEARCH IN THE PROJECT SUPPORTS CBG PRIORITY AREAS IN 1. HUMAN HEALTH, AND NUTRITION SECURITY, 2. BIOENERGY/BIOFUEL AND NATURAL RESOURCES, AND 3. SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE.

GLOBAL CLIMATIC CHANGES ARE PREDICTED TO PROVOKE WORLDWIDE EXTREME ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, LIMITING CROP GROWTH AND PRODUCTIVITY. THE HIGHLY FREQUENT FLOODING EVENTS ARE FORCING GLOBALLY MORE CLIMATE CHALLENGES ON THE AGRICULTURE SECTOR. ADDRESSING THESE CHALLENGES THROUGH SMART-AGRICULTURAL-PRACTICES IS NOT ALWAYS A SUSTAINABLE SOLUTION, SO THERE IS A GROWING NEED TO IDENTIFY AND/OR BREED STRESS-TOLERANT CULTIVARS/ROOTSTOCKS TO MAINTAIN SUSTAINABILITY IN THE CONTEXT OF CLIMATE CHANGE. IN THE CURRENT PROJECT, THE MUSCADINE GRAPEVINE, A MAJOR FRUIT CROP OF ECONOMIC IMPORTANCE, HAS EMERGED AS A MODEL PERENNIAL FRUIT CROP FOR STUDYING ROOT-HYPOXIA TOLERANCE. OUR RESEARCH SUGGESTED THAT MUSCADINES COULD RESPOND TO THE ENVIRONMENTAL STRESS STIMULI BY REBUILDING THEIR DEFENSE MECHANISM AND SYSTEM ARCHITECTURE, MODIFYING WHOLE VINE STRATEGIES TO AVOID THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT WITH MAINTAINING PRODUCTIVITY. OUR PRIMARY RESEARCH FINDING HAS SUGGESTED HOW VINES POTENTIALLY PERCEIVED THE ALERTSIGNAL AND HOW THEY GOVERNED THE SUBSEQUENT CHANGES IN GROWTH BEHAVIOR. IT PROPOSED THAT GRAPEVINES UTILIZED THE ANTIOXIDATIVE DEFENSE MECHANISM TO PERMIT FLEXIBLE AND APPROPRIATE MODULATION OF PLANT GROWTH IN RESPONSE TO THE CHANGES IN NATURAL ENVIRONMENTS. THESE DIFFERENT KEY PLAYERS WORK MUTUALLY AND/OR INDEPENDENTLY TO COORDINATE THE VINE DECISION IF EXPOSED TO UNFAVORABLE ENVIRONMENTAL CIRCUMSTANCES. THE TARGET OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY MOLECULAR MECHANISMS AND METABOLOME ARCHITECTURE UNDERLYING ROOT-HYPOXIA TOLERANCE/RESISTANCE IN MUSCADINE. GIVEN THE EXISTING GAPS IN OUR KNOWLEDGE OF THE MECHANISMS UNDERLYING GRAPEVINE-WATERLOGGING RESPONSES, WE AIM TO ANSWER THE FOLLOWING QUESTION: HOW CAN WE MOVE TOWARDS A MORE INTEGRATIVE DEFINITION OF GRAPEVINE STRESS TOLERANCE?

MUSCADINE GRAPES ARE NATIVE TO SOUTHEASTERN USA AND PRIMARILY GROWN FOR TABLE AND WINE MAKING. DESPITE HIGH NUTRACEUTICAL VALUE AND HEALTH BENEFITS THEY ARE NOT PREFERRED OVER EUROPEAN BUNCH GRAPE BECAUSE OF THEIR LOW SUGAR CONTENT AND SHORT PRODUCT SHELF LIFE. HIGH LEVEL OF NATURAL SUGAR IS CRUCIAL IN DEVELOPING BERRY SINCE IT SERVES AS A PRIMARY SUBSTRATE AND CARBON BACKBONE FOR SECONDARY METABOLITES PRODUCTION. ACCORDING TO OUR FINDINGS, MUSCADINE GRAPE IS A SUCROSE-ACCUMULATOR WHILE BUNCH GRAPE A HEXOSE-ACCUMULATOR WHICH NEGATIVELY IMPACTS SUGAR TRANSPORT TO MUSCADINE BERRY. OUR RESEARCH ALSO SHOWED THAT THAT PHOTOSYNTHETIC EFFICIENCY MAY NOT BE A REGULATING FACTOR FOR LOW SUGAR ACCUMULATION IN MUSCADINE GRAPE. HENCE, WE PROPOSE TO TAKE A FUNCTIONAL GENOMICS APPROACHTO IDENTIFY CANDIDATE GENE/S REGULATING SUGAR ACCUMULATION. THE FUNCTION OF CANDIDATE GENE/S WILL BE VALIDATED IN A HETERLOGOUS MODEL SYSTEM.THIS APPROACH WILL HELP IDENTIFY CANDIDATE GENE/S TO DEVELOP HIGH SUGAR MUSCADINE GRAPE FOR IMPROVING ITS PRODUCT QUALITY AND MARKET VALUE. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO HELP BUILD FAMU CAPACITY IN FUNCTIONAL GENOMICS, DEVELOP COMPETENT WORKFORCE, SUPPORT STAKEHOLDER NEEDS, AND ENHANCE MARKETABILITY TO SUSTAIN MUSCADINE GRAPE INDUSTRY.

FLORIDA IS ONE OF THE LARGEST WINE MARKETS IN THE U.S. AND IS RANKED AMONG THE TOP 10 IN WINE PRODUCTION IN THE NATION. FLORIDA'S WINES ARE PREDOMINANTLY PRODUCED WITH MUSCADINE GRAPES (MUSCADINIA ROTUNDIFOLIA, SMALL) YET ARE FERMENTED BY GENERIC COMMERCIAL STRAINS OF SACCHAROMYCES CEREVISIAE WHICH ORIGINATE AND ARE USED WITH THE TRADITIONAL EUROPEAN GRAPES(VITIS VINIFERA,L).A NEW TREND IN MODERN WINEMAKING IS THE USE OF THE ALMOST FORGOTTEN NATURAL FERMENTATION WITH INDIGENOUS YEAST, WHICH CAN ENHANCE THE REGIONAL CHARACTER OF THE WINE BY PRODUCING DISTINCT COLOR, FLAVOR, AROMA, HEALTH-BENEFICIAL BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS, AND BETTER MARKET VALUE OF THE FINAL PRODUCT.FLORIDA'S UNIQUE CLIMATIC CONDITIONS HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO PRODUCE YEASTS WITH FAVORABLE AND SIGNATURE AROMA PROFILES. WITH THIS MULTIDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH PROJECT, WE ARE AIMING TO: (1) REACH TO NEW DISCOVERIES BY GENERATING THE UPLC-TOF-MS AND GC-MS-BASED NON-TARGETED METABOLOMIC PROFILES OF SIGNATURE STYLES OF MUSCADINE WINES FERMENTED WITH INDIGENOUS YEASTS; (2) ESTABLISH AND CURATE MUCH-NEEDED REFERENCE BIOREPOSITORY OF AUTOCHTHONOUS YEAST SPECIES FROM REGIONAL MUSCADINE VINEYARDS (FL, LA, TX) FOR THE USE OF RESEARCHERS AND INDUSTRY; AND (3) EXPAND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR MINORITY STUDENTS, PRODUCERS AND EXTENSION PERSONNEL IN ADVANCED BIOPROCESSING TECHNOLOGIES.EXPECTED OUTCOMES WILL NOT BE LIMITED ONLY TO: (I) NOVEL MUSCADINE WINE METABOLOMICS DATA AND ORIGINAL MUSCADINE WINEMAKING YEAST STRAINS; (II) NEW FAMU PATENTS; (III) NEW HIGH-QUALITY REGIONAL WINES; (IV) NEW MARKET OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE INDUSTRY; (V) TRAINING OPPORTUNITY FOR YOUNG PROFESSIONALS IN CUTTING EDGE TECHNOLOGIES; (VI) NEW WORKFORCE AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT FOR RURAL COMMUNITIES IN THE SOUTHEASTERN U.S.

PLANT BIOMASS AND SEED OILS REPRESENT A SIGNIFICANT, ENERGY-RICH SOURCE OF RENEWABLE HYDROCARBONS. HOWEVER, DUE TO LOW CROP YIELD, COMPETITION WITH FOOD PRODUCTION, AND LIMITED ARABLE LAND AVAILABILITY, CURRENT SUPPLIES OF THESE ENERGY-RICH COMPOUNDS ARE LIMITED. SWITCHGRASS (PANICUM VIRGATUM L.) IS A PERENNIAL, WARM-SEASON, DEDICATED BIOENERGY CROP CAPABLE OF PRODUCING HIGHER BIOMASS SUITABLE AS A BIOENERGY FEEDSTOCK. IN SWITCHGRASS, TRAIT IMPROVEMENT BY TRADITIONAL BREEDING IS HAMPERED DUE TO GENETIC COMPLEXITY AND THE AVAILABILITY OF RESOURCES. BIOTECHNOLOGY, HOWEVER, ENABLES THE GENETIC ENHANCEMENT OF SWITCHGRASS BY FOCUSING ON THE DESIRED TRAITS THAT ARE NOT PRESENT IN NATURE. OUR GOAL IS TO INCREASE PHOTOSYNTHESIS AND BIOMASS PRODUCTION IN SWITCHGRASS BY THE ECTOPIC INTRODUCTION OF A FOREIGN GENE AND ALSO TO ENHANCE PLANT RESILIENCE TO STRESSES. WITH THE POTENTIAL TO DEVELOP BREAKTHROUGH TECHNOLOGY FOR AN IMPORTANT BIOENERGY CROP, THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AT WEST VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY (WVSU) AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE FIELD OF BIOENERGY RESEARCH.

EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS AND THEIR COMMUNITY PARTNERS HAVE ACCESS TO INCREASING VOLUMES OF DATA. THIS DATA MAY BE USED TO ASSESS LOCAL CONDITIONS, DEVELOP STRATEGIES AND POLICIES, OR TO EVALUATE PROGRAM IMPACT. DESPITE THIS INCREASE IN AVAILABILITY AND DESIRE TO USE DATA, DATA USE OFTEN DOES NOT MEET CAPACITY DUE TO LIMITATIONS IN THE TECHNICAL ABILITY TO PROCESS AND ANALYZE THE DATA, AS WELL AS TIME TO DEDICATE TO DATA PROCESSING, ANALYSIS, AND EFFECTIVE PRESENTATION. THUS, COMMUNITIES NEED ASSISTANCE FROM INDIVIDUALS WITH EXPERTISE IN ANALYTICS AND FAMILIAR WITH THE SOCIAL AND COMMUNITY APPLICATIONS OF THOSE ANALYTICS TO HELP MANAGE, ANALYZE, AND INTERPRET THIS DATA. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO ADDRESS THESE ISSUES BY CREATING A CENTER FOR SOCIAL DATA ANALYTICS (CSDA) AT VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY. THROUGH THE CSDA, WE WILL CONNECT EXTENSION WITH PARTNERS ACROSS THE UNIVERSITY IN TRAINING STUDENTS IN DATA ANALYTICS AND THE APPLICATION OF DATA ANALYTICS TO COMMUNITY & EXTENSION ISSUES AND WILL CONNECT EXTENSION WITH CAMPUS EXPERTISE IN DATA ANALYTICS AND PROVIDING TRAINING IN DATA LITERACY TO EXTENSION COMMUNITIES.THE HALLMARK OF THE CSDA'S ACTIVITIES WILL BE THE DATA SCIENCE FOR THE PUBLIC GOOD (DSPG) YOUNG SCHOLARS PROGRAM. THIS WILL BE A 10-WEEK DSPG SUMMER PROGRAM FOR UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS. THE STUDENTS WILL BE PARTNERED WITH FACULTY AND EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS TO FORM COMMUNITY-FOCUSED RESEARCH TEAMS AND CARRY OUT COLLABORATIVELY CONSTRUCTED DATA SCIENCE PROJECTS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS. WE WILL IDENTIFY COMMUNITY-BASED RESEARCH PROBLEMS BY ENGAGING THE EXPERTISE AND COMMUNITY KNOWLEDGE OF EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS THROUGH OUR COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE. EXTENSION EDUCATORS, STAFF, AND FACULTY WILL BE ELIGIBLE TO ACT AS PROJECT ADVISORS WHO COORDINATE WITH COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS TO IDENTIFY ISSUES OR CONCERNS, NOTE RELEVANT DATA SOURCES, AND HELP GUIDE THE WORK OF THE RESEARCH TEAMS. DURING THE COURSE OF THE PROGRAM, WE WILL IMMERSE OURSTUDENTS AND FACULTY IN DATA SCIENCE THROUGH WORKSHOPS AND TRAINING ON STATISTICAL COMPUTING AND VISUALIZATION TOOLS INCLUDING R, AND GIS; ACCESSING AND USING LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL DATA RESOURCES SUCH AS CENSUS PRODUCTS AND OPEN DATA PORTALS; AND LEARNING ABOUT POLICY AND ETHICS.THROUGH THE CSDA'S ACTIVITIES, EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS AND COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS WILL ALSO HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO RECEIVE TRAINING ON DATA SCIENCE LITERACY, TO ACCESS AVAILABLE TOOLS AND RESOURCES, AND TO UNDERSTAND THE PROMISE OF DATA SCIENCE TO ADDRESS THEIR PROBLEMS. THIS TRAINING WILL OCCUR BOTH IN TANDEM WITH THE DSPG YOUNG SCHOLAR'S PROGRAM, AND YEAR-ROUND IN COORDINATION WITH THE REGULAR ACTIVITIES OF EXTENSION.WE BELIEVE THIS APPROACH WILL CREATE:KNOWLEDGE, EXPERTISE, DISCOVERIES, AND TRAINING PRODUCTS THAT CAN IMPROVE THE ABILITY OF COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS TO ASSIST STAKEHOLDERS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES IN THE USE OF DATA-DRIVEN APPROACHES.NEW INTEREST IN THE EXTENSION WORK AND, P,OTENTIALLY, CAREERS THROUGH THE ENGAGEMENT OF THE STUDENTS AND FACULTY FROM THE BROADER CAMPUS COMMUNITY.A PROGRAM OF RESEARCH THAT ADDRESSES DIVERSE COMMUNITY CHALLENGES THAT LIE BEYOND THE SCOPE OF ANY SINGLE FIELD OF STUDY AND HELPS ATTRACT THE RELEVANT SKILLS FROM ACROSS THE CAMPUS TO ENGAGE IN EXTENSION PROBLEMS.A COMMUNITY-ORIENTED APPROACH TO DATA SCIENCE EDUCATION WITH A STRONG CORE IN EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, WHICH HAS THE POTENTIAL TO TRANSFORM TEACHING PRACTICES IN DATA SCIENCE BY INCORPORATING THE PERSPECTIVES AND KNOWLEDGE FROM DIFFERENT FIELDS OF STUDY, DIFFERENT DATA APPLICATION ENVIRONMENTS, AND DIVERSE COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS.

WITH ITS HIGH ECONOMIC VALUE AND MULTIPLE USES, SOYBEAN (GLYCINE MAX (L.) MERR.) IS AN OILSEED CROP THAT PLAYS A VITAL ROLE IN ADDRESSING INCREASING GLOBAL DEMAND IN THE FOOD, FEED, FUEL, AND CHEMICAL SECTORS. HOWEVER, AS WE ENTER AN ERA IN WHICH GLOBAL FOOD PRODUCTION IS LIKELY TO DOUBLE AS THE HUMAN POPULATION INCREASES, USING PRIME AGRICULTURAL LANDS AND RESOURCES FOR FOOD, FEED, AND ENERGY PRODUCTION WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF CLIMATE CHANGE BECOMES AN EVEN MORE SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGE. ADVANCES IN TRADITIONAL BREEDING AND AGRONOMIC PRACTICES HAVE STEADILY INCREASED SOYBEAN SEED YIELDS AND TOLERANCE TO BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC STRESSES, WHICH IS ESSENTIAL IN ENHANCING SEED YIELD. HOWEVER, DUE TO THE CONSTRAINTS OF RELATIVELY LIMITED GENETIC DIVERSITY, ESPECIALLY WHEN COMPARED TO CROPS SUCH AS MAIZE, FURTHER GAINS FROM SOYBEAN BREEDING MAY BE INCREMENTAL. WE AIM TO HAVE SOLAR RADIATION STRESS TOLERANCE IN SOYBEAN PLANTS AND ENHANCE SEED YIELD. DEVELOPMENT OF TOOLS SUCH AS GENE CONSTRUCTS, AGROBACTERIUM-MEDIATED TRANSFORMATION, MOLECULAR AND BIOCHEMICAL METHODS, AND TRANSGENIC SOYBEAN LINES WITH ALTERED SEED COMPOUNDS WILL BE NECESSARY FOR SCIENTISTS WORKING IN BASIC AND APPLIED ENERGY RESEARCH. SHARING LARGE-SCALE SEQUENCING AND LIPIDOMICS DATA IN THIS PROJECT WITH THE BROADER SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY WILL SUPPORT CROP IMPROVEMENT RESEARCH PROJECTS.

GENOMIC METHODS FACILITATED THE IDENTIFICATION OF ASSOCIATED QUANTITATIVE TRAIT NUCLEOTIDES (QTNS) EFFECTS RANGING FROM NEGATIVE TO POSITIVE ON THE PHENOTYPE. THE TREND IS PYRAMIDING POSITIVE-EFFECT QTNS AND PURGING DELETERIOUS ALLELES WITH THE GENOME EDITING TECHNOLOGIES CALLED PAGE (I.E., PROMOTING ALLELES BY GENOME EDITING). MODERN CROP IMPROVEMENT IS BASED ON THE INTROGRESSION OF FAVORABLE ALLELES FROM LANDRACES AND KNOCKING OFF DELETERIOUS ALLELES THAT PASS ALONG THE DOMESTICATION AND BREEDING PROCESSES. TO TAKE FULL ADVANTAGE OF THESE GENOMIC RESOURCES, WE NEED KNOWLEDGE OF DATA-DRIVEN ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE (AI) METHODOLOGIES AND TO INTEGRATE WITH MODERN HIGH-THROUGHPUT TECHNOLOGIES. ML AND SYSTEMS GENOMICS HAVE BEEN EXTENSIVELY USED TO ANALYZE GENOMIC DATA. IN THIS PROPOSAL, WE ASSEMBLED INTRODUCTORY TUTORIAL MODULES FOR GENOMIC-DRIVEN IDENTIFICATION OF ALLELIC EFFECTS AND METHODS FOR BUILDING MULTIPLE FAVORABLE ALLELE RECOMBINANTS.THE PROPOSED INFRASTRUCTURE WILL SIGNIFICANTLY ENHANCE THE TEACHING CAPACITY IN THE AREA OF GENOME EDITING WITH SPECIAL REFERENCE TO TOMATO AND PHENOMIC METHODS TO ACCELERATE THE IDENTIFICATION OF GENES UNDERLING VARIOUS TRAITS SUCH AS FRUIT COLORS AND OTHER FRUIT ATTRIBUTES INCLUDING SIZE AND SHAPE. THE NEWLY ACQUIRED INSTRUMENTATION THROUGH THIS PROPOSAL WILL ALSO BE USED TO ORGANIZE PHENOMIC AND MACHINE LEARNING WORKSHOPS USING MECHANISMS UNDERLYING TOMATO FRUIT COLORS AND RELATED METABOLITES. THE PROPOSED INSTRUMENTATION WILL BENEFIT APPROXIMATELY 50-60 UNDERGRADUATE AND MASTER'S STUDENTS IN THE BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES AND BIOTECHNOLOGY AT WVSU BY PROVIDING ACCESS TO GENOME ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES THROUGH A SPECIALLY DESIGNED COURSE AS WELL AS FACULTY-DIRECTED RESEARCH IN PLANT GENOMICS, METABOLOMICS, BIOINFORMATICS, AND MACHINE LEARNING.

HEALTHY SOIL IS A CRITICAL AND FOUNDATIONAL COMPONENT FOR SUSTAINING THE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION OF GRAINS, FIBER, FRUITS, VEGETABLES, AND ANIMAL FEED. INAPPROPRIATE SOIL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES HAVE LED TO SIGNIFICANT DECLINES IN SOIL HEALTH AS EVIDENCED BY SOIL EROSION, DEGRADED FERTILITYAND PRODUCTIVITY, REDUCED VITAL PHYSIO-CHEMICAL PROPERTIES, AND INCREASED SOIL INPUT DEMANDS. AN ASTOUNDING 75 BILLION TONS OF SOIL LOSSES HAVE BEEN REPORTED ANNUALLY FROM THE GLOBAL LAND SURFACE AT THE COST OF $400 BILLION. THIS MAGNITUDE OF FAILURE OVER TIME HAS LED TO A SIGNIFICANT PROBLEM IN MAINTAINING SOILS HEALTHY ENOUGH TO MEET THE FOOD DEMAND OF A GROWING GLOBAL POPULATION, ESTIMATED TO INCREASE TO 9.7 BILLION BY 2050. AS AN EXTENSION OUTREACH-EDUCATION PROJECT, WE WILL FOCUS ONTRAININGUNDERGRADUATE STUDENTSAND FARMERS/PRODUCERS ONIMPROVING THE HEALTH AND PRODUCTIVITY OF SOILS FOR BETTER ECONOMIC CROP RETURNS AND CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION. THIS EFFORT WILL PRODUCE MORE ROBUST 1890 LAND-GRANT UNIVERSITY SOIL HEALTH EDUCATION CURRICULAR PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO PREPARE STUDENTS FOR THE CHALLENGES OF ENTERING THEJOB MARKET AT USDA AND RELATED AGENCIES. BASIC METHODS WILL INCLUDE MODULARIZINGEXISTING DEPARTMENTAL COURSES DESIGNED TO EDUCATE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS ABOUT THE MANAGEMENT, SCIENTIFIC PRINCIPLES, AND TECHNOLOGIES OF SOIL HEALTH AND ITS ROLE IN ACHIEVING FOOD SECURITY AND MITIGATING CLIMATE CHANGE. THESE METHODS, IN ADDITION TO THE LABORATORY AND IN-THE-FIELD EXPERIENCE TRAINING, WILL ALSOPREPARE STUDENTS FOR ENTRY-LEVEL EMPLOYMENT WITH USDA AND RELATED AGENCIES UPON GRADUATION. ARESEARCHCOMPONENT IS FEATUREDTO STUDY THE IMPACT OF WINTER COVER CROPPING AND COMPOST IMPACTS ON NITROGEN USE EFFICIENCY,FLOWS IN ORGANIC VEGETABLE PRODUCTION, AND SOIL ORGANIC MATTER IMPROVEMENTS ON SANDY SOIL IN THE DELMARVA PENINSULA REGION. SUCH RESEARCH WILL HELP MITIGATE CLIMATE CHANGE BYIMPROVINGTHE PRODUCTIVITY OF SANDY SOILS THIS PROJECT HAS GREAT POTENTIAL TO DELIVER A SOIL HEALTH MODELPROGRAM TO IMPROVE SOIL HEALTH EDUCATION, RESEARCH, AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS AT ALL 1890 UNIVERSITIES.

MICROBES ARE AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE SOIL ECOSYSTEM. SOIL MICROBES WITH BENEFICIAL PROPERTIES COULD BE UTILIZED FOR SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE, FOOD SECURITY, AND HUMAN HEALTH. AMONG SOIL MICROBES, ACTINOMYCETES AND THEIR METABOLITES OFFER A SOLUTION TO SURPASS THE YIELD BARRIER CAUSED BY PLANT AND FOOD-BORNE BACTERIAL AND FUNGAL PATHOGENS, WHILE AVOIDING SOME OF THE COSTS, AND THE IMPACTS OF CHEMICAL INPUTS (FUNGICIDES, BACTERIOCIDES) ON HUMAN HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT. CURRENT PROPOSAL AIMS TO DEVELOP ACTINOMYCETES-DERIVED METABOLITES AS ANTIMICROBIAL AGENTS TO PREVENT/TREAT PLANT DISEASE AND PRESERVE FRESH PRODUCE AND FOOD FROM SPOILAGE. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO: (1) ISOLATE ACTINOMYCETE SPECIES FROM THE SOILS OF UNIQUE NICHES AND CREATE A LIBRARY OF STRAINS, (2) SCREEN THE ISOLATES TO IDENTIFY BIOACTIVE METABOLITES AGAINST A PANEL OF COMMON FOODBORNE AND PLANT PATHOGENS, AND (3) CHARACTERIZE THE ACTIVE METABOLITES AT THE MOLECULAR LEVEL AND DETERMINE THE EFFICACY OF THE PURE COMPOUNDS AGAINST THE PANEL OF TEST PATHOGENS. THE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL I) OFFER MICROBIAL NATURAL PRODUCT-BASED SOLUTIONS TO CONTROL PLANT AND FOODBORNE PATHOGENS AND ADDRESS SIGNIFICANT PROBLEMS FACING AGRICULTURE AND FOOD PRODUCTION/PROTECTION IN THE US, II) PROVIDE EXCELLENT EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR MINORITY STUDENTS, AND III) ENHANCE RESEARCH, OUTREACH, AND EDUCATION CAPACITIES OF UMES. THIS PROJECT ALIGNS WITH ALL OF THE THREE GOALS OF THE CBG PROGRAM BY ESTABLISHING RESEARCH COLLABORATION BETWEEN UMES AND THE UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY WILL FACILITATE THE EXCHANGE OF IDEAS AND EXPERTISE BETWEEN THE INSTITUTIONS, AND WILL STRENGTHEN RESEARCH CAPABILITIES AT UMES.

IN THE UNITED STATES, CONVENTIONAL RAISED BROILER CHICKENS DOMINATES THE POULTRY INDUSTRY AS IT IS A VERY EFFICIENT AND SAFE METHOD OF POULTRY PRODUCTION. DESPITE THE SAFE AND ECONOMICAL POULTRY PRODUCTS THAT ARE PRODUCED BY U.S. POULTRY COMPANIES, CONSUMER DEMAND FOR MEAT THAT IS PRODUCED THROUGH ALTERNATIVE METHODS (PASTURE, FREE RANGE, AND ORGANIC) CONTINUES TO INCREASE. IN 2019, SALES OF ORGANIC CHICKEN WERE $1.115 BILLION, AND THE VALUE OF THE U.S. BROILER CHICKEN INDUSTRY IN 2021 WAS ABOUT $31.5 BILLION. STUDIES EVALUATING EARLY AGE THERMAL CONDITIONING, DIET MANIPULATION ON HEAT STRESSED PASTURED POULTRY ARE LIMITED. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO 1. EVALUATE THE PERFORMANCE EFFECTS, STRESS RESPONSE PARAMETERS, AND BIRD BEHAVIOR INDICATORS OF EARLY AGE THERMAL CONDITIONING, AND FEEDING TRYPTOPHAN AND PRE AND PROBIOTIC SUPPLEMENTED DIETS, TO MITIGATE THE EFFECTS OF HEAT STRESS ON DIFFERENT BREEDS OF CHICKENS RAISED ON PASTURE; 2. EVALUATE CARCASS MICROBIAL LEVELS AND FECAL MICROBIOME FROM DIFFERENT BREEDS OF CHICKENS RAISED ON PASTURE FED TRYPTOPHAN AND PRE AND PROBIOTIC SUPPLEMENTED DIETS; AND 3. ESTABLISH A PASTURE POULTRY EXTENSION PROGRAM AT UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND EASTERN SHORE (UMES) TO ASSIST POULTRY GROWERS IN THE REGION. THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH A RESEARCH FOUNDATION AT UMES TO DEVELOP RESEARCH PROJECTS TO ADDRESS CHALLENGES SURROUNDING PASTURE RAISED POULTRY, AND EDUCATE HIGH-SKILLED GRADUATES WHO ARE NEEDED IN THE REGION AND NATION. THIS PROJECTMEETS THE FOLLWING CBG PRIORITY AREAS: FOOD SAFETY, RURAL COMMUNITIES FOR THE 21ST CENTURY AND SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE.

HIGHLY INFECTIOUS DISEASES IN POULTRY CAUSED BY INFLUENZA AND CORONAVIRUSES, ANDCAMPYLOBACTERANDSALMONELLARESULT IN SIGNIFICANT ECONOMIC LOSSES FOR FARMERS AND CAN POSE A RISK TO HUMAN HEALTH. NO ANTIVIRAL DRUGS ARE SPECIFICALLY APPROVED FOR TREATING INFLUENZA OR CORONAVIRUS INFECTIONS. ALSO, THE WIDESPREAD USE OF ANTIBIOTICS AGAINST BACTERIAL INFECTIONS HAS LED TO INCREASED PROBLEMS OF ANTIBIOTIC RESISTANCE, AND THE PRESENCE OF THEIR RESIDUES IN THE ENVIRONMENT COMPROMISES HUMAN AND ANIMAL HEALTH. ONE POTENTIAL ALTERNATIVE STRATEGY IS EXPLORING NATURAL PRODUCTS WITH ANTIVIRAL/ANTIBACTERIAL TO REDUCE RELIANCE ON ANTIBIOTICS IN THE POULTRY INDUSTRY. CYANOBACTERIA ARE RELATIVELY EASY TO CULTIVATE IN OPEN AND CLOSED SYSTEMS, DO NOT NEED ARABLE LAND, AND BETTER ATMOSPHERE CARBON CAPTURE AND SOLAR ENERGY CONVERSION EFFICIENCY MAKE THEM A POTENTIALLY SUSTAINABLE, COST-EFFECTIVE, AND ENVIRONMENT-FRIENDLY SOURCE OF NATURAL PRODUCTS. ANTIBACTERIAL AND ANTIVIRAL ACTIVITIES OF SOME CYANOBACTERIAL EXTRACTS/METABOLITES AGAINST SOME MICROBES HAVE BEEN REPORTED IN THE LITERATURE STUDIES. HOWEVER, THE PROPOSED WORK AIMS AT ENTIRE SMALL MOLECULE (> 700 G/MOL) CYANOBACTERIAL METABOLITES FROM CYANOMETDB TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL INHIBITORS AGAINST PROMINENT DRUG TARGET RECEPTORS AND EVALUATION OF ANTIVIRAL/ANTIBACTERIAL ACTIVITIES OF IDENTIFIED COMPOUNDS AND THEIR SOURCE CYANOBACTERIAL CRUDE EXTRACTS AGAINST SPECIFIC HIGHLY INFECTIOUS PATHOGENS IN POULTRY. IN ESSENCE, WE WILL EXPLORE POTENTIAL CRUDE CYANOBACTERIAL EXTRACTS/PURIFIED COMPOUNDS FOR PROPHYLACTIC AND THERAPEUTIC CONTROL OF HIGHLY INFECTIOUS POULTRY VIRUSES AND BACTERIA WHILE GAINING A FUNDAMENTAL UNDERSTANDING OF THEIR MECHANISMS OF ACTION AND THEIR BROAD-SPECTRUM ACTIVITY TO ENHANCE THE ONGOING RESEARCH AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS AT TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY (TSU). THE SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE GAINED THROUGH THE PROPOSED WORK HELPS TO DEVELOP BROAD-SPECTRUM ANTIMICROBIAL FEED SUPPLEMENTS AND THEIR EFFICIENCY EVALUATION BY ANIMALCHALLENGE STUDIES AS FUTURE WORK.

THERE IS AN INCREASING INTEREST OF USING PLANT POLYPHENOLS AS ANTIOXIDANTS AND ANTIMICROBIAL IN FEED TO COMBAT THE ANTIBIOTIC RESISTANCE ISSUE. GRAPE POMACE (GP) IS A BY-PRODUCT OF GRAPES FROM WINE MAKING AND IS RENEWABLE AND SUFFICIENT IN GRAPE JUICE AND WINE PRODUCING REGIONS. IT IS RICH IN POLYPHENOLS AND HAS POTENTIAL TO SERVE AS AN ANTIBIOTIC ALTERNATIVE FOR LIVESTOCK ANIMALS. HOWEVER, PREVIOUS STUDIES SHOW THAT THE GP IS OFTEN CONTAMINATED WITH TOXIGENIC FUNGI AND HIGH LEVEL OF OTA WHICH COULD CAUSE ANIMAL SICKNESS AND AFFECT ANIMAL PERFORMANCE AND PRODUCTION, PARTICULARLY TO PIGS AND POULTRY. ALTHOUGH STUDIES OF OTA DETOXIFICATION METHODS HAVE BEEN REPORTED, THE RESEARCH ABOUT THE FEASIBILITY OF THOSE METHODS IN REAL FOOD/FEED MATERIALS IS LIMITED. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP AN INNOVATIVE AND AFFORDABLE DETOXIFICATION APPROACH BY COMBINING THERMAL PRESSURE TREATMENT AND PROBIOTIC FERMENTATION TO MAKE GP A SAFER FEED INGREDIENT, AND TO EVALUATE THE DETOXIFICATION EFFICACY AND THE IMPACT OF FEEDING DETOXIFIED GP ON MEAT QUALITY AND THE SAFETY USING A POULTRY MODEL. THE APPROACH FOR DETOXIFICATION WILL ENSURE ALL HARMFUL MICROBES AND SPORES ARE KILLED, AND OTA IN GP IS DEGRADED INTO NON-TOXIC COMPOUNDS NOT JUST ADSORBED. IF THE DETOXIFIED GP IS SAFE FOR POULTRY, IT WILL ALSO BE SAFE FOR OTHER FARM ANIMAL SPECIES BECAUSE POULTRY IS MORE SENSITIVE TO OTA THAN MOST FARM ANIMALS EXCEPT SWINE. THE GP DETOXIFIED BY THE APPROACH OF THIS PROJECT MAY SERVE AS RESERVOIR OF ANTIBIOTIC TO IMPROVE THE IMMUNITY OF LIVESTOCK ANIMALS IF REGULARLY CONSUMED AT RIGHT DOSE. THIS WILL REDUCE FARMERS' RELIANCE ON ANTIBIOTICS AND INCREASE THEIR PROFITABILITY. THE SUCCESSFUL DETOXIFICATION OF OTA IN GP WILL ALSO ENHANCE THE VALUE ADDED USE OF GP WHICH WILL BENEFIT GRAPE WINERIES AND FEED INDUSTRY.

WITH THE RAPID GROWING MARKET FOR PLANT-BASED FOODS AND THE NEEDFOR FOOD ENGINEERS AND FOOD SCIENTIST, FLORIDA A&M UNIVERSITY (FAMU) COMBINES THE FORCES FROM FLORIDA STATE UNIVERSITY, UC DAVIS, AND INDUSTRY COLLABORATORS TO INCREASE THE RESEARCH AND EDUCATION CAPACITIES AT MINORITY-SERVING UNIVERSITIES.THE MAIL GOALS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO VALORIZE WASTE BYPRODUCTS FROM THE FOOD INDUSTRY AND EMPOWER THE RESEARCH AND EDUCATION CAPACITIES AT FAMU.WE WILL DEVELOPED RESEARCH AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS TO INCREASE THE PRODUCTIVITY, SAFETY, TEXTURE, AND NUTRITIONAL VALUES OF PLANT-BASED MEAT ANALOGS AND TRAINING STUDENTS AT FAMU ON VALUE-ADDED PROCESSING TECHNOLOGIES, FOOD ANALYSIS, AND SENSORY EVALUATION.SPECIFIC OBJECTIVE INCLUDE 1) EXTRACT PLANT PROTEIN FROM OILSEED MEAL, A WASTE FOOD BYPRODUCT, AND PROCESS THE PLANT PROTEIN TO MEAT ANALOGS, 2) OPTIMIZE THE PROCESSING CONDITIONS, INCLUDING ZONE TEMPERATURES, SCREW SPEED, AND MOISTURE CONTENT, TO MODULATE THE TEXTURE AND SAFETY OF THE MEATANALOGS, 3) DEVELOP AI-ASSISTED IMAGING SYSTEM TO DETECT THE QUALITY AND TEXTURE OF THE MEAT ANALOGS IN THE PROCESSING LINE, AND 4) TRAINING THE STUDENTS AT MINORIY-SERVING UNIVERSITY BY HAND-ON RESEARCH EXPERIENCES AND INTERNSHIPS PROVIDED BY FOOD COMPANIES.

A SIGNIFICANT NUMBER OF PEOPLE CURRENTLY LACK THE NUTRITIONAL NECESSITIES TO LEAD HEALTHY AND SUSTAINABLE LIVES, AND THIS WILL ONLY WORSEN WITH THE PROJECTED GROWTH IN THE WORLD'S POPULATION AND THE AMOUNT OF FOOD NEEDED TO SUPPLY THEIR EATING NEEDS, PREDICTS THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL ORGANIZATION OF THE UNITED NATIONS. A SMALL PERCENTAGE OF COUNTRIES ACCOUNT FOR A LARGE PERCENTAGE OF GLOBAL FOOD ACCESS. TO FEED ANOTHER TWO BILLION PEOPLE BY 2050 (ESTIMATE), WE WILL HAVE TO DOUBLE THE WORLD'S FOOD PRODUCTION. THIS PROJECTION POSES A PROBLEM BECAUSE WITH INCREASED POPULATION COMES A DECREASE IN FARMABLE LAND. THEREFORE, THE WORLD'S AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRIES NEED TO DOUBLE THE FOOD PRODUCTION ON ALMOST HALF OF THE LAND WE CURRENTLY HAVE. AS A RESULT, THERE IS A CALL FOR AGRICULTURAL STUDENTS TO HELP ENSURE WE HAVE A SAFE AND HEALTHY FOOD SUPPLY.FOOD SCIENCE, PART OF SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING AND MATHEMATICS (STEM) MAJORS, HAS ALWAYS BEEN A DYNAMIC DISCIPLINE EVOLVING TO MEET INDUSTRY AND SOCIETAL NEEDS. FOOD SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY HAVE EMBRACED ALL SCIENCES - PHYSICS, CHEMISTRY, BIOLOGY, MATERIALS SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING, BIOTECHNOLOGY, MICROBIOLOGY, NUTRITION, TOXICOLOGY, AND COMPUTER SCIENCE - TO RESOLVE NUTRITIONAL DEFICIENCIES AND ENHANCE FOOD SAFETY. IN ADDITION, TODAY'S CONSUMERS ARE INCREASINGLY DEMANDING HEALTHY AND NUTRITIONAL FOODS. CONSEQUENTLY, ACCORDING TO THE U.S. BUREAU OF LABOR, FOOD SCIENCE HAS BETTER JOB PROSPECTS THAN ANY OTHER INDUSTRY. WORLDWIDE, ENHANCED JOB PROSPECTS IN AGRICULTURE INCLUDE PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT, QUALITY CONTROL, NUTRITION, AND FOOD SAFETY. THE U.S. BUREAU OF LABOR STATISTICS (2020) PROJECTED GROWTH OF 7% IN AGRICULTURAL EMPLOYMENT AND FOOD SCIENCE FROM 2018 TO 2028, WHICH IS GREATER THAN THE AVERAGE FOR ALL OTHER OCCUPATIONS (5%).CURRENTLY, THE STEM WORKFORCE IS DOMINATED BY WHITE MALES (48%); HOWEVER, THIS MAJORITY IS DECREASING DUE TO U.S. DEMOGRAPHIC CHANGES. AS A RESULT, MANY FOOD COMPANIES ARE LOOKING TO DIVERSIFY THEIR LABOR FORCE AND BRING NEW AND CREATIVE PERSPECTIVES AND IDEAS TO THE TABLE. CONSEQUENTLY, THERE IS A NEED TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF WELL-PREPARED MINORITY GRADUATES IN THESE FIELDS. HOWEVER, ONE OF THE CHALLENGES TO IMPROVING THE REPRESENTATION OF MINORITIES IN THE STEM WORKFORCE IS TO ENHANCE THEIR RETENTION IN STEM PROGRAMS. SEVERAL FACTORS MAY CONTRIBUTE TO THIS LOW RETENTION. BLACK COLLEGE STUDENTS LEAVE STEM FIELDS AT HIGHER RATES THAN THEIR WHITE PEERS. ACCORDING TO A 2019 EDUCATIONAL RESEARCHER STUDY OF UNDERGRADUATES, 40% OF BLACK STUDENTS SWITCH OUT OF STEM MAJORS, COMPARED WITH 29% OF WHITE STUDENTS. IN ADDITION, LIMITED AWARENESS OF CAREER OPPORTUNITIES AND A LACK OF SKILLS NEEDED TO COMPETE FOR POSITIONS IN THE MARKETPLACE HAVE NEGATIVELY IMPACTED THE MINORITY WORKFORCE NUMBERS.AS SUCH, THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EXPAND ACCESS TO THE FOOD AND NUTRITIONAL SCIENCES PROGRAM (FNS) AT NORTH CAROLINA A&T STATE UNIVERSITY (NC A&T) TO MINORITY MALE STU,DENTS USING A VARIETY OF INNOVATIVE RECRUITMENT AND MARKETING METHODS TO PREPARE HIGH-ACHIEVING STUDENTS FOR JOBS IN THE FOOD INDUSTRY.

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF OUR PROPOSED HBCU AGRICULTURE BUSINESS INNOVATION CENTER (ABIC) IS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF SUCCESSFUL AGRICULTURAL BUSINESSES BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE THROUGH COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS ACROSS HBCUS. THIS PROJECT IS AN INTEGRATED PROPOSAL WITH THE PRIMARY FOCUS ON OUTREACH (EWE) FUNCTIONS TO SERVE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED POPULATIONS. THE PROPOSED ABIC WILL ALSO SERVE AS A CONVENER TO SUPPORT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL PARTNERSHIP IN PROVIDING ACCESS TO PRIVATE VENTURE CAPITAL, DATA TRACKING AND ANALYSIS, EVALUATION, AND MEASUREMENT FOR EFFECTIVE PROGRAMMING IN OUTREACH.
