DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY (DSU) AND THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND EASTERN SHORE (UMES) ARE TWO 1890 LAND-GRANT MINORITY-SERVING INSTITUTIONS THAT STRIVE TO PROVIDE ACCESS AND OPPORTUNITIES TO A DIVERSE POPULATION OF MINORITIES IN THE EXCELLENCE OF TEACHING, RESEARCH, AND OUTREACH. THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND EASTERN SHORE PROVIDES INDIVIDUALS, INCLUDING FIRST-GENERATION COLLEGE STUDENTS, ACCESS TO A HOLISTIC LEARNING ENVIRONMENT THAT FOSTERS MULTICULTURAL DIVERSITY, ACADEMIC SUCCESS, AND INTELLECTUAL AND SOCIAL GROWTH. IT PREPARES GRADUATES TO ADDRESS CHALLENGES IN A GLOBAL KNOWLEDGE-BASED ECONOMY WHILE MAINTAINING ITS COMMITMENT TO MEETING THE WORKFORCE AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT NEEDS OF THE EASTERN SHORE, THE STATE, THE NATION, AND THE WORLD. A LONG-TERM STRATEGIC PLAN AT DSU IS TO ENGAGE STUDENTS IN RESEARCH AND TEACHING TO INCREASE THE STOREHOUSE OF KNOWLEDGE IN VARIOUS DISCIPLINES AND FIELDS AND, AS APPROPRIATE, TO APPLY THAT KNOWLEDGE TO THE SOLUTION OF COMMUNITY, REGIONAL, NATIONAL,AND INTERNATIONAL PROBLEMS. THE IDEA OF PROVIDING UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AT DSU AND UMES WITH EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES WILL HELP TO MEET THE GOALS OF BOTH 1890 LAND GRANT HBCUS. ADDITIONALLY, PROVIDING STUDENTS WITH EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING EARLY IN THEIR CAREERS THROUGH INVOLVEMENT IN RESEARCH, SERVICE LEARNING, LEADERSHIP PROGRAMS, AND OTHER HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES WILL HELP TO DEVELOP LEADERS WHOSE ATTAINED KNOWLEDGE IN THEIR AREA WILL BE USED TO SERVE THE GLOBAL SOCIETY. THE MAJOR GOAL OF THIS JOINT TEACHING PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH THE NECESSARY TOOLS REQUIRED TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN THE AREAS OF AGRICULTURE, FOOD SECURITY, NUTRITION, AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH. WE WILL ACHIEVE THIS BY ENHANCING THEIR FIELD EXPERIENCE, INTERACTION, AND RESEARCH EXPERIENCES TOGETHER AS A TEAM WITH SIGNIFICANT NUMBERS OF UNDERREPRESENTED MINORITY STUDENTS. THE FIRST OBJECTIVE OF THIS MULTI-INSTITUTIONAL JOINT PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE MINORITY UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN FANH DISCIPLINES WITH EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES TO MAKE THEM BETTER PREPARED AS A FUTURE WORKFORCE. THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH INTERNSHIPS, WORKSHOPS, INSTRUCTIONAL MATERIAL DEVELOPMENT, AND RESEARCH TRAINING TO SOLVE REAL-WORLD ISSUES FOCUSING ON SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE, FOOD SECURITY, NUTRITION, AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH. THE SECOND OBJECTIVE INCLUDES SOFT SKILLS WITH A FOCUSON LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT OF STUDENTS THROUGH COLLABORATIONS, LEADERSHIP WORKSHOPS, PRESENTATIONS, LAYERED MENTORING, AND INTERACTIONS WITH CLIENTELE ON SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE, FOOD SECURITY, NUTRITION, AND NATURAL RESOURCES.THIS PROPOSAL STRIVES FOR DEVELOPING A STRONG INTER-AND MULTI-DISCIPLINARY PARTNERSHIP THAT BUILDS ON EXISTING TEACHING AND RESEARCH PROGRAMS. THROUGH THIS GRANT, THE ONGOING COLLABORATION WILL BE DEVELOPED WITH FEW NEW MEMBERS AND WILL BE ENHANCED WITH OTHER MEMBERS VIA PROGRAM ACTIVITIES IN THE PROJECT. THESE PARTNERSHIPS WILL SIGNIFICANTLY ENHANCE THE PROPOSED STUDENT EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, AND LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM EFFORTS. BY PROVIDING FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES TO THIS DIVERSE TEAM OF FACULTY/STAFF TO RECRUIT STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED MINORITIES TO ENHANCE THEIR KNOWLEDGE IN FANH DISCIPLINES, EXISTING PARTNERSHIP AND COLLABORATION WILL BE SIGNIFICANTLY ENHANCED, AND NEW COLLABORATION BUILT. UNDER THE THREE MAIN PROGRAM AREAS: SMALL FARM PROGRAM EFFORTS WILL BUILD ON THE EXISTING COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH PROJECT AND COOPERATIVE EXTENSION FACULTY/STAFF NETWORKING. INVOLVING UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN THE EXTENSION PROGRAM ACTIVITIES IS EXPECTED TO SPARK INTEREST BY THE PARTICIPATING STUDENTS FOR THE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION CAREER AND INCREASE OUR RETENTION FOR THE POTENTIAL WORKFORCE. COLLABORATIONS ARE A CENTRAL ASPECT OF CAST RESEARCH TEACHING-EXTENSION PROGRAMS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS A TEACHING PROGRAM WITH ROBUST AND WELL-PLANNED STUDENT EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS THAT ARE EXPECTED TO ENGAGE OUR STUDENTS ON EMERGING ISSUES WE ARE FACING TODAY (I.E. COVID19, CLIMATE CHANGE, FLOODING, DROUGHT, INSECT INVASION, ANIMAL HEALTH). THROUGH EXTENSION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES AND OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE TO OUR STUDENTS IN THIS PROGRAM, OUR UNDERGRADUATES WILL COMMUNICATE AND ADVOCATE THEIR SCIENCES TO THE PUBLIC. IN ADDITION, INTERACTION WITH OUR NEIGHBORING STATE, MD AND THE USDA-ARS PROGRAM ON THE DSU CAMPUS WILL PROVIDE CONTACTS AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR COLLABORATION THAT CAN EXTENDBEYOND THE PROGRAM AND THE OPPORTUNITY FOR THE DISSEMINATION OF APPLIED RESEARCH RESULTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION MODEL THAT WILL INCORPORATED INTO THE AGRIBUSINESS CURRICULUM AND TO FOSTER GEOSPATIAL INFORMATION SCIENCE EDUCATION AMONG STUDENTS FROM UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. SPECIFICALLY, THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE AS FOLLOWS: (1) TO INCREASE THE LEVEL OF AWARENESS IN GIS KNOWLEDGE OF YOUTH IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES BY OFFERING HANDS-ON WORKSHOP ACTIVITIES AT LINCOLN UNIVERSITY SATELLITE OFFICE IN KANSAS CITY AND LINCOLN EXTENSION INNOVATIVE CENTER IN JEFFERSON CITY, MISSOURI; (2) TO EDUCATE THE NEXT GENERATION WORKFORCE, PARTICULARLY MINORITIES, WHO ARE ADEQUATELY EQUIPPED IN GIS KNOWLEDGE AND SKILL BY OFFERING GIS MINOR COURSES;(3)TO DEVELOP A NEW MODULE THAT INCORPORATES GIS IN THE AGRIBUSINESS CURRICULUM.

THE PROPOSAL HELPS KENTUCKY STATE UNIVERSITY ADDRESS THE NEED FOR TRAINING OF SMALL-SCALE, MINORITY, AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS TO DEVELOP STRATEGIES FOR THE HANDLING OF PRODUCE AND MAKING OF VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS TO BE IN COMPLIANCE WITH FOOD SAFETY MODERNIZATION ACT (FSMA) REGULATIONS, AS WELL AS PROCESSING AND MARKETING REQUIREMENTS/STANDARDS FOR COVID-19, EVEN AFTER VACCINES ARE DEVELOPED. THEREFORE, THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROPOSAL ARE TO: 1) PROVIDE IN-PERSON WORKSHOPS AND ONLINE TRAINING PROGRAMMING FOR HANDLING OF PRODUCE AND PACKAGING, AS WELL AS VALUE-ADDED PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT AS RESULT OF COVID-19, GOOD AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES (GAPS), AND FSMA POLICIES; 2) ASSIST PRODUCERS IN RECIPE AND LABEL APPROVAL AND FARMERS MARKET TASTING TRIALS WITH COVID-19 LIMITATIONS; 3) OFFER WORKSHOPS AND TRAININGS ON NEW POTENTIAL VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS SUCH AS CONFECTIONS, DRIED FRUIT, GRANOLA, HOT SAUCE, AND MORE; 4) PROVIDE ADDITIONAL EQUIPMENT ENHANCEMENTS FOR THE KSU FRUITAND VEGETABLE MOBILE PROCESSING UNIT; AND 5) CREATE UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH AND PRACTICUM OPPORTUNITIES IN THE RESEARCH AREAS IN OBJECTIVE 3, WHICH WILL DEVELOP LEADERSHIP AND CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS IN STUDENTS. EXTENSION CAPACITY WILL BE ENHNCED THROUGH CREATION OF A NEW SAFETY CURICULUM AND ADDITIONAL EQUIPMENT PURCHASED. THE NEW EQUIPMENT WILL SUPPORT ADDITIONAL RESEARCH AND CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT IN FOOD SCIENCE AND SAFETY IN THE SCIENCES AREA AND ASSIST IN THE CONTINUATION OF THE PROJECT.

RIVERS REPRESENT A CONFLUENCE OF NATURAL AND HUMAN-ALTERED ENVIRONMENTS AND PROCESSES. RIVER WATER QUALITY FLOWS FROM LINKAGES AMONG MUNICIPAL, AGRICULTURAL AND INDUSTRIAL INPUTS, REGIONAL GEOLOGY, RIVER MANAGEMENT, AND CONTINENTAL CLIMATE PATTERNS. THE INTERSECTION OF THESE FORCES IS MEDIATED BY THE METABOLISM OF RIVER MICROORGANISMS (MICROBIOMES) THAT RESIDE IN THE WATER AND SEDIMENT. WHILE THE INCREDIBLE METABOLIC DIVERSITY OF RIVER MICROBIOMES IS LARGELY RESPONSIBLE FOR MAINTAINING WATER QUALITY, IT CAN ALSO MAGNIFY PROBLEMS ASSOCIATED WITH NUTRIENT POLLUTION AND GREENHOUSE GAS (GHG) EMISSIONS. THE KANAWHA-NEW RIVER BASIN ENCOMPASSES MORE THAN 12,000 SQUARE MILES OF APPALACHIAN MOUNTAINS AND FOOTHILLS. THE LOWER KANAWHA RIVER, IN THE CHARLESTON METROPOLITAN AREA, EXPERIENCES DRAMATIC CHANGES IN DISCHARGE RATE, WATER CHEMISTRY, AND WATER QUALITY FOLLOWING LARGE STORM EVENTS. UNFORTUNATELY, CLIMATE CHANGE PROJECTIONS FOR THE UNITED STATES ANTICIPATE THAT THE FREQUENCY AND INTENSITY OF STORMS WILL INCREASE. THEREFORE, STORM EVENTS MAY SIMULTANEOUSLY EXACERBATE WATER QUALITY PROBLEMS AND GHG EMISSIONS DUE TO PROCESS LINKAGES WITHIN THE SHARED RIVER MICROBIOME. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO EXAMINE THE EFFECTS OF STORM EVENTS ON WATER QUALITY, GHGS AND MICROBIOME PROCESSES IN THE KANAWHA RIVER WATERSHED. THIS RESEARCH IS MULTI-DISCIPLINARY AND WILL USE A SUITE OF TOOLS INCLUDING HYDROLOGY, HYDROCHEMISTRY, QUANTITATIVE MODELING, MICROBIAL ECOLOGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL GENOMICS THAT WILL BUILD THE RESEARCH CAPACITY OF WVSU IN THE AREAS OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND FRESHWATER SCIENCES AND BIOTECHNOLOGY.

ELEVATED DISSOLVED ORGANIC CARBON (DOC) IN DRINKING SOURCE WATER AND POTENTIAL FORMATION OF TOXIC DISINFECTION BY-PRODUCTS (DBPS) IN DRINKING WATER HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A THREAT TO HUMAN HEALTH. NUMEROUS SMALL DRINKING WATER TREATMENT SYSTEMS IN US RURAL COMMUNITIES ARE CURRENTLY FACING CHALLENGES IN COMPLIANCE WITH THE STRINGENT EPA STAGE II DBP REGULATIONS TO PROVIDE SAFE DRINKING WATER, DUE TO LIMITED RESOURCES AND TECHNOLOGIES. IN ADDITION, DRINKING WATERBORNE DISEASES CAUSED BY MICROBIAL CONTAMINANTS ARE ALSO OF PUBLIC HEALTH CONCERN DUE TO INSUFFICIENT DISINFECTION IN SMALL WATER SYSTEMS. THE CURRENT DISINFECTANTS USED BY MOST SMALL WATER SYSTEMS COULD ACTIVELY REACT WITH DOC IN SOURCE WATER AND LEAD TO THE FORMATION OF NUMEROUS DBPS IN DRINKING WATER. IT HAS BEEN CONFIRMED THAT MANY DBPS ARE CARCINOGEN OR POTENTIAL CARCINOGEN, THREATENING A PUBLIC HEALTH, ESPECIALLY THE RESIDENTS IN RURAL COMMUNITY. THEREFORE, IT IS URGENTLY NEEDED TO DEVELOP A NOVEL, COST-EFFECTIVE TREATMENT TECHNOLOGY FOR DBP CONTROL AND IMPROVED DRINKING WATER SAFETY.THIS PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AN INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGY BASED ON FENTON-LIKE ADVANCED OXIDATION PROCESS TO SIMULTANEOUSLY DISINFECT WATERBORNE PATHOGENS AND MITIGATE THE FORMATION OF CARCINOGENIC DBPS IN DRINKING WATER. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL BE FOCUSING ON: I) ASSESSING THE YIELDS OF STRONG DISINFECTANTS (HYDROXYL AND SUPEROXIDE RADICALS) BY MAGNETIC FE3O4- AND FE3O4-COATED GRANULAR ACTIVE CARBON, AND II) EVALUATING THE TREATMENT EFFECTIVENESS FOR PATHOGEN AND DBP CONTROL. IF SUCCESSFUL, THIS PROJECT WOULD SUBSTANTIALLY REDUCE WATERBORNE PATHOGEN AND DBP-RELATED DISEASES AND ENHANCE OUR UNDERSTANDINGS OF CHEMICAL MECHANISMS ON DBP FORMATION. RESULTS COULD LEAD TO A COST-EFFECTIVE, ENVIRONMENTAL-SAFE TREATMENT TECHNOLOGY FOR IMPROVING DRINKING WATER SAFETY AND SAFEGUARDING RURAL RESIDENTS FROM UNSAFE DRINKING WATER. THE STUDY COULD ALSO STRENGTHEN THE EDUCATION AND RESEARCH CAPACITY OF WATER SCIENCE AT LINCOLN UNIVERSITY, A 1890 HBCU, THROUGH MULTI-INSTITUTION COLLABORATION AND POTENTIALLY CONTRIBUTE TO A DIVERSITY OF AGRICULTURAL WORKFORCE AND PROFESSIONALS.

SPATIAL MAPPING AND QUANTIFYING ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS ON DISTURBANCES DAMAGING NATURAL RESOURCES NEED MULTIDISCIPLINARY PLANS WITH COLLABORATION AND ENGAGEMENT OF SCIENTISTS WORKING IN NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, GIS, REMOTE SENSING, BIOLOGY, AND CLIMATE CHANGE FIELDS. WE PROPOSE A COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH PROJECT TO MODEL THE OAK MORTALITY CHALLENGE IN THE OZARK HIGHLANDS. THIS IS A SPATIALLY EXPLICIT FRAMEWORK WHICH WILL INCORPORATE THE EFFECTS OF ENVIRONMENTAL (CLIMATIC, BIOPHYSICAL, AND EDAPHIC) VARIABLES ON OAK MORTALITY OCCURRENCE AND SPREAD. THE PROJECT LINKS TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES ON BIODIVERSITY AND WILL PROVIDE THE SPATIAL FRAMEWORK FOR THE STUDY OF THE POTENTIAL UNDERLYING CAUSES OF DAMAGE TO OAK WOODLANDS AND CONSEQUENTLY EXAMINE ALTERNATIVE CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT APPROACHES.OAK DECLINE, AS IS IT IS COMMONLY REFERRED TO, REPRESENTS A LARGE THREAT TO THE STABILITY AND ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONING OF MOST OF THE HARDWOOD FORESTS OF THE NORTHERN HEMISPHERE BECAUSE OAK SPECIES ARE USUALLY DOMINANT AND RANK HIGHLY WITH THE ECOLOGICAL ROLES THEY PLAY IN THESE SYSTEMS. THE OZARK HIGHLANDS OF MISSOURI AND ARKANSAS REPRESENT A VITAL CASE STUDY FOR OAK DECLINE IN THE LAST TWO DECADES. ABOUT 35% OF MISSOURI'S TOTAL LAND AREA IS COVERED WITH FORESTS (6.2 MILLION HA). THESE FORESTS PROVIDE CRITICAL ECONOMIC AND LIFE SUPPORT SYSTEMS AND HARBOR A RICH DIVERSITY OF WILDLIFE SPECIES. RESEARCH ON THE POTENTIAL UNDERLYING CAUSES OF OAK DECLINE IS CRITICAL TO THE INSTITUTIONAL GOALS AND STRATEGIC PLANS OF BOTH LINCOLN UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI (LU) AND THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI (MU). IT IS IN INSTITUTIONAL GOALS OF LU TO DEVELOP AND EXPAND THE RESEARCH IN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AREAS AND TO FURTHER DEVELOP AND SUPPORT ITSCENTER OF EXCELLENCE IN GEOSPATIAL INFORMATION SCIENCE LABORATORY. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES THE OPPORTUNITY OF ACHIEVING BOTH GOALS. THE USDA FOREST SERVICE'S POLICY IS TO INCREASE THE REPRESENTATION AND EMPLOYMENT OF MINORITY STUDENTS IN FORESTRY RESEARCH AND IT IS A POLICY OF LU TO RECRUIT AND EDUCATE MORE MINORITY GRADUATE STUDENTS IN GEOSPATIAL AND FORESTRY RESEARCH. THUS, THIS PROJECT IS ALIGNED WITH BOTH POLICIES.THIS PROPOSED PROJECT IS AN INTEGRATED COLLABORATIVE WORK BETWEEN LU AND MU PRIMARILY FOCUSED ON UNDERSTANDING THIS RECENT DISTURBING PHENOMENON OF OAK DECLINE. THE KNOWLEDGE ACQUIRED IS ANTICIPATED TO LEAD TO FOREST MANAGEMENT ACTIONS, IN A PROACTIVE MANNER, TO WARD OFF OAK DECLINE IN SUSCEPTIBLE OAK FORESTS. THIS FUNDAMENTAL, APPLIED, AND MULTIDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH WILL BE INTEGRATED WITH TEACHING/EDUCATION. IN THIS REGARD, GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS WILL BE RECRUITED AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES WILL BE AFFORDED AND MENTORED. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THE OPPORTUNITY FOR SCIENTISTS AT BOTH INSTITUTIONS TO COMBINE THEIR RESOURCES AND ENHANCE THEIR CAPACITY IN SPATIAL MODELING TO STUDY THE LANDSCAPE AND LOCAL SCALE CHANGES IN OAK DECLINE. IT WILL INVESTIGATETHE POTENTIAL ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS, FOR THE FIRST TIME, IN THIS GLOBAL HOTSPOT OF OAK MORTALITY IN THE OZARK MOUNTAINS. COLLABORATION WITH MU AND OTHER DATA AND RESEARCH AGENCIES WILL SPECIFICALLY HELP BUILDING CAPACITIES AT LU FOR SPATIALLY EXPLICIT LANDSCAPE SCALE MODELING FOR FOREST MANAGEMENT APPLICATIONS.

HEALTHY SOIL IS THE BASE OF SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE. THE HEALTH OF A SOIL, HOWEVER, IS DETERMINED BY ITS PHYSICAL, CHEMICAL, AND BIOLOGICAL PROPERTIES AND IS INFLUENCED BY HUMAN LAND USES AND MANAGEMENT. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ESTABLISH A SOIL HEALTH TRAINING ACADEMY AT DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY (DSU) AS A MODEL TO THE 1890 LAND-GRANT INSTITUTIONS TO PREPARE MINORITY AGRICULTURAL PROFESSIONALS WITH THE EXPERTISE OF SOIL HEALTH MANAGEMENT THROUGH INTEGRATED TEACHING AND EXTENSION TRAINING EFFORTS. THE PROJECT TEAM AT DSU WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO CREATE THE SOIL HEALTH TRAINING ACADEMY, CONSTRUCT A DESIGNATED WEBSITE, DEVELOP SOIL HEALTH TRAINING MATERIALS, INTEGRATE SOIL HEALTH EDUCATION IN FOUR COURSE CURRICULA, AND TRAIN STUDENTS AND AGRICULTURAL WORKERS WITH THE EXPERTISE OF SOIL HEALTH MANAGEMENT THROUGH INTENSIVE WORKSHOPS, EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING PROJECTS, AND OTHER EXTENSION ACTIVITIES. SUCCESSFUL EXECUTION OF THEPROJECT WILL GREATLY ENHANCETHE PROFESSIONALISM OF AGRICULTURAL STUDENTS, IMPROVE THE SOIL HEALTH MANAGEMENT SKILLS OF DELMARVA AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS,AND PROMOTE SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE.

DECADES OF OVER-USE AND MIS-USE OF ANTHELMINTIC TREATMENTS FOR GASTROINTESTINAL NEMATODE (GIN) CONTROL HAS LED TO THE EMERGENCE OF MULTI-DRUG RESISTANT PARASITES. THIS POSES A SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGE TO PARASITE CONTROL ON SMALL RUMINANT FARMS. ONE NOVEL APPROACH TO REGAIN THE ABILITY TO SUCCESSFULLY TREAT PARASITE INFECTIONS IS THE REPLACEMENT OF ANTHELMINTIC RESISTANT PARASITES WITH A POPULATION OF DRUG-SUSCEPTIBLE PARASITES. HOWEVER, STUDIES HAVE SHOWN THAT ALTHOUGH REPLACEMENT IS HIGHLY SUCCESSFUL INITIALLY, THE SMALL SUB-POPULATION OF SURVIVING RESISTANT WORMS WAS ABLE TO COME BACK FASTER THAN EXPECTED. THE RECENT RELEASE OF A NEW PRODUCT, BIOWORMA® (CONTAINING THE NEMATOPHAGOUS FUNGUS DUDDINGTONIA FLAGRANS), MIGHT OFFER AN OPPORTUNITY TO PREVENT THE CONTAMINATION OF PASTURES WITH SURVIVING DRUG-RESISTANT PARASITES AND MAKE THIS APPROACH MORE SUCCESSFUL. THEREFORE, THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROPOSED EXTENSION PROJECT ARE: 1) TO DEMONSTRATE THE TARGETED USE OF D. FLAGRANS ON UNIVERSITY FARMS TO FACILITATE THE REPLACEMENT OF DRUG-RESISTANT POPULATIONS OF GIN WITH DRUG-SUSCEPTIBLE GIN; 2) TO VALIDATE THE EFFICACY OF D. FLAGRANS IN REPLACING DRUG-RESISTANT POPULATIONS OF GIN WITH DRUG-SUSCEPTIBLE GIN ON SMALL RUMINANT PRODUCER FARMS; AND 3) DEVELOP EXTENSION PROGRAMMING AND A TRAINING CURRICULUM ON BIOWORMA® AND ITS ON-FARM APPLICATION. RESULTS WILL BE USED TO DEMONSTRATE TO PRODUCERS, EXTENSION AGENTS AND VETERINARIANS, HOW BIOWORMA® CAN BE USED TO CONTROL AND POSSIBLY REVERSE DRUG-RESISTANT PARASITE POPULATIONS ON FARMS. THIS PROPOSAL IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT AMONG FIVE UNIVERSITIES. IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT WOULD SIGNIFICANTLY ENHANCE THE EXTENSION CAPACITY OF THE 1890'S INSTITUTIONS INVOLVED AS WELL AS AIDING CRITICAL EFFORTS IN GIN CONTROL.

SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED INDIVIDUALS OFTEN LIVE IN FOOD DESERTS--COMMUNITIES WHERE ACCESS TO AFFORDABLE, HEALTHY FOODS IS LIMITED, WHICH CREATES GREATER RISK FOR OBESITY, HEART DISEASE AND DIABETES. FARMER'S MARKETS ARE ALSO A BARRIER FOR THESE COMMUNITIES AS MARKETS ARE DISPROPORTIONALLY FOUND IN MORE AFFLUENT COMMUNITIES.CREATING FARMS IN SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES IS ONE SOLUTION FOR INCREASING ACCESS TO HEALTHY FOODS. HOWEVER NEW FARMERS, ESPECIALLY THOSE WHO ARE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED, FACE BARRIERS IN GAINING ACCESS TO TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, MENTORSHIP, LAND, CAPITAL, MARKETS AND EQUIPMENT.THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO BUILD AN INFRASTRUCTURE OF NEW FARMERS IN THE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES BY CREATING SMALL, INCUBATOR FARMS. FARMERS WILL BE TRAINED BY CSUE AND LOCAL FARM MENTORS IN CROP PRODUCTION AND FARM BUSINESS PLANNING. TO BUILD A HEALTHIER COMMUNITY AND INCREASE ACCESS TO FRUITS AND VEGETABLES, FARMER'S MARKETS WILL BE HELD AT THE INCUBATOR FARM WITH THE NEW FARMERS AS VENDORS. CSUE WILL PROVIDE COOKING DEMONSTRATIONS USING PRODUCE AVAILABLE FOR SALE AND RESIDENTS WILL BE ENCOURAGED TO ATTEND NUTRITIONAL CLASSES TO INCREASE SELF-EFFICACY FOR CHOOSING, STORING, PREPARING, AND PRESERVING FRESH PRODUCE.CSU IS A NEW 1890 LAND GRANT INSTITUTION AND MANY STUDENTS HAVE NOT BEEN EXPOSED TO EXTENSION AS A CAREER. THE PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR MINORITY UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO OBSERVE AND JOB SHADOW EXTENSION PERSONNEL DURING TEACHING ACTIVITIES AT THE INCUBATOR FARM. STUDENTS WILL ALSO BE ENCOURAGED TO PARTICIPATE IN TEACHING AT THE FARM TO ENCOURAGE THEM TO CONSIDER EXTENSION AS A CAREER OPTION.

CAPACITY BUILDING AT THREE 1890 LAND-GRANT HBCUS (UNIVERSITY ARKANSAS PINE BLUFF, VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY, AND KENTUCKY STATE UNIVERSITY) WILL BE ENABLED BY ADDRESSING MULTIPLE CAPACITY BUILDING PRIORITIES (FOOD SAFETY; GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY; AGRICULTURAL BIO-SECURITY; AND SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE). USDA'S STRATEGIC GOALS (MAXIMIZE AMERICAN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCER'S ABILITY TO PROSPER BY FEEDING THE WORLD AND PROTECT AGRICULTURAL HEALTH BY PREVENTING THE SPREAD OF AGRICULTURAL PESTS AND DISEASE) AS WELL AS NIFA'S SCIENCE GOALS TO CATALYZE EXEMPLARY AND RELEVANT RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS AND ADVANCE OUR NATION'S ABILITY TO ACHIEVE GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY AND FIGHT HUNGER WILL ALSO BE ADDRESSED. THE SCIENTIFIC GOAL IS TO DEVELOP ALTERNATIVE ANTIMICROBIALS TO TREAT AND PREVENT STREPTOCOCCUS INIAE, AN EMERGING PATHOGEN OF SEVERAL AQUACULTURE SPECIES THAT CONTRIBUTES TO GLOBAL ANNUAL STREPTOCOCCOSIS LOSSES IN BILLIONS OF DOLLARS. THESE PATHOGENS CAN RESIDE FREE-LIVING AS WELL AS WITHIN FISH CELLS (INTRACELLULAR), ALLOWING THEM TO EVADE BOTH THE HOST IMMUNE SYSTEM AND ANTIBIOTIC TREATMENT. ALTERNATIVE ANTIMICROBIALS THAT AVOID RESISTANCE DEVELOPMENT IN TARGETED AND NON-TARGETED SPECIES AND THAT CAN KILL INTRACELLULAR PATHOGENS ARE SORELY NEEDED. ALTHOUGH ANTIBIOTICS ARE EFFECTIVE AGAINST S. INIAE, ANTIBIOTIC-USE IN ANIMAL PRODUCTION IS SCRUTINIZED DUE TO SELECTION FOR MULTIDRUG-RESISTANT STRAINS AND FARM-TO-CLINIC ANTIBIOTIC-RESISTANCE GENE TRANSFER. THERE ARE ONLY THREE APPROVED ANTIBIOTICS TO TREAT FOOD FISH, AND THERE ARE ALREADY REPORTS OF ANTIBIOTIC-RESISTANT STREPTOCOCCI IN FARMED FISH. PHAGE ENDOLYSINS [CELL WALL DEGRADING ENZYMES THAT DIGEST THE PRIMARY STRUCTURAL COMPONENT OF THE BACTERIAL CELL WALL: PEPTIDOGLYCAN] ACT EXTRACELLULARLY ON THE PATHOGEN, AVOIDING MANY KNOWN RESISTANCE MECHANISMS THAT OCCUR WITHIN THE PATHOGEN (E.G., EFFLUX PUMPS) SO ARE HIGHLY REFRACTORY TO RESISTANCE DEVELOPMENT. THESE ENZYMES CAN BE FUSED TO PROTEIN TRANSDUCTION DOMAINS (SHORT POSITIVELY CHARGED SEGMENTS OF A PEPTIDE WITH ~30 RESIDUES THAT FACILITATE THE TRANSPORT OF THE ENDOLYSIN ACROSS THE CELL WALL), CREATING NOVEL ANTIMICROBIALS THAT CAN PREVENT AND/OR ERADICATE BOTH FREE-LIVING (PLANKTONIC) FORMS OF THE PATHOGEN AND INTRACELLULAR S. INIAE (THAT RESIDE WITHIN FISH CELLS). THE NEAR-SPECIES-SPECIFICITY OF THESE ENDOLYSINS AVOIDS SELECTION FOR ENZYME-RESISTANCE AMONG BENEFICIAL BACTERIAL STRAINS (COMMENSALS) AND IS THUS HIGHLY REFRACTORY TO RESISTANT STRAIN DEVELOPMENT. THIS PROPOSAL WILL WORK WITH ENDOLYSIN ENZYMES KNOWN TO KILL S. INIAE AND WILL FUSE THEM TO 11 DIFFERENT PROTEIN TRANSDUCTION DOMAINS. EACH FUSION CONSTRUCT WILL BE TESTED IN CELL CULTURE FOR THE ABILITY TO KILL INTRACELLULAR S. INIAE. ONCE THE OPTIMAL HIGH-ACTIVITY ENZYME-FUSION CONSTRUCTS ARE IDENTIFIED IN CELL CULTURE, THEY WILL BE TESTED IN BOTH FARM-RAISED TILAPIA AND HYBRID STRIPED BASS.

THE TEXTILE AND APPAREL INDUSTRY REQUIRES THAT EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS SUPPLY THEM WITH GRADUATES THAT HAVE UP-TO-DATE TECHNOLOGICAL SKILLS TO HELP THEM MEET THE NEEDS OF THE 21ST CENTURY CONSUMERS. GIVEN THIS, PROGRAMS ARE EXPECTED TO INVEST IN FACILITIES THAT CAN HELP STUDENTS TO GRADUATE WITH SUCH SKILLS. THEREFORE, THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD THE CAPACITY OF THE MERCHANDISING, TEXTILES AND DESIGN PROGRAM BY ENHANCING AND STRENGTHENING THE CURRICULUM AND TEACHING LABORATORIES. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO (1). DEVELOP HUMAN CAPITAL AT THE TEXTILES AND APPAREL WORKPLACE BY PRODUCING GRADUATES WITH RELEVANT TECHNICAL AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS (2). ENHANCE AND STRENGTHEN THE QUALITY OF TEACHING AND EDUCATION THROUGH ACTIVITIES SUCH AS LAB INSTRUCTION, CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT, FACULTY DEVELOPMENT AND INSTRUCTIONAL MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT, AND (3). STRENGTHEN RESEARCH AND TEACHING AT THE UNIVERSITY. TO MEET THESE OBJECTIVES, THIS PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH A STATE- OF -THE- ART COMPUTER AIDED DESIGN LABORATORY. THE LAB WILL BE USED TO ENHANCE THE CURRENT COURSES AND EXPAND THE COURSE OFFERING BY CREATING NEW COURSES. THE CREATION OF A STATE-OF -THE -ART TECHNOLOGY LABORATORY WILL ENHANCE THE TEACHING AND LEARNING ENVIRONMENT. EXPERIENTIAL TEACHING AND LEARNING THROUGH USE OF INDUSTRY LIKE EQUIPMENT WILL ENABLE FACULTY TO PREPARE STUDENTS FOR FUTURE TEXTILES AND APPAREL INDUSTRY CAREERS. GRADUATES FROM THIS PROGRAM WILL ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE, TECHNICAL AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS NECESSARY FOR THEIR CAREERS. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL LEAD TO MODERNIZATION AND UPGRADING OF THE UNIVERSITY'S INFRASTRUCTURE AND FACILITIES. IT WILL HELP MEET THE UNIVERSITY'S STRATEGIC PRIORITY AND MAY RESULT INTO AN ATTRACTIVE FASHIONS PROGRAM THAT MAY LEAD TO INCREASED ENROLLMENT IN THE PROGRAM AND INCREASED RESEARCH FOR FACULTY ACROSS CAMPUS.

RESEARCH HAS SHOWN THAT THE WORKFORCE IS DEFICIENT IN THE US AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY BECAUSE OF NUMEROUS REASONS, INCLUDING NEGATIVE PERCEPTIONS ABOUT AGRICULTURAL JOBS. CONSEQUENTLY, MILLIONS OF POSITIONS ARE BEING UNFILLED, ADVERSELY IMPACTING DOMESTIC PRODUCTION CAPACITIES AND THE ABILITY TO COMPETE IN INTERNATIONAL MARKETS. THIS SITUATION IS ALARMING AS THE DEMAND FOR FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE AND THE VULNERABILITY OF NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL SUPPLY CHAIN SYSTEMS HAVE BEEN EXPOSED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. HOWEVER, EXISTING INITIATIVES TO ENHANCE THE US AGRICULTURAL WORKFORCE HAVE TARGETED MOSTLY STUDENTS MAJORING IN AGRICULTURAL FIELDS, EXCLUDING CURRENT AND FUTURE PARENTS AND/OR RELATIVES WHO COULD PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN INFLUENCING PERCEPTIONS OF CURRENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS ABOUT THE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY. THIS PROJECT INTENDS TO FIRSTLY, ADDRESS THE DEFICIENCY OF THE US AGRICULTURAL WORKFORCE BY CONDUCTING RESEARCH RELATED TO THE WORKFORCE IN THE US AGRICULTURAL SECTOR, AND ATTEMPT TO PROVIDE NARRATIVES APT TO INCREASE THE AWARENESS OF STUDENTS AND FAMILIES ON THE NOBLENESS OF AGRICULTURE. SECONDLY, WE WILL IMPLEMENT AN EDUCATION MODEL THAT WILL TARGET NOT ONLY STUDENTS MAJORING IN AGRICULTURAL-RELATED FIELDS BUT ALSO CURRENT AND FUTURE PARENTS AND/OR RELATIVES THAT COULD INFLUENCE OTHER INDIVIDUALS IN THEIR DECISIONS TO ENTER THE US AGRICULTURAL WORKFORCE. THEREFORE, THIS PROJECT WILL DOWNGRADE ROADBLOCKS ENCOUNTERED BY THE INITIATIVES DUE TO THE MISCONCEPTION OF AMERICANS ABOUT JOBS IN THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR. THIS REPLICABLE EDUCATION MODEL COULD BE EMBEDDED IN SHORT-TERM AND LONG-TERM POLICIES AIMING AT ENHANCING DOMESTIC AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND INTERNATIONAL COMPETITIVENESS BY BOOSTING LABOR FORCE PARTICIPATION.

THE CARIBBEAN COUNTRIES REPRESENT FLORIDA'S LARGEST SINGLE-TRADING BLOC. BECAUSE OF EXTENSIVE AGRICULTURAL TRADE AND TOURISM IN THE REGION, FLORIDA CONTINUES TO SEE NON-NATIVE PEST INSECT INVASIONS AND THEIR DETRIMENTAL IMPACTS. THE ONCE FORMIDABLE GEOGRAPHIC BARRIERS POSED BY THE ATLANTIC OCEAN AND THE CARIBBEAN SEA HAVE BEEN REDUCED THROUGH INCREASED TRAVEL AND TRADE. CONSEQUENTLY, DURING THE LAST THREE DECADES A GREAT NUMBER OF EXTREMELY DAMAGING PEST INSECTS BECAME ESTABLISHED IN FLORIDA AS THE RESULT OF BOTH ACCIDENTAL AND INTENDED INTRODUCTIONS. THERE HAVE BEEN SEVERE ECONOMIC LOSSES TO FOOD AND PLANT-BASED INDUSTRIES, EXPORT MARKETS, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND NATIVE SPECIES HABITATS. THIS INTEGRATED PROJECT FOCUSES ON DEVELOPING FAMU'S CAPACITY IN THIS CRITICAL NEED AREA TO SUPPORT GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY, AGRICULTURAL BIOSECURITY AND SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE. THE FOCUS OF EDUCATION COMPONENT IS : I) TO RECRUIT AND TRAIN QUALIFIED MINORITY STUDENTS IN ENTOMOLOGY, II) TO DEVELOP AND OFFER TWO FULLY ONLINE COURSES IN ENTOMOLOGY, AND III) TO REVIEW AND EVALUATE THE EXISTING PROGRAM CURRICULA IN ENTOMOLOGY, AND IV) TO INTEGRATE TRAINING IN EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES BY STRENGTHENING FACULTY EXPERTISE AND INSTRUCTIONAL RESOURCE BASE. THE FOCUS OF RESEARCH COMPONENT IS: 1) TO IDENTIFY AND PREDICT FUTURE INVASIONS OF POTENTIAL INVASIVE INSECTS, II) TO DETECT PRESENCE OF INVASIVE PEST INSECTS AND DETERMINE THEIR PATHWAYS, ESTABLISHMENT, SPREAD, AND SPEED USING GIS, LUCID, AND DIGITAL MODELING, AND III) TO DETERMINE ECONOMIC IMPACTS OF POTENTIAL INVASIVE PEST INSECTS.

IN ALABAMA, RAISING MEAT GOATS OFFERS A VIABLE FORM OF SUSTAINABLE LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION, PARTICULARLY FOR INDIVIDUALS WITH LIMITED FINANCIAL RESOURCES AND/OR LIMITED LAND AVAILABILITY GOALS OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT ARE TO: 1) PROVIDE A GENETICALLY SOUND TESTING PROGRAM THAT WOULD ALLOW BOTH LARGE AND SMALL MEAT GOAT PRODUCERS TO PARTICIPATE, 2) PROMOTE PERFORMANCE TESTING OF MEAT GOATS IN ALABAMA AND ACQUAINT PRODUCERS WITH ITS OVERALL VALUE, 3) PROVIDE A COMMON TEST FOR EVALUATING RATE OF GAIN, STRUCTURAL SOUNDNESS, MUSCULARITY, CONDITION, AND ESTIMATED CARCASS MERIT, PARASITE RESISTANCE, AND 4) PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY FOR PUREBRED BREEDERS AND COMMERCIAL PRODUCERS TO PURCHASE PERFORMANCE-TESTED BUCKS, WHICH HAVE BEEN EVALUATED IN PART UNDER SIMILAR, UNBIASED, ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS. A FINAL SELECTION INDEX WILL BE CALCULATED BY COMBINING THE GROWTH RATE AND CARCASS MERIT, AND UTILIZED THE INDEX TO RANK BUCKS AT THE CONCLUSION OF EACH TEST PERIOD. WIDESPREAD MEAT GOAT INDUSTRY USES OF SUPERIOR SIRES IDENTIFIED IN THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY FOR LIMITED-RESOURCE PRODUCERS TO PURCHASE PERFORMANCE-TESTED BUCKS, WHICH HAVE BEEN EVALUATED IN PART UNDER SIMILAR, UNBIASED, ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL HELP TUSKEGEE UNIVERSITY COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM TO PROMOTE MEAT GOAT PRODUCTION AS A VIABLE SOURCE OF SUSTAINABLE LONG-TERM, STABLE INCOME FOR LIMITED -RESOURCE FARMERS; ESTABLISH SUPERIOR GENETIC IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM; AND ENHANCE CONSUMER DEMAND FOR CHEVON AT THE RETAIL LEVEL. ALSO, THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NIFA CHALLENGE AREA ('GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY), PROGRAM PRIORITY AREA (SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE), AND PROJECT NEED AREA (EXTENSION DELIVERY/METHODOLOGY) BY UNDERTAKING STUDIES THAT PROVIDE A VARIETY OF RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO ASSIST LIMITED RESOURCES FAMILIES IMPROVE PROFITABILITY OF FARMS AND SUSTAINABILITY OF RURAL COMMUNITIES.

GINGER IS A PROFITABLE CROP FOR SMALL FARMERS IN VIRGINIA. THE GROWING SEASON IN VIRGINIA IS ONLY EIGHT MONTHS, AND IT IS HARVESTED EARLY AS 'BABY-GINGER" (4-8 MONTHS AFTER SPROUTING). THE VSU HAS INITIATED GROWING FIVE DIFFERENT GINGER VARIETIES: WHITE-CHINESE, INDIAN, BLUE-RING, YELLOW, AND RED-PINK. WE THINK THAT THE COMPOSITION OF DIFFERENT GINGER VARIETIES IS DIFFERENT, AND "BABY" AND "MATURE" GINGERS AFFECT HUMAN HEALTH DIFFERENTLY. OUR GOAL IS TO STUDY DIFFERENT TYPES OF GINGER AT VARIOUS HARVEST TIMES AND TEST THEIR EFFECTS ON OBESITY PREVENTION. (1) WE WILL GROW DIFFERENT GINGER VARIETIES, (2) STUDY THEIR COMPOSITION AND STUDY WHICH VARIETY IS BEST FOR REDUCING FAT STORAGE, AND (3) PROVIDE THIS INFORMATION TO FARMERS AND CONSUMERS. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE NEW RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION TO GINGER GROWERS IN THE COUNTRY (RESEARCH & EXTENSION), EVALUATE THEIR POTENTIAL FOR THE PREVENTION OF OBESITY (RESEARCH & EDUCATION), AND DEVELOP STRATEGIES FOR SPREADING EVIDENCE-BASED HEALTH INFORMATION (EDUCATION & EXTENSION). WE WILL PERFORM SOME OF OUR WORK IN COLLABORATION WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND, EASTERN SHORES. OUR STUDY WILL SERVE AS A MODEL TO LINK FARM AND LABORATORY RESEARCH TO FARMERS, HEALTHCARE WORKERS, AND CONSUMERS.

FOODBORNE ILLNESS IS A MAJOR THREAT TO PUBLIC HEALTH AND IS ASSOCIATED TO PATHOGENIC MICROORGANISMS ON FRESH PRODUCE. FOOD SAFETY CHALLENGES IN PRODUCE ARE BETTER SOLVED WHEN INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGIES IN DETECTION OF FOODBORNE PATHOGENS ARE APPLIED. METAGENOMICS OFFERS AN UNBIASED, CULTURE-FREE METHOD TO INVESTIGATE COMPLETE GENETIC MAKE-UP OF A FOOD SAMPLE, OFFERING INSIGHTS INTO THE ASSOCIATED MICROBIAL COMMUNITY. HENCE, THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) TRAIN THE PI IN METAGENOMICS AND BIOINFORMATICS; (2) INCORPORATE METAGENOMICS AND BIOINFORMATICS IN COURSES NEEDED TO PREPARE STUDENTS FOR SUCCESSFUL CAREERS IN AGRICULTURE. TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY (TSU) THEREFORE, PROPOSES TO: (1) TRAIN PI IN METAGENOMICS AND COMPUTATIONAL BIOINFORMATICS SKILLS; (2) INCORPORATE METAGENOMICS AND BIOINFORMATICS IN FOOD SCIENCE COURSES IN TSU; AND (3) CREATE LONG-TERM COLLABORATION BETWEEN TSU, USDA-ARS-NEA-BARC AND EZBIOME LABORATORIES. THE PI WILL BE TRAINED ON THE ENTIRE WORKFLOW OF METAGENOMICS WET LAB PROCEDURES AS WELL AS POST SEQUENCING BIOINFORMATIC AND STATISTICAL ANALYSIS USING CLOUD BASED METAGENOMIC BIOINFORMATICS PLATFORM. UPON COMPLETION OF THIS TRAINING THE PI WILL BE ABLE TO CONDUCT METAGENOMICS WET LAB AND BIOINFORMATICS AT HER LABORATORY AND TRAIN STUDENTS AND TECHNICIANS AT TSU. THE ANTICIPATED IMPACTS AND OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: (1) KNOWLEDGEABLE FACULTY (N=1) IN APPLICATION OF METAGENOMICS TOOL AND COMPUTATIONAL BIOINFORMATICS; (2) COMPETITIVE STUDENTS (N=16) WITH SKILLS TO ADDRESS FOOD SAFETY CHALLENGES IN AGRICULTURE; (3) ONLINE DATABASE/WEBSITE (N=1) ON MICROBIAL DIVERSITY IN PRODUCE IRRIGATED WITH CREEK AND POND WATER; AND (4) UPGRADED FOOD SCIENCE COURSES (N=2), AND (5) REFEREE JOURNAL ARTICLE (N = 1).

NEARLY ALL COW-CALF PRODUCERS WILL SAY THEIR GOAL IS TO SELL CALVES FOR A PREMIUM ON SALE DAY. HOWEVER, MOST BUYERS WILL SAY THEIR OBJECTIVE IS TO BUY HEALTHY CALVES AS ECONOMICALLY AS POSSIBLE. WHILE THESE MAY SEEM LIKE COMPETING INTERESTS, BOTH BUYERS AND SELLERS CAN GET WHAT THEY WANT WITH CALF PRECONDITIONING PROGRAMS. CALF PRECONDITIONING PROGRAMS PROMOTE CALF GROWTH, ENHANCE IMMUNE FUNCTION AND MINIMIZE STRESS DURING WEANING, ADDING VALUE TO CALVES AS THEY LEAVE THEIR POINT OF ORIGIN AND ENTER THE BEEF SUPPLY CHAIN. USUALLY, THESE PROGRAMS UTILIZE HIGH-QUALITY PASTURES AND GRAIN SUPPLEMENTS AND RANGE FROM 45 TO 60 DAYS AFTER WEANING. THIS PREPARATION WILL REDUCE SHRINKAGE AND MINIMIZE FEEDLOT MORTALITY. THE PRIMARY VALUE OF PRECONDITIONING PROGRAMS TO THE CATTLE INDUSTRY IS REDUCING THE RISK OF SUBSEQUENT SICKNESS IN CALVES. HOWEVER, A COMMON PRACTICE AMONG LIMITED-RESOURCE CATTLE PRODUCERS IS TO WEAN CALVES AND DIRECTLY SEND THEM TO THE STOCKYARD FOR SALE OFTEN AT MUCH LOWER WEIGHTS THAN PRECONDITIONED CALVES. THIS WEANING SYSTEM YIELDS THE LEAST ECONOMIC RETURNS TO THE PRODUCER BECAUSE THE BUYER ASSUMES ALL THE RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH A CALF THAT IS NOT PREPARED TO ENTER THE FEEDLOT PHASE OF PRODUCTION. THEREFORE, A PRODUCER CAN EXPECT GREATER RETURNS FROM PRECONDITIONED CALVES, AS OPPOSED TO SELLING NORMALLY-WEANED CALVES AT THE STOCKYARD.

GRAFTING INVOLVES UNITING TWO LIVING PLANT PARTS SO THAT THEY GROW AS A SINGLE PLANT. IT IS AN ANCIENT TECHNIQUE USED BY FARMERS AND GARDENERS TO COMBINE DESIRED ATTRIBUTES OF THE ROOTSTOCK WITH THOSE OF THE DONOR PLANT SHOOT, OR SCION. THERE HAS BEEN INCREASED INTEREST IN VEGETABLE GRAFTING IN THE UNITED STATES, TO THE EXTENT THAT APPROXIMATELY 40 MILLION GRAFTED TOMATOES ARE NOW GROWN ANNUALLY IN NORTH AMERICAN GREENHOUSES. UNTIL RECENTLY, WHITEFLIES AND FUSARIUM WILT (FW) HAVE BEEN MAINLY CONTROLLED IN WATERMELON BY PRE-PLANT FUMIGATION WITH METHYL BROMIDE. HOWEVER, IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE MONTREAL PROTOCOL AND THE US CLEAN AIR ACT, METHYL BROMIDE WAS PHASED OUT IN 2005. THE LOSS OF METHYL BROMIDE FOR PRE-PLANT SOIL FUMIGATION WAS ESTIMATED TO RESULT IN ANNUAL YIELD LOSSES OF 15% TO 20% FOR WATERMELON IN SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL US STATES. THUS, THERE IS A STRONG INTEREST IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND USE OF ALTERNATIVE TECHNOLOGIES SUCH AS RESISTANT ROOTSTOCKS FOR GRAFTING TO MANAGE WHITEFLIES AND FW IN WATERMELON AND OTHER VEGETABLE CROPS. THE GOAL OF OUR PROPOSAL IS TO ENHANCE RESILIENCY AND MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES FOR WATERMELON GROWERS IN THE UNITED STATES BY LAUNCHING APPROPRIATE GRAFTING TECHNOLOGIES TO OPTIMIZE RETURNS ON INVESTMENT AND ADDRESS BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC STRESS FACTORS. GRAFTING IS THE PRACTICE OF JOINING A CULTIVAR POSSESSING DESIRABLE MARKET AND HORTICULTURAL FEATURES (SCION) TO A ROOTSTOCK THAT CAN CONFER INCREASED RESISTANCE/TOLERANCE TO INSECT PESTS AND/OR ABIOTIC STRESS SUCH AS SOIL ACIDITY, AND MAY INCREASE YIELD OR ENHANCE FRUIT QUALITY. THIS PROPOSAL OFFERS A PLETHORA OF OPPORTUNITIES FOR GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO BECOME ACQUAINTED WITH AND BECOME FURTHER INVOLVED IN VARIOUS EXPERIMENTS IN BASIC HORTICULTURAL PRACTICES SUCH AS GRAFTING AND BREEDING FOR RESISTANCE TO BIOTIC AND ABIOTIC STRESS. THE TRAINING IN THESE TECHNOLOGIES OFFERED TO STUDENTS ALONG WITH THE APPLIED GENOMIC PROCEDURES OF HORTICULTURE WILL BRIGHTEN THEIR EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES IN VARIOUS PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ENTERPRISES AT BOTH THE STATE AND NATIONAL LEVELS.

WORLDWIDE, ONE-THIRD OF FOOD PRODUCED IS THROWN AWAY UNEATEN. REDUCING FOOD LOSSES AND WASTE BECOMES AN IMPORTANT APPROACH IN SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT AIMING TO ELIMINATE HUNGER. FOOD SPOILAGE RESULTS FROM OXIDATION AND MICROBIAL DECOMPOSITION OF FOOD NUTRIENTS AND OCCURS AT EVERY STEP FROM PRODUCTION TO SUPPLY CHAIN AND CONSUMERS. APPLICATION OF FOOD PRESERVATIVES IS A COMMON PRACTICE TO SUPPRESS THE GROWTH OF MICROORGANISMS AND OXIDATION REACTIONS, THUS PROLONGING FOOD SHELF-LIFE AND DECREASING FOOD WASTE. SELENIUM IS AN ESSENTIAL TRACE ELEMENT FOR HUMAN HEALTH AND HAS SHOWED BOTH ANTIMICROBIAL AND ANTIOXIDANT ACTIVITY. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO EXPLORE THE POTENTIAL APPLICATION OF MICROBIAL SYNTHESIZED SELENIUM NANOPARTICLES IN REDUCING FOOD SPOILAGE. OUR SPECIFIC GOALS INCLUDE: 1) OPTIMIZE MICROBIAL SYNTHESIS OF SELENIUM NANOPARTICLES FOR THEIR APPLICATION IN FOOD PROTECTION; 2) EXAMINE THE ANTIMICROBIAL AND ANTIOXIDANT ACTIVITY OF SELENIUM NANOPARTICLES IN VITRO; 3) TEST THE POTENTIAL OF SELENIUM NANOPARTICLES IN PROTECTING AND STABILIZING FOOD QUALITY; 4) INVESTIGATE THE SAFETY AND TOXICITY AND RELATED MECHANISMS OF SELENIUM NANOPARTICLES VIA IN VITRO AND IN VIVO METHODS. THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE INFORMATION REGARDING THE EFFECTS OF SELENIUM NANOPARTICLES ON PROTECTING FOOD QUALITY AND INCREASING FOOD SAFETY. FURTHERMORE, THE OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE ON THE SAFE USE OF SELENIUM NANOPARTICLES AS FOOD SUPPLEMENTS. THE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY NATURE OF THIS PROJECT PROVIDES A GREAT PLATFORM AT AAMU TO SUBJECT DIVERSE STUDENT/SCIENTIST POPULATIONS TO RESEARCH ON NANOTECHNOLOGY, MICROBIOLOGY, FOOD SAFETY AND TOXICOLOGY, THUS INTEGRATING CAPACITY BUILDING IN BOTH RESEARCH AND TEACHING IN MULTIPLE DISCIPLINES.

LONGLEAF PINE (PINUS PALUSTRIS MILL.) FOREST IS AN IMPORTANT FOREST ECOSYSTEM IN THE USA DUE TO ITS SOCIAL, ECONOMIC, AND ECOLOGICAL VALUE. HOWEVER, ITS EXTENT DECLINED DRAMATICALLY. ONE OF THE CRITICAL ISSUES IS ITS SPORADIC SEED PRODUCTION. OUR PREVIOUS STUDIES INDICATED THAT THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN CONE PRODUCTION AND CLIMATE (WEATHER) IS COMPLICATED. ON A DECADE SCALE, THE COEFFICIENTS OF VARIANCE (CVS) OF CONE PRODUCTION WERE POSITIVELY CORRELATED WITH THE CVS OF ANNUAL AIR TEMPERATURE BUT NEGATIVELY CORRELATED WITH THE CVS OF ANNUAL PRECIPITATION. IT IS UNCLEAR WHETHER CONE PRODUCTION IS RELATED TO TREE TIMBER GROWTH AND HOW THE POSSIBLE WEATHER (OR CLIMATE) FACTORS AFFECT THIS RELATIONSHIP. THIS RESEARCH WILL QUANTIFY THIS RELATIONSHIP USING FIELD DATA ACROSS DIFFERENT SITES ACROSS THE SOUTHEASTERN REGION. THE OBJECTIVES INCLUDE TO (I) CHARACTERIZE THE PATTERNS OF TREE GROWTH BASED ON STEM ANALYSIS; (II) COMPARE TREE GROWTH AND CONE PRODUCTION AND QUANTIFY THEIR RELATIONSHIP; (III) IDENTIFY THE LIKELY WEATHER (OR CLIMATE) FACTORS THAT MAY DETERMINE TIMBER GROWTH OR CONE PRODUCTION; AND (IV) GENERATE A QUANTITATIVE APPROACH WHICH CAN PREDICT THE ANNUAL DYNAMICS OF CONE PRODUCTION AND TIMBER GROWTH ACROSS THE RANGE OF LONGLEAF PINE. THIS PROPOSED RESEARCH PROJECT WILL PROVIDE MANAGEMENT IMPLICATIONS AND ALSO INVOLVE TRAINING STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS. IT WILL STRENGTHEN THE LINKAGE BETWEEN THE FORESTRY PROGRAM IN AAMU (1890 INSTITUTION) AND THE USDA FOREST SERVICE FOR QUALITY RESEARCH IN FOREST AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES. THIS PROPOSAL IS CLASSIFIED AS A STANDARD RESEARCH PROPOSAL WITHIN THE CBG PRIORITY AREA OF SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES.

PHYTOPHTHORA CAPSICI IS ONE OF THE MOST DESTRUCTIVE PATHOGENS IMPACTING PEPPER AND TOMATOES PRODUCTION. IT INFECTS ALL PARTS OF THE PLANT AND CAUSES SEVERE LOSSES IN YIELD. AFTER PHYTOPHTHORA BECOMES ESTABLISHED AT A LOCATION IS VERY DIFFICULT TO ERADICATE BECAUSE IT AFFECTS MANY VEGETABLE CROPS. FARMERS RELY ON CULTURAL METHODS TO COMBAT THIS DISEASE, BUT THESE METHODS ARE INADEQUATE. ALTHOUGH THERE ARE EFFECTIVE CHEMICAL FUNGICIDES, THE DEVELOPMENT OF FUNGICIDE RESISTANCE IS A PROBLEM, AND FUNGICIDES ARE TOXIC TO FARMWORKERS AND CONTAMINATE THE ENVIRONMENT, SOIL, WATER, AQUATIC LIFE, WILDLIFE, AND OTHER ORGANISMS. THERE IS CLEARLY A NEED TO FIND ALTERNATIVE TOOLS TO BOLSTER CULTURAL METHODS AND REDUCE FUNGICIDE USAGE. THIS PROJECT WILL (1) ADVANCE THE DEVELOPMENT OF BACTERIAL STRAINS FOR PHYTOPHTHORA DISEASE MANAGEMENT AND PLANT GROWTH PROMOTION. (2) DEVELOP USER-FRIENDLY FORMULATIONS OF THE NEW BACTERIAL PRODUCTS (3) GENERATE INFORMATION ON HOW THE BACTERIA WORK TO CONTROL THE PHYTOPHTHORA DISEASES AND PROMOTE PLANT GROWTH; (4) SHOW THE COST AND BENEFITS OF USING THIS TYPE OF DISEASE CONTROL; AND (5) PROVIDE TRAINING TO FARMERS AND EXTENSION AGENTS ON ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY PRODUCTS THAT ARE AVAILABLE IN THE MARKET AND THE NEW PRODUCTS FROM THIS PROJECT THAT CAN BE COMBINED WITH CULTURAL PRACTICES AND REDUCE FUNGICIDE USAGE. THIS PROJECT INTEGRATES RESEARCH AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES INCLUDING CUTTING-EDGE RESEARCH TO BETTER UNDERSTAND DISEASE CONTROL BY USING THE SELECTED MICROORGANISMS. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPACT VEGETABLE FARMING AND EMPOWER FARMERS TO MAKE INFORMED CHOICES ON DISEASE MANAGEMENT AND REDUCING TOXIC PESTICIDE RESIDUES AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION.

NUMEROUS STUDIES HAVE DEMONSTRATED THAT PLANT-DERIVED BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS COULD HELP PREVENT AND/OR TREAT A NUMBER OF CHRONIC DISEASES SUCH AS OBESITY, CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE, TYPE 2 DIABETES, NEURODEGENERATIVE DISORDERS, AND SOME CANCERS. THEREFORE, THERE HAS BEEN A RAPIDLY GROWING DEMAND AND INTEREST FOR THE FOOD INDUSTRY TO DEVELOP FUNCTIONAL FOODS USING VARIOUS PLANT EXTRACTS OR PURIFIED PLANT COMPOUNDS. HOWEVER, APPLYING THESE COMPOUNDS TO FOODS STILL REPRESENTS A BIG CHALLENGE PRIMARILY BECAUSE OF THEIR UNPLEASANT TASTE, LOW WATER SOLUBILITY, INSTABILITY, AND DIFFICULTY OF UNIFORM DISPERSION IN FOOD MATRICES. THESE ISSUES WILL BE EFFECTIVELY MINIMIZED USING A PROPER ENCAPSULATION TECHNIQUE. STARCH IS ONE OF THE MOST PROMISING CANDIDATES FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF DELIVERY VEHICLES FOR PLANT-DERIVED BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS DUE TO ITS VERSATILITY, RENEWABILITY, LOW COST, AND BIODEGRADABILITY. IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL DEVELOP A GENERAL FRAMEWORK FOR ENCAPSULATING LOW-MOLECULAR-WEIGHT BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS USING MODIFIED STARCH AS A CARRIER. THIS PROJECT WILL OPEN NEW APPLICATIONS OF STARCH IN FOOD AND NUTRACEUTICAL INDUSTRY AND FUNCTIONALFOOD DEVELOPMENT USING ENCAPSULATED PLANT-DERIVED COMPOUNDS SUCH AS GINGER EXTRACT. WE EXPECT THAT SUCH FOODS WITH HIGHLY IMPROVED SENSORY AND NUTRITIONAL PROPERTIES WILL PROMOTE CONSUMPTION OF PLANT-DERIVED BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS WHICH WILL HELP REDUCE RISKS OF SOME COMMON CHRONIC DISEASES.

ACCORDING TO THE2012 CENSUS OF AGRICULTURE, VALUE OF SALES FOR THE GOAT AND SHEEP SECTOR OF US AGRICULTURE INCREASED 33 PERCENT OVER THE SALES FIGURE FROM THE 2007 CENSUS. DURING 2012 SALES OF SHEEP AND GOATS AND THEIR PRODUCTS TOTALED $939.7 MILLION, ACCOUNTING FOR 0.2 PERCENT OF ALL AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS SOLD IN THE UNITED STATES. ADDITIONALLY, IN 2012 THERE WERE APPROXIMATELY 115,000 SHEEP AND GOAT FARMS, ACCOUNTING FOR 5.4% OF ALL FARMS IN THE UNITED STATES. MAINTAINING HEALTH OF SHEEP AND GOATS IS CRUCIALFOR MAINTAINING A SAFE AND AVAILABLE FOOD SUPPLY (HTTP://WWW.APHIS.USDA.GOV). GOAT PRODUCTION (ESPECIALLY MEAT AND DAIRY TYPES) IS THE FAST GROWING LIVESTOCK INDUSTRY IN THE US BECAUSE OF THE INCREASINGLY DIVERSE ETHNICITY OF THE POPULATION, HEALTH ATTRIBUTES OF GOAT MEAT AND MILK, COMPATIBILITY OF GOATS WITH OTHER DOMESTIC RUMINANT SPECIES, AND SUITABILITY OF GOATS FOR SMALL AS WELL AS MODERATE AND LARGE FARM SETTINGS. ALL GOAT INVENTORY IN THE US ON JANUARY 1, 2017 TOTALED 2.64MILLION HEAD, UP 1% FROM 2016 AND REMAINED STABLE THESE YEARS (2019; HTTPS://WWW.NASS.USDA.GOV). HOWEVER, ALONG WITH THE FAST GROWTH OF THE GOAT POPULATION, SOME HEALTH ISSUES OF GOATS PUT THIS NEW INDUSTRY IN JEOPARDY. A TREMENDOUS THREAT IS INTERNAL PARASITISM, WHICH SIGNIFICANTLY RESTRAINS GOAT PRODUCTION AND ERODES THE PROFIT OF GOAT PRODUCERS. THE USDA NATIONAL ANIMAL HEALTH MONITORING SYSTEM REPORTED THAT 74% OF SHEEP IN THE US ENCOUNTERED GASTROINTESTINAL PARASITISM (USDA, 2003). NECROPSY RECORDS HAVE SHOWN THAT INTERNAL PARASITES CAUSE MORE GOATS TO DIE IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES THAN THE TOTAL OF THE NEXT THREE LEADING CAUSES OF GOAT DEATHS (USDA, 2012). CURRENT MANAGEMENT OF INTERNAL PARASITISM IN SMALL RUMINANTS IS MAINLY THROUGH UTILIZATION OF CHEMICAL DRUGS. NEVERTHELESS, THIS PRACTICE IS CHALLENGED BY LACK OF EFFECTIVE ANTI-PARASITE DRUGS (FOR COCCIDIOSIS), AND THE INCREASING DEMAND FOR "GREEN" ANIMAL PRODUCTS IN THE CONSUMER MARKET. THEREFORE, THIS PROPOSED RESEARCH IS HIGHLY RELEVANT TO THE GOAT AND SHEEP INDUSTRY IN OKLAHOMA, OTHER REGIONS OF THE US, AND MANY PARTS OF THE WORLD.THE OVERALL GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO SECURE SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION OF SMALL RUMINANTS IN THE USA BY INTEGRATING RESOURCES AND TECHNOLOGIES AND ENHANCE THE IMPACT OF LANGSTON UNIVERSITY. TO ACHIEVE THESE GOALS, SERIES OF IN VITRO AND ANIMAL EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CONDUCTED. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF A VARIETY OF PLANT EXTRACTS COLLECTED GLOBALLY ON COCCIDIOSIS IN SMALL RUMINANTS. THE RESULTS FROM THESE STUDIES ARE ANTICIPATED TO DEVELOP ANTI-COCCIDIA PRODUCT(S) THAT CAN DIRECTLY ACT TO THE PARASITES OR INDIRECTLY THROUGH THE ENHANCEMENT OF PROTECTIVE IMMUNITY IN THE HOST. THE EXPERIMENTS WILL DEMONSTRATE EFFICACY OF THE ANTI-COCCIDIA COMPOUNDS ISOLATED FROM PLANTS AND THEIR CRUCIAL ROLE IN MODULATION OF THE IMMUNITY IN PARASITE-RESISTANCE. OVERALL, THESE STUDIES WILL PROVIDE SIGNIFICANT MEASURES AND INFORMATION TO COMBATING THE NASTYPARASITISM IN SMALL RUMINANTS INDUSTRY. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE CAPABILITY OF LU TO CONDUCT COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH OTHER INSTITUTIONS ON ISSUES RELEVANT TO US AGRICULTURAL COMPETITIVENESS, INCREASE THE SHARING OF RESEARCH FINDINGS, AND IMPROVE THE CAPABILITY TO PROVIDE LEADERSHIP IN INCREASING GOAT PRODUCTION EFFICIENCY IN THE USA. FURTHERMORE, THE INVOLVEMENT IN EVERY ASPECT OF CUTTING-EDGE RESEARCH AND STATE-OF-THE-ART LABORATORY TECHNOLOGIES AS PROPOSED IN THIS PROJECT, OUR STUDENTS WILL BE WELL PREPARED FOR A BROADER AND BRIGHTER FUTURE CAREER.

THE POULTRY INDUSTRY IS ONE OF THE MAJOR AGRICULTURAL ENTITIES IN THE UNITED STATES. ALABAMA RANKS 2ND IN BROILER AND 13TH IN EGG PRODUCTION IN THE NATION. THE INDUSTRY RELIES ON AN INTENSIVE PRODUCTION SYSTEM IN ORDER TO MEET CONSUMER DEMANDS FOR MEAT AND EGGS. IN RECENT YEARS, ALTERNATIVE METHODS OF POULTRY PRODUCTION HAS SEEN A RAPID GROWTH IN THE UNITED STATES, AND THE TREND IS ESCALATING. THESE SYSTEMS ARE VERSATILE, IN THAT THEY ARE INEXPENSIVE TO START UP, AND APPLICABLE IN MOST REGIONS OF THE UNITED STATES. INTEGRATION OF POULTRY PRODUCTION WITH CROPS AND OTHER LIVESTOCK PROVIDES A DIVERSIFIED FARMING SYSTEM THAT IS IMPORTANT FOR AGRICULTURAL SUSTAINABILITY ESPECIALLY IN SMALL FARM OPERATIONS.A MAJOR BENEFIT OF INTEGRATING POULTRY WITH OTHER LIVESTOCK IN A CO-GRAZING SYSTEM IS THE POTENTIAL OF REDUCING GASTROINTESTINAL PARASITES, THEREBY PREVENTING INFESTATION OF THE LIVESTOCK SPECIES. THE MAJOR GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO EVALUATE THE PERFORMANCE EFFICIENCY OF POULTRY RAISEDON PASTURE UTILIZING DIFFERENT TYPES OF FORAGES, AND THE INTEGRATION OF POULTRY AND MEAT GOATS ON INTERNAL PARASITE LOAD. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO: (1) EVALUATE THE EFFECT OF DIFFERENT FORAGES ON THE PERFORMANCE OF BROILER AND LAYER CHICKENS; (2) DETERMINE QUALITY OF MEAT AND EGGS FROM CHICKENS RAISED ON PASTURE UTILIZING DIFFERENT TYPES OF FORAGES; (3) DETERMINE THE EFFECT OF CO-GRAZING CHICKENS WITH GOATS ON PASTURE AND THE EFFECT ON GASTROINTESTINAL NEMATODE IN THE GOATS. THERE IS A GREAT NEED FOR INFORMATION RELATED TO THESE TOPICS, AND THIS PROJECT IS SEEKING TO DEMONSTRATE THE PROPER TECHNIQUES INVOLVED, AND THEN DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS TO ALL INTERESTED PARTIES INCLUDING POULTRY AND GOAT PRODUCERS, RESEARCHERS, STUDENTS, EXTENSION AGENTS, AND INDUSTRY. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON PRODUCTION TECHNIQUES, THE WELFARE OF CHICKENS AND MEAT GOATS (AS IT RELATES TO ENVIRONMENTAL AND BIOLOGICAL STRESS, AND INTERNAL PARASITES), QUALITY, AND CONSUMER ACCEPTABILITY OF THE PRODUCTS. FOR THE CHICKENS, MOST OF THE NUTRIENTS FROM PASTURE COMES FROM EATING GRASS SEEDS, INSECTS, WORMS, LARVAE, AND OTHER BUGS THAT ARE FOUND IN THE PASTURES. THEIR DIET IS USUALLY SUPPLEMENTED WITH UN-MEDICATED CONCENTRATE FEED FOR A MORE COMPLETE NUTRITION. IT IS IMPORTANT TO NOTE THAT THE NUTRITIVE VALUE OF CHICKEN MEAT AND EGGS ARE DIRECTLY RELATED TO THE COMPOSITION OF THEIR DIET. THEREFORE, THE TYPES OF FORAGES IN THE PASTURE WILL INFLUENCE THE NUTRITION PROFILE AS WELL AS OTHER COMPONENTS (COLOR AND FLAVOR) OF BOTH THE MEAT AND EGGS OF THE BIRDS. PASTURES WILL BE PLANTED WITH SPECIFIC TYPES OF FORAGES TO EVALUATE THEIR IMPACT ON THE QUALITY OF MEAT AND EGGS. SOME CONSUMERS ARE WILLING TO PAY MORE FOR PREMIUM, NATURALLY RAISED MEAT AND EGGS BECAUSE THEY PERCEIVE THE HEALTH BENEFITS OUTWEIGH THE ADDITIONAL COSTS. ALTHOUGH THIS SPECIALTY-PRODUCT MARKET WILL NOT COMPLETELY REPLACE THE CONVENTIONAL SYSTEM OF COMMERCIAL PRODUCTION, IN TERMS OF VOLUME OF PRODUCTION, IT IS AN IMPORTANT SUPPLEMENTAL COMMODITY FOR LIMITED RESOURCE FARMERS TO DIVERSIFY THEIR AGRICULTURAL ENTERPRISE. THE MULTISPECIES GRAZING INVOLVING PASTURED CHICKENS AND GOATS IS AN ALTERNATIVE METHOD BEING PURSUED FOR THE CONTROL OF GASTROINTESTINAL NEMATODES (GIN) WHICHIS A MAJOR PROBLEM ENCOUNTERED BY GOAT FARMERS.GOAT PRODUCERS RELYHEAVILY ONANTHELMINTICS (ANTI-PARASITIC DRUGS) TO CONTROL INTERNAL PARASITES INGOAT HERDS.UNFORTUNATELY, THESE PARASITES HAVE BECOME INCREASINGLY RESISTANT TO THESE DRUGS CURRENTLY ON THE MARKET. ONLY FEW ANTHELMINTIOCS ARE FDA-APPROVED FOR USE IN GOATS, AND DUE TO THE COST INVOLVED IN DEVELOPING NEW DRUGS, THERE IS A CONSIDERABLE WAITING PERIOD FOR ONE TO COME ON THE MARKET.PRODUCERS CAN NO LONGER RELY ON ANTHELMINTICS ALONE TO CONTROL INTERNAL PARASITES IN THEIR HERD. THE CONTROL OF GIN IS COSTLY TO THE PRODUCER AND INVOLVES TREATMENT EXPENSES, REDUCED ANIMAL WEIGHT GAIN, AND EVEN DEATH. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE HOPE IS FOR A NATURAL AND EFFECTIVE APPROACH TO REDUCE GIN THAT WOULD GO A LONG WAY IN CUTTING COST IN THE MANAGEMENT OF MEAT GOATS, MORE GOATS READY FOR MARKET, AND MORE PROFIT FOR THE PRODUCER. AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, PRODUCERS WILL BE ABLE TO DIVERSIFY THEIR FARMS BY BUILDING AN INTEGRATED SUSTAINABLE ENTERPRISE, AND ADDING TO THEIR INCOME, WHILE AT THE SAME TIME CONTRIBUTING TO FOOD SECURITY. CONSUMERS WILL BE ABLE TO MAKE PURCHASING DECISIONS WITH COMPLETE CONFIDENCE BECAUSE THEY ARE AWARE OF THE QUALITY OF THE PRODUCTS, AS WELL AS THE ENVIRONMENT IN WHICH THEY WERE PRODUCED.

THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE NEED TO STRENGTHEN AGRICULTURE, SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATHEMATICS (AG-STEM) KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS AMONG ELEMENTARY, MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS; ENHANCE THEIR APPLICATION OF AG-STEM CONTENT AND SKILLS IN PROBLEM-SOLVING CONTEXTS (I.E., SOLVE REAL-WORLD PROBLEMS) PRESCRIBED BY NEXT GENERATION SCIENCE STANDARDS (NGSS); HELP THEM DEVELOP AN INTEREST IN STEM AS A DISCIPLINE AND/OR AS A CAREER CHOICE; AND INCREASE COLLEGE ENROLLMENT OF KENTUCKY STUDENTS BY ESTABLISHING A STRONG AG-STEM EDUCATION AND OUTREACH MODEL PROGRAM FOR KENTUCKY STATE UNIVERSITY (KSU) TO REACH OUT, COLLABORATE, AND BUILD A PIPELINE WITH TARGETED K-12 PUBLIC SECONDARY SCHOOL SYSTEMS (GRADES 9-12) FROM THE TWO LARGEST CITIES IN KENTUCKY (LEXINGTON AND LOUISVILLE). THIS PARTNERSHIP WILL PROVIDE UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS FIRSTHAND KNOWLEDGE OF THE BROADER EDUCATIONAL AND CAREER OPPORTUNITIES IN THE AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES AND INCREASE THEIR AWARENESS OF KSU'S ACADEMIC PROGRAMS IN THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, COMMUNITY, AND THE SCIENCES (CACS). THE PROJECT WILL ALSO INTRODUCE AQUACULTURE AND AQUAPONICS CONCEPTS TO ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL-AGE STUDENTS AT KSU'S ROSENWALD CENTER FOR 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT. THIS PROPOSED PROJECT WILL COMBINE THE STRENGTHS OF EXPERIENTIAL, HANDS-ON EDUCATION AND INQUIRY-BASED SCIENCE LEARNING WITH A POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT FRAMEWORK THAT ADDRESSES THE DEVELOPMENTAL AND EDUCATIONAL NEEDS OF DIVERSE YOUTH. STUDENTS WILL BE ENGAGED IN ADAPTED WATER GARDEN LESSONS AND HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES THAT ALIGN WITH THE HIGH SCHOOL CURRICULUM. 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS SUPPORT AGRICULTURE LITERACY BY OFFERING EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES THAT PREPARE UNDERREPRESENTED YOUTH IN DIVERSE COMMUNITIES FOR A VARIETY OF CAREERS IN THE AG-STEM PIPELINE. THE PROPOSED PROJECT BUILDS CAPACITY AT KSU BY CREATING A NEW DUAL-CREDIT COLLEGE COURSE FOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, WHO WILL EMPLOY A PROJECT-BASED INVESTIGATION (PBI) INTERVENTION THAT MIRRORS REAL-LIFE WORK OF AGRICULTURE SCIENTISTS. SCHOOLS NEED MORE AUTHENTIC PBIS FOR STUDENTS THAT MANIFEST NGSS AND FOLLOW PRACTICES THEY PRESCRIBE. FURTHERMORE, THERE IS A DEARTH OF RESEARCH ON HOW PBI PROJECTS CAN FOSTER STUDENTS' KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS IN STEM DISCIPLINE(S), INTEREST IN STEM, AND INTEREST IN PURSUING COURSEWORK, CAREERS, AND/OR HOBBIES IN STEM DISCIPLINES. THIS PROJECT FITS WELL WITH A PBI FRAMEWORK DUE TO ITS FOCUS ON USING A REAL-WORLD PROBLEM FOR STUDENTS TO INVESTIGATE IN THE CLASSROOM AND MAKING CONNECTIONS TO REAL-WORLD ISSUES RELEVANT TO STUDENTS' EXPERIENCES, INTERESTS, AND LIVES.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT BUILDS ON KSU'S 1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION CAPACITY BY STRENGTHENING EXTENSION DEVELOPMENT AND SERVICES, AND BY UPGRADING EXTENSION TECHNOLOGIES AND CAPABILITIES. IT IS A CONTINUATION OF EFFORTS AT KSU TO INTRODUCE GENETICALLY IMPROVED TILAPIA FOR EXPANDING AND DIVERSIFYING LOCALLY FARMED FISH (AQUACULTURE) AND OTHER FARMED PRODUCTS. THE PROJECT AIMS TO TRANSFER ADVANCED GENETIC RESOURCES DEVELOPED AT KSU INTO LOCAL AQUACULTURE PRODUCTION, TO CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES AND FARMS TO GROW AND EXPAND, TO PROVIDE RESOURCES AND PROGRAMS TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF LIFE THROUGH DELIVERY OF NUTRITION AND HEALTH RESOURCES IN MINORITY AND OTHER MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES, TO PROVIDE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR EXTENSION SPECIALISTS AND AGENTS, AND TO UPGRADE RESOURCES AND EQUIPMENT NECESSARY FOR INCREASED EFFECTIVENESS AND WIDER EXTENSION IMPACT. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO: (I) PRODUCE GENETICALLY IMPROVED NILE TILAPIA BY USE OF CROSSBREEDING AND YY-MALE TECHNOLOGYTO OBTAIN SUPERIOR GROWTH PERFORMANCE FOR COMMERCIAL PRODUCTION; (II) IMPLEMENT ON-FARM NILE TILAPIA GROWTH DEMONSTRATIONS USING A FAST-GROWING TILAPIA CROSS DEVELOPED IN OUR PREVIOUS USDA CAPACITY BUILDING GRANT PROJECT; (III) BUILD EXTENSION RESOURCES TO FACILITATE AND EVALUATE THE MARKETING AND SALES OF LOCALLY PRODUCED AQUACULTURE PRODUCTS IN ETHNIC AND COMMUNITY LOCAL MARKETS SERVING MINORITY AND LIMITED-RESOURCE STAKEHOLDERS; AND (IV) DEVELOP HUMAN NUTRITION OUTREACH PROGRAMS AND RESOURCES FOR TRAINING AND EDUCATION OF EXTENSION PERSONNEL, MINORITY AND LIMITED-RESOURCE STAKEHOLDERS, AQUACULTURE PRODUCERS, BUSINESSES AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE AQUACULTURE GROWTH AND INCREASED CONSUMPTION OF LOCAL PRODUCTS, AND PRODUCERS AND CONSUMERS WILL BE EMPOWERED TO RAISE, MARKET, SELL, AND INCORPORATE TILAPIA AND OTHER LOCAL AQUACULTURE PRODUCTS INTO HEALTHY DIETS.

THE LACK OF URBAN TREE CARE KNOWLEDGELENDS TO DIMINISHED ECOSYSTEM BENEFIT RETURNS ON URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTS IN THE STATE OF WEST VIRGINIA, ESPECIALLY OUTSIDE THE EASTERN PANHANDLE. ALACK OF STATE FUNDING FOR URBAN FORESTRY PROGRAMMING AND STAFF FURTHER COMPLICATES KNOWLEDGE DELIVERY. THIS WEST VIRGINIA TREE MINDERS (WVTM) PROGRAM SEEKS TO PUT THE POWER OF URBAN AND COMMUNITY TREE MANAGEMENT IN THE HANDS OF COMMUNITIES, ALLOWING THEM A DEGREE OF SELF-SUFFICIENCY IN MAKING DECISIONS REGARDING COMMUNITY TREE CARE.ONLINE, SELF-PACED TREE CARE LESSONS WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED WITHTECHNICAL SUPPORT AND HANDS-ON TRAINING FROM THE WVTM TEAM, WHICH IS COMPRISED OF WV STATE UNIVERSITY AGRICULTURE & NATURAL RESOURCES EXTENSION SERVICE (WVSUES) AND THE WV DIVISION OF FORESTRY (WVDOF) URBAN & COMMUNITY FORESTRY (UCF) PROGRAM. THIS PROGRAM WILL ALLOW FOR MORE WIDESPREAD ACCESS TO UCF KNOWLEDGE SPECIFIC TO ISSUES AND CHALLENGES FACED BY WV COMMUNITIES WHILE MAXIMIZING IN-PERSON ASSISTANCE AND TRAINING WITH LIMITED STAFF. THESE LESSONS WILL ALSO BE INTEGRATED INTO FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE CURRICULA IN SEVERAL SMALLER WV COLLEGES WHERE THERE IS NO URBAN FORESTRY COURSE, PROVIDING A PATHWAY FOR STUDENTS TO PURSUE CAREERS IN THIS UP-AND-COMING "GREEN" FIELD. STUDENT INTERNSHIPS WILL ALSO PROVIDE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING.ECOSYSTEM BENEFITS OF URBAN CANOPY COVERAGE INCLUDEPOSITIVE IMPLICATIONS FOR HUMAN HEALTH, WATER QUALITY, ENERGY SAVINGS, AND COMMUNITY IDENTITY. EXPECTED RESULTS OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE MORE COMMUNITIES PLANTING AND ACTIVELY MANAGING URBAN TREES AND PARTICIPATING IN OTHER URBAN FORESTRY-RELATED PROGRAMMING AND FUNDING, AS WELL ASMORE WV STUDENTS ENTERING THE URBAN FORESTRY OR OTHER SERVICE ORGANIZATION WORKFORCE. THE WV TREE MINDERS PROGRAM WILL BE A HUB OF URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTRY CONTENT AND TRAINING THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS WITH STATE AGENCIES, EXTENSION, AND PROFESSIONALS IN THE INDUSTRY, PROVIDING A PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE PLATFORM OF EXPERTISE, EVENTS, AND CONTACTS SPECIFIC TO THE STATE OF WEST VIRGINIA.

MORE THAN 11% OF U.S. AND 10% OF VIRGINIA POPULATIONS ARE REPORTED TO BE FOOD INSECURE, A SITUATION THAT IS LIKELY TO WORSEN FOLLOWING THE PROJECTED IMPACT OF COVID-19 EPIDEMIC ON FOOD SYSTEMS. AREAS WITH LOW ACCESS TO AFFORDABLE AND NUTRITIOUS FOOD ARE DEFINED AS FOOD DESERTS AND URBAN AGRICULTURE HAS BEEN PROPOSED AS A MITIGATION STRATEGY. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD THE CAPACITY OF VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY (VSU) TO PROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE EDUCATION ON MICRO-FARMING. MICRO-FARMS ARE SMALL-SCALE FARMS SUITABLE FOR URBAN AREAS WHERE AGRICULTURAL LAND IS SCARCE, AS THEY MAXIMIZE USE OF SPACE AND PRODUCE HIGHER CROP YIELDS PER UNIT AREA. CURRENTLY THERE IS LACK OF SYSTEMATIC EDUCATION ON MICRO-FARMING AT VSU. THUS, THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO: I) PROCURE A MODULAR MICRO-FARM ("CROPBOX") SUITABLE FOR GROWING VEGETABLE, HERBS, AND MICROGREENS; II) CONDUCT RESEARCH EXPERIMENTS THAT WILL OPTIMIZE ENVIRONMENTAL GROWING CONDITIONS; III) DISSEMINATE RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION ON MICRO-FARMING; AND IV) ENGAGE STUDENTS IN HANDS-ON EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING ON MICRO-FARMING. THE TARGET AUDIENCES WILL INCLUDE EXTENSION AGENTS, MASTER GARDENERS, YOUTH LEADERS, AND VSU STUDENTS. THE EXPECTED LONG-TERM PROJECT OUTCOMES ARE: INCREASED URBAN FOOD PRODUCTION, ENHANCED FOOD SECURITY; REDUCED COST OF FOOD; IMPROVED HEALTH THROUGH ACCESS TO FRESH FOODS; AND INCREASED LOCAL INCOMES. THE SUCCESS OF THE PROJECT WILL BE EVALUATED CONTINUOUSLY USING APPROPRIATE TOOLS SUCH AS PRE/POST-TESTS, QUESTIONNAIRES, SURVEYS, AND FOLLOW UP INTERVIEWS. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES FOUR KEY NIFA PRIORITY AREAS, NAMELY, FOOD SECURITY; SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE; YOUTH DEVELOPMENT; AND OBESITY AS IT RELATES TO NUTRITION.

CASHMERE IS ONE OF THE FINEST AND MOST-EXPENSIVE ANIMAL FIBERS KNOWN TO MAN. IT IS USED EXTENSIVELY IN FINE CLOTHING, RESULTING IN GARMENTS THAT HAVE A LUXURIOUS FEEL AND HIGH VALUE. STANDARDS FOR CASHMERE PRODUCTION STATE THAT THE MAXIMUM MEAN FIBER DIAMETER (MFD) OF CASHMERE PRODUCING GOATS IS 19 MICRONS. US CASHMERE GOAT PRODUCERS INVEST CONSIDERABLE TIME AND FUNDS TO RAISE BREEDING ANIMALS WITHOUT KNOWING THEIR GENETIC POTENTIAL FOR FINE CASHMERE PRODUCTION. PRODUCERS WILL SAMPLE THEIR GOATS FOR CASHMERE CHARACTERISTICS AND GENETIC ANALYSIS THROUGH A GENOME WIDE ASSOCIATION STUDY TO IDENTIFY GENETIC MARKERS ASSOCIATED WITH CASHMERE PRODUCTION. PRODUCERS CAN THEN TEST POTENTIAL BREEDING ANIMALS AT AN EARLY AGE, SAVING MONEY AND INCREASING THE PACE OF GENETIC PROGRESS. CASHMERE PRODUCERS ALSO NEED A SOURCE OF SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION AND A FIBER GOAT SUPPLEMENT WILL BE CREATED TO COMPLEMENT THE ONLINE MEAT GOAT TRAINING PROGRAM OF LANGSTON UNIVERSITY. CULL CASHMERE GOATS OFTEN HAVELUXURIOUS FIBER ON THEIR SKIN FOR WHICH FIBER DIAMETER IS IRRELEVANT. TANNING GOATSKINS AS AN EXTRA INCOME GENERATING METHOD WILL BE DONE - BOTH BY HAND AND THROUGH WORKING WITH COMMERCIAL TANNERIES.

PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) ARE A CLASS OF PERSISTENT ORGANIC CONTAMINANTS PRESENT IN SURFACE AND GROUNDWATER SAMPLES AROUND THE WORLD. EXPOSURE TO PFAS CAN LEAD TO ADVERSE HEALTH OUTCOMES IN HUMANS, AS STUDIES IN LABORATORY ANIMALS HAVE OBSERVED DEVELOPMENTAL AND PHYSIOLOGICAL ABNORMALITIES UPON EXPOSURE. AGRICULTURAL STUDIES SUGGEST THAT PLANTS IRRIGATED WITH PFAS-CONTAMINATED WATER CAN ACCUMULATE THESE COMPOUNDS. SINCE INSECT PESTS FEED ON PLANT TISSUES, THIS PROJECT WILL EXPLORE THE IMPACT OF TRANSLOCATED AND ACCUMULATED PFAS ON BOTH PLANT PHYSIOLOGY AND PLANT-INSECT INTERACTIONS. PRELIMINARY STUDIES CONDUCTED AT UMES HAVE DEMONSTRATED PFAS TRANSLOCATION AND ACCUMULATION IN SOYBEAN AND TOMATO PLANTS WHICH AFFECTED SEVERAL PLANT DEVELOPMENTAL INDICES. AS A RESULT, PLANTS BECAME MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO DAMAGE BY THE BEET ARMYWORM, SPODOPTERA EXIGUA. IT IS HYPOTHESIZED THAT PLANT PHYSIOLOGY IS ALTERED BY PFAS, AND THUS DEFENSE MECHANISMS SUCH AS THE PRODUCTION OF VOLATILE ORGANIC COMPOUNDS AND REACTIVE OXYGEN SPECIES WILL BE ASSESSED. IN ADDITION, LARVAE GAINED WEIGHT AND PROCEEDED TO PUPATION MORE RAPIDLY. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE IMPACTS OF DIETARY PFAS ON THE DEVELOPMENTAL CYCLE OF THE BEET ARMYWORM BY EVALUATING GENE EXPRESSION AND HORMONAL CHANGES IN LARVAE. EXTENDING LAB-BASED OBSERVATIONS TO SELECTED FARM SITES ON THE DELMARVA PENINSULA, PFAS CONCENTRATIONS WILL BE MONITORED IN IRRIGATION WATER AND PLANT TISSUES. OUTREACH MATERIALS WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR AN ANNUAL SMALL FARM CONFERENCE HELD AT UMES, WITH INTEGRATION OF FINDINGS INTO UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE COURSES AT UMES. TWO GRADUATE STUDENTS AND TWO INTERNS WILL BE TRAINED AS A CONSEQUENCE OF THIS WORK.

THE HONEY BEE, A PILLAR OF THE ECONOMY FOR PROVIDING POLLINATION SERVICES AND PRODUCING HONEY, IS BATTLING UNPRECEDENTED POPULATION DECLINE. RESEARCH EFFORTS TO IDENTIFY THE CULPRIT BEHIND THIS PHENOMENON HAVE CULMINATED IN A MULTIFACTORIAL ETIOLOGY, INCLUDING STRESSORS SUCH AS PATHOGENS, CHEMICAL TOXICITY, AND POOR COLONY MANAGEMENT. THE INTRICACY OF THE PROBLEM ENTAILS A MITIGATION APPROACH THAT ADOPTS AN INTEGRATED ANALYSIS AND SCRUTINY AT LOCAL LEVELS. IN THE RESEARCH PART OF THIS PROPOSAL, WE SUGGEST CONDUCTING A HOLISTIC SURVEY OF PATHOGEN INCIDENCE, PESTICIDE RESIDUES, AND COLONY LOSSES OCCURRING IN APIARIES THROUGHOUT KENTUCKY. THE DISEASE DIAGNOSIS OF SAMPLED HIVES WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH MOLECULAR AND METAGENOMICS METHODS AND LINKED TO POTENTIAL PESTICIDE EXPOSURE UNCOVERED BY CHEMICAL ANALYSIS OF HIVE MATRICES. THE COLONY LOSS RATE IN RELATION TO RISK FACTORS SUCH AS POOR MANAGEMENT WILL BE DETERMINED BY AN EPIDEMIOLOGICAL SURVEY USING A QUESTIONNAIRE. IN THE TEACHING PARTOF THIS PROPOSAL WE SUGGEST CURRICULUM IMPROVEMENT BY ENHANCING EXISTING COURSES WITH PRACTICA AND NEW TEACHING TOOLS AS WELL AS DEVELOPING A NEW GENOMICS COURSE. THIS INTEGRATED PROJECT ALSO PROPOSES IMPROVING OUR EXTENSION SERVICES THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF CUSTOM-BASED SOLUTIONS, DETERMINED BY FIELD DATA, THAT WILL TAKE INTO ACCOUNT BEEKEEPERS' TANGIBLE NEEDS.IF FUNDED, THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN THE CAPACITY OF THE LONGSTANDING APICULTURE AND POLLINATORS HEALTH PROGRAM AT KSU, WHICH DELIVERS TRANSLATIONAL RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH TO STAKEHOLDERS. THE PROGRAM SERVES THE INSTITUTION'S GOAL TO CLOSE THE ACHIEVEMENT GAP OF UNDER-REPRESENTED MINORITY AND LOW-INCOME STUDENTS IN STEM FIELDS.

AQUACULTURE IN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY (CB) AND DELAWARE INLAND BAYS (DIB) OFFERS HOPE FOR RESTORING OYSTER POPULATIONS VITAL FOR IMPROVING WATER QUALITY AND A SUSTAINABLE SHELLFISH INDUSTRY. HOWEVER, THERE ARE PUBLIC HEALTH CONCERNS WITH OYSTERS DUE TO NATURAL PATHOGENS, SUCH AS VIBRIO PARAHAEMOLYTICUS AND VIBRIO VULNIFICUS. ADDITIONALLY, SPOILAGE MICROORGANISMS CAN ADVERSELY AFFECT OYSTER QUALITY AND SHELF LIFE. UNFORTUNATELY, INFORMATION IS LACKING ON THE EFFECTS OF AQUACULTURE PRACTICES (E.G., ON-BOTTOM VERSUS OFF-BOTTOM OYSTER CULTURE), THE INFLUENCE OF WEATHER EVENTS, AND PHYSIOCHEMICAL PARAMETERS ON PATHOGENIC VIBRIOS AND MICROBIOMES OF OYSTERS AND SEAWATER IN THE CB AND DIB. THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO ADDRESS THESE SPECIFIC DATA GAPS TO SHOW HOW AQUACULTURE PRACTICES, WEATHER EVENTS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS INFLUENCE THE PREVALENCE OF THESE PATHOGENS AND MICROBIOMES IN OYSTERS AND SEAWATER COLLECTED FROM BOTH BAY SYSTEMS USING STATE-OF-THE-ART MOLECULAR METHODS SUCH AS MOSTPROBABLE NUMBER (MPN) PCR, 16S RRNA SEQUENCING AND SHOTGUN METAGENOMICS. THE INVOLVEMENT OF STUDENTS AND STAKEHOLDERS WILL ALSO ENHANCE EDUCATIONAL AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES. SUCCESSFUL ACCOMPLISHMENT OF PROJECT OBJECTIVES WILL NOT ONLY AUGMENT OUR UNDERSTANDING IN THESE AREAS BUT WILL ALSO PROVIDE VALUABLE INFORMATION PERTAINING TO SEAFOOD SAFETY AND MONITORING STRATEGIES AS WELL AS AQUATIC AND HUMAN HEALTH RISKS. THE UNIQUE COMBINATION OF MULTI-INSTITUTIONAL EFFORTS IN RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND EXTENSION WILL ENHANCE THE CAPACITY OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND EASTERN SHORE (UMES) AND DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY (DSU) IN AQUACULTURE, FOOD AND THE AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE UMES AND DSU STRATEGIC PLANS AND UMES AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION MISSION AND DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THE NIFA-CBG PROGRAM PRIORITY AREAS: FOOD SAFETY AND WATER QUALITY.

MICRO CRYSTALLINE CELLULOSE (MCC) MATERIALS HAVE BEEN USED FOR A RANGE OF APPLICATIONS FOR MANY YEARS, BUT THERE IS LIMITED INFORMATION AVAILABLE ON THE PERFORMANCE OF BIOCOMPOSITE PANELS UNDER DYNAMIC IMPACT. DEVELOPING HIGH IMPACT STRENGTH BIOCOMPOSITES MADE WITH SWITCHGRASS, GIANT MISCANTHUS, DDGS HAS FUNDAMENTAL SIGNIFICANCE IN TERMS OF SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT. PROPOSED STUDY WILL ALLOW STUDENTS TO LEARN HOW TO DEVELOP NEW MATERIALS FROM BIO-BASED SUSTAINABLE MATERIALS COST EFFECTIVELY, APPRECIATE THE DIFFERENCES IN DIFFERENT BIOMATERIALS, ENGINEER COMPOSITE MATERIALS BASED ON COMPOSITE THEORY, AND DEVELOP TECHNOLOGIES FOR NEW BIOPRODUCTS. NEW BIOBASED PRODUCTS WILL HAVE FAR REACHING APPLICATIONS SUCH AS COST-EFFECTIVE BOARDS TO PROTECT BUILDINGS AGAINST NATURAL DISASTERS SUCH AS HURRICANES AND STORMS IN COASTAL CITIES.

MANY FACTORS LIMIT EFFICIENCY OF MEAT GOAT PRODUCTION SYSTEMS IN THE USA, ONE BEING RELATIVELY LOW LIVE WEIGHT AT HARVEST, WITH AVERAGE WEIGHT CONSISTENT AT 60 POUNDS OVER MANY YEARS. THIS RESTRICTS MONETARY RETURNS BECAUSE OF THE HIGH COST OF MAINTAINING REPRODUCING FEMALES YIELDING PROGENY MARKETED AT RELATIVELY LOW BODY WEIGHT. INCREASING HARVEST WEIGHT COULD BE ADVANTAGEOUS BY INCREASING RETURN PER ANIMAL AND LESSENING SUPPLY SEASONALITY. MOREOVER, WITH MARKETING AT A RELATIVELY YOUNG AGE, GROWTH RATE AND BODY WEIGHT COULD BE INCREASED BY MAINTAINING MALE ANIMALS INTACT, ADVANTAGEOUS IF MEAT QUALITY IS NOT COMPROMISED. DETERMINING OPTIMAL DIET COMPOSITION FOR MAXIMAL LEAN TISSUE ACCRETION AND MINIMAL DEPOSITION OF INTERNAL FAT WOULD ELEVATE PROFITABILITY. ALL OF THESE FACTORS MAY VARY AMONG DIFFERENT BREEDS OF MEAT GOATS AVAILABLE IN THE USA. THEREFORE, EFFECTS OF LIVE WEIGHT AND AGE AT HARVEST, THE NATURE OF THE DIET, CASTRATION, AND MEAT GOAT BREED ON CARCASS YIELD, MASS OF INTERNAL FAT, PRODUCT QUALITY AND CONSUMER APPEAL, PRICE PER UNIT LIVE AND CARCASS WEIGHT, COST OF PRODUCTION, AND PROFITABILITY WILL BE DETERMINED. RESULTS WILL BE DISSEMINATED THROUGH EXTENSION PUBLICATIONS, AN INSTITUTIONAL WEBSITE, PRESENTATIONS AT MEETINGS OF PRODUCER GROUPS AND PROFESSIONAL SCIENTIFIC SOCIETIES, AND ARTICLES IN PEER-REVIEW JOURNALS. THE FINDINGS REGARDING FACTORS INFLUENCING HARVEST AT HEAVIER WEIGHTS WILL BE OF VALUE THROUGHOUT THE USA. THE GAIN IN KNOWLEDGE REGARDING PRODUCTION SYSTEMS INCLUDING SOME 'FEEDLOT' CONDITIONS DURING A PORTION OF THE POST-WEANING STAGE OF PRODUCTION MAY LEAD TO MEAT GOAT PRODUCTION IN AREAS OF THE COUNTRY WHERE PREVIOUSLY ABSENT OR LIMITED. THIS SHOULD ALSO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF ANIMALS THAT CAN BE PRODUCED ON FARMS PER UNIT LAND AREA AND FACILITATE USE OF FORAGE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES BEST SUITED FOR THE INITIAL 'GROWING' PHASE TO THE CURRENT NORMAL HARVEST WEIGHT OF 60 POUNDS.

MUSCADINE GRAPES (VITIS ROTUNDIFOLIA) ARE GROWN IN THE SOUTHEASTERN USA MAINLY FOR FRESH FRUIT AND WINE PRODUCTION GENERATING MILLIONS OF DOLLARS IN REVENUE. THEY HAVE LONG BEEN CHERISHED FOR THEIR DISTINCT FRUITY FLAVOR AND A NUMBER OF HEALTH BENEFITS INCLUDING ANTIOXIDANT, ANTI-INFLAMMATORY, ANTI-CANCER, AND ANTI-AGING POTENTIALITY. IN SPITE OF HAVING HIGH NUTRACEUTICAL VALUE AND NUMEROUS HEALTH BENEFITS, MUSCADINE GRAPES ARE NOT PREFERRED AS TABLE GRAPE OVER EUROPEAN BUNCH GRAPE DUE TO PRESENCE OF LARGE SEEDS. MUSCADINE GRAPE INDUSTRY, THEREFORE, STRIVES TO DEVELOP SEEDLESS MUSCADINE GRAPES TO SUSTAIN THE GRAPE INDUSTRY IN THE SOUTHEASTERN USA. THERE ARE NO KNOWN SEEDLESS MUSCADINE GRAPE GENOTYPES THAT CAN BE USED FOR INTROGRESSION OF SEEDLESSNESS INTO MUSCADINE GRAPE THROUGH CLASSICAL BREEDING. BESIDES, IT IS ALSO NOT FEASIBLE TO TRANSFER SEEDLESSNESS TRAIT FROM BUNCH GRAPE (VITIS VINIFERA L.) TO MUSCADINE GRAPE THROUGH CONVENTIONAL BREEDING BECAUSE OF THEIR GENETIC INCOMPATIBILITY (40 VS 38 CHROMOSOMES) AND DIFFERING BLOOMING DATES. EVEN THE PROMISING EMBRYO RESCUE TECHNIQUE COUPLED WITH CLASSICAL BREEDING COULD NOT DEVELOP A COMMERCIALLY VIABLE SEEDLESS MUSCADINE CULTIVAR IN THE LAST 3 DECADES. BESIDES, CONVENTIONAL BREEDING TAKES MORE THAN A DECADE FOR TRANSFERRING A DESIRABLE TRAIT TO PERENNIAL CROP LIKE GRAPE. HENCE, ALTERNATIVE INNOVATIVE APPROACHES/TECHNOLOGIES HAVE TO BE EXPLORED TO OVERCOME THE LIMITATIONS OF CONVENTIONAL BREEDING FOR DEVELOPING THE SEEDLESS MUSCADINE GRAPES.IN GRAPE, SEEDLESSNESS OCCURS THROUGH PARTHENOCARPY AND STENOSPERMOCARPY. UNLIKE PARTHENOCARPY, BERRY SIZE IS NOT COMPROMISED IN STENOSPERMOCARPY AND PREFERRED FOR PRODUCING SEEDLESS GRAPE CULTIVAR. OUR RESEARCH IS DIRECTED TOWARDS DEVELOPING SEEDLESS MUSCADINE GRAPE THROUGH INDUCING STENOSPERMOCARPY IN MUSCADINE GRAPES USING INNOVATIVE GENE EDITING TECHNOLOGY. RECENT STUDIES SHOWED THAT REDUCED EXPRESSION OF GRAPE MADS-BOX TRANSCRIPTION FACTOR GENE, AGAMOUS-LIKE11(VVAGL11) IS RESPONSIBLE FOR STENOSPERMOCARPIC SEEDLESSNESS IN SULTANINA-DERIVED GRAPE CULTIVARS. THIS RESEARCH AIMS AT DEVELOPING SEEDLESS MUSCADINE GRAPE THROUGH SUPPRESSING THE SEEDLESSNESS GENE USING CRISPR-BASED GENE EDITING TECHNOLOGY. RECENTLY, WE HAVE IDENTIFIED THE VVAGL11 ORTHOLOGOUS GENE RESPONSIBLE FOR STENOSPERMOCARPIC SEEDLESSNESS IN MUSCADINE GRAPE (VROAGL11). THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL CHARACTERIZE THE VROAGL11 GENE FOR STENOSPERMOCARPIC SEEDLESSNESS IN MUSCADINE GRAPE AT THE MOLECULAR LEVEL, DETERMINE THE RELATIONSHIP OF ITS EXPRESSION LEVELS WITH SEED SIZE, WEIGHT AND NUMBER IN SELECTED MUSCADINE CULTIVARS USING QRT-PCR, VALIDATE ITS ROLE IN SEEDLESSNESS USING HETEROLOGOUS MODEL SYSTEM (ARABIDOPSIS/TOMATO) AND APPLY CRISPR-CAS9 GENE EDITING TECHNOLOGY TO KNOCK OUT OR SUPPRESS THE TARGET GENE FOR INTRODUCING STENOSPERMOCARPIC SEEDLESSNESS IN MUSCADINE GRAPES. THE CRISPR-CAS9 CONSTRUCTS OR RIBONUCLEOPROTEINS (RNPS) WILL BE DELIVERED TO GRAPE CALLI/PROTOPLASTS VIA AGROBACTERIUM-MEDIATED PLASMIDS AND/OR DIRECTLY (PROTOPLAST TRANSFECTION) TO KNOCKOUT OR KNOCKDOWN THE MUSCADINE VROAGL11 GENE. THE EDITED GENE WILL BE VERIFIED BY SEQUENCING TISSUE CULTURE-GENERATED PLANTS. OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL YIELD NON-GENETICALLY MODIFIED SEEDLESS MUSCADINE TABLE GRAPE AND BUILD CAPACITY AND EXPERTISE OF FLORIDA A&M UNIVERSITY IN CUTTING-EDGE CRISPR-CAS9 GENE EDITING TECHNOLOGY.

THERE IS A POSITIVE ASSOCIATION OF PROGRAMMING AND YOUTH OUTCOMES WHEN ADULTS FROM THE COMMUNITY VOLUNTEER. LOCAL VOLUNTEERISM IS ESSENTIAL TO DEVELOPING AND SUSTAINING INTEREST IN 4-H PROGRAMMING. EXPANDING THE PARTICIPATION OF THE 4-H PROGRAM TO INCLUDE MORE LOW-INCOME AND UNDERSERVED AUDIENCES IN A WAY THAT IS RELEVANT TO THEM AND SUSTAINABLE IN THEIR RESPECTIVE COMMUNITIES IS ESSENTIAL TO THE GROWTH AND SUCCESS OF NORTH CAROLINA (NC) 4-H. THERE IS A GREAT OPPORTUNITY TO DEVELOP STRATEGIES AND TRAINING MATERIALS TO SUPPORT BUILDING A STRONG VOLUNTEER BASE IN UNDERSERVED AFRICAN AND NATIVE AMERICAN COMMUNITIES. RECRUITING EFFORTS AND VOLUNTEER MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES WILL LOOK DIFFERENT IN LOW-INCOME AND COMMUNITIES OF COLOR (PREDOMINANTLY AFRICAN AND NATIVE AMERICAN) THAN THE TRADITIONAL 4-H COMMUNITIES, WHERE BUY-IN IS OBVIOUS AND THE PROGRAM IS WELL-KNOWN AND SUPPORTED. A CONCERTED EFFORT AND MODEL TO ATTRACT PARTICIPATION FROM BOTH ADULTS AND YOUTH RESIDING IN THESE COMMUNITIES ISA MAJOR GAP IN OUR CURRENT 4-H PROGRAM. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO (1) INCREASE THE NUMBER OF VOLUNTEERS IDENTIFIED, RECRUITED AND TRAINED TO WORK WITH 4-H CLUBS AND PROGRAMS IN TARGETED COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE STATE OF N.C., (2) INCREASE THE NUMBER OF UNDERSERVED MINORITY YOUTH RECRUITED AND RETAINED IN 4-H PROGRAMS ACROSS N.C. AND (3) TO INCREASE THE SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE OF 4-H VOLUNTEERS NEEDED TO LEAD 4-H CLUBS AND CLUB-LEVEL PROJECTS. THE GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO (1) DECREASE THE BURDEN OF FACILITATING 4-H CLUBS ON 4-H AGENTS, WHICH WILL INCREASE THE LOCAL CAPACITY TO SERVE MORE YOUTH IN 4-H; (2) INCREASE THE OVERALL NUMBER OF STABLE UNDERSERVED MINORITY FOCUSED CLUBS IN N.C. (3) INCREASE THE NUMBER OF MINORITY YOUTH EXPOSED TO STEM AND NUTRITION CLUB MATERIALS.

THE UPSKILLING OF 4-H EXTENSION AGENTS AND K-5 EDUCATORS IN AREAS OF AGRICULTURAL EDUCATION IS PERTINENT TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN AGRICULTURALLY LITERATE POPULATION THAT WILL BE WELL-INFORMED WHEN MAKING DECISIONS ABOUT THE FUTURE OF AGRICULTURE. IN A SYNTHESIS OF LITERATURE BY KOVAR ET AL. (2013), IT WAS FOUND THAT THERE IS AN INCREASED NEED FOR AGRICULTURAL LITERACY AMONG THE GENERAL POPULATION IN ADDITION TO THAT OF EDUCATORS IN FIELDS NOT SPECIFIC TO AGRICULTURE (KOVAR ET AL, 2013; ANDERSON ET AL, 2014). KOLOSKI AND RITZ (2016) CONDUCTED A NEEDS ASSESSMENT THAT DETERMINED AREAS OF FUTURE RESEARCH RELATED TO CTE WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF EDUCATOR PREPARATION, 9-12 CLASSROOM INSTRUCTION AND CONTRIBUTIONS OF CTE. THE RESULTS OF THE NEEDS ASSESSMENT INDICATED SEVERAL THEMES FOR MEASURED IMPROVEMENT: (1) STUDENT SUCCESS BASED ON A VARIETY OF OUTCOMES (CAREER AND ACADEMIC); (2) DEVELOPING COGNITIVE ABILITIES THROUGH CTE LEARNING (3) METHODS FOR CONNECTING CTE CURRICULA TO A RAPIDLY EVOLVINGWORKPLACE (4) CTE ADMINISTRATOR'S/SUPERVISORS DEPTH AND BREADTH OF KNOWLEDGE, EXPERIENCE AND CONCEPT OF CTE (5) SECONDARY ADMINISTRATOR'S PREPARATION FOR LEADING CTE PROGRAMS (KOLOSKI, ET AL, 2016).ELEMENTARY SCHOOL-AGED STUDENTS ARE AT A PRIME AGE FOR INTRODUCTION TO CONCEPTS OF AGRICULTURE AND ITS RELATIONSHIP TO STEM. EARLY EXPOSURE TO STEM AND SCIENTIFIC PROCESSES SUCH AS THOSE ASSOCIATED WITH AGRICULTURE INCREASES STUDENT MOTIVATION TO ENROLL IN ADVANCED MATH AND SCIENCE COURSES WHEN THEY ARE AVAILABLE. ADDITIONALLY, THIS EXPOSURE PROMOTES AN INCREASE OF CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS, CONFIDENCE BUILDING AND SELF-EFFICACY THAT CAN BE MAINTAINED THROUGHOUT A 10 STUDENTS' EDUCATIONAL CAREER (DEJARNETTE, 2016). THIS EARLY EXPOSURE TO STEM WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF AGRICULTURE DEMONSTRATES THE PROCESSES OF STEM IN AN APPLIED MANNER, ALLOWING STUDENTS TO DRAW CONNECTIONS BETWEEN COURSE CONTENT AND "REAL-WORLD" APPLICATIONS. IT ALSO ALLOWS STUDENTS TO BECOME BETTER AWARE OF AGRICULTURAL CAREER PATHWAYS AND BOLSTERS THE LIKELIHOOD OF AGRICULTURE CLUSTER COMPLETION IN SYSTEMS THAT OFFER HIGH SCHOOL AGRICULTURE PROGRAMS.IN ADDITION TO ASSISTING IN THE ACQUISITION OF AGRICULTURAL CONTENT KNOWLEDGE, PROJECTS SUCH AS THE AG-STEM INTEGRATED SKILLS INSTITUTE WILL BRIDGE GAPS BETWEEN VARIOUS EDUCATIONAL ENTITIES, COMMUNITY GROUPS AND STAKEHOLDERS WITHIN THE LOCAL COMMUNITY. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ALIGN NEXT GENERATION SCIENCE STANDARDS, A NATIONAL SCIENCE CURRICULUM STANDARD, NATIONAL STANDARDS FOR READING AND MATH AND CURRICULUM SPECIFIC TO THE STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA WITH EXISTING 4-H CURRICULUM TO SUPPORT AGRICULTURAL LITERACY WITHIN THE K-5 EDUCATIONAL SETTING. THIS CURRICULUM INTEGRATION WILL SHOW THE IMPACTS OF AGRICULTURE ACROSS A BROAD RANGE OF SPECTRUMS AND DISCIPLINES OFTEN OVERLOOKED AS ASSOCIATES OF AGRICULTURE. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO CONNECT LOCAL 4-H EXTENSION AGENTS WITH K-5 TEACHERS AND UNIVERSITY PERSONNEL, ALLOWING FOR THE FOSTERING OF ONGOING RELATIONSHIPS OF MUTUAL BENEFIT. THESE RELATIONSHIPS ALLOW FOR THE CONTINUAL TRANSFER OR EXCHANGE OF INFORMATION BETWEEN CONSTITUENT GROUPS WITH DIFFERENT ROLES WITHIN THE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM, FOSTERS EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AND PLACES VALUE ON THE UNDERSTANDING AND KNOWLEDGE OF PRACTICING AGRICULTURALISTS SUCH AS LOCAL FAMERS (GALBREATH, 2015). THIS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE OVERALL SUSTAINABILITY OF AGRICULTURAL KNOWLEDGE EXCHANGE AND INCREASE COMMUNITY VIABILITY AND THE SUPPORT THE 2014-2018 NIFA GOALS OF CATALYZING EXEMPLARY AND RELEVANT RESEARCH, EDUCATION AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS SERVING AS A MODEL TO BE IMPLEMENTED AT OTHER INSTITUTIONS. THROUGH THESE LINKAGES AND PARTNERSHIPS, THE SHARING OF KNOWLEDGE CAN CREATE A CULTURE THAT IS WELL EQUIPPED TO ADDRESS SOCIETAL CHANGES BY UNDERSTANDING THE ROLES OF RESEARCH, OUTREACH, EDUCATION, EXTENSION AND THE WAYS IN WHICH THESE DISCIPLINES INTERSECT TO INFLUENCE AGRICULTURE (BLUNDOCANTO ET AL., 2019). SIMILARLY, THE INTERACTION BETWEEN THESE GROUPS POSITIVELY INFLUENCE THE LEARNING ENVIRONMENT AND FUTURE INNOVATION IN ADDITION TO GENERATING NEW IDEAS WHICH HAVE POSITIVE IMPLICATIONS OF THE FUTURE OF AGRICULTURE AS CITIZENS BECOME MORE AWARE OF THEIR ROLES AND POTENTIAL CAREERS WITHIN THE DISCIPLINE (PANT, 2012).AGRICULTURAL LITERACY AMONGST THE GENERAL POPULATION AND AMONGST EDUCATORS IS NEEDED THROUGHOUT AS WE WORK TO PROVIDE A SUSTAINABLE FOOD AND FIBER SYSTEM TO SUPPORT AN EXPANDING GLOBAL POPULATION. UNFORTUNATELY, MANY PEOPLE NOW HAVE LIMITED INTERACTIONS OR ACCESS TO AGRICULTURE OUTSIDE OF THEIR CONSUMER EXPERIENCES AND MANY DO NOT RECOGNIZE THE SYNERGIES BETWEEN AGRICULTURE AND SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING AND MATH (STEM) (KOVAR ET AL, 2013; VALLERA & BODZIN, 2016). CREATING AN EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING-BASED TRAINING APPROACH TO INCREASE AGRICULTURAL LITERACY OF 4-H AGENTS AND K-5 EDUCATORS WILL CREATE AN OPPORTUNITY TO CONNECT CONCEPTS OF AGRICULTURE TO THOSE OF STEM THROUGH HANDS-ON PROCESSES ALLOWING PARTICIPANTS TO GARNER, APPLY AND DEVELOP TRANSFERRABLE SKILLS IN THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR. BY TRAINING EDUCATORS AND 4-H AGENTS IN THIS PROCESS, THEY WILL BE BETTER ABLE TO TRANSLATE AGRICULTURAL CONCEPTS TO K-5 STUDENT PARTICIPANTS BY INCORPORATING THEM INTO THEIR REGULAR LESSON PLANS, DISCUSSIONS OR ACTIVITIES. THESE TRAINING SESSIONS WILL ALSO ALLOW 4-H AGENTS AND TEACHERS TO BUILD UPON THE EXPERTISE OF ONE ANOTHER TO DEVELOP A CROSS-FUNCTIONAL APPLIED KNOWLEDGE BASE.

THIS RESEARCH PROPOSAL IS AN EXPANDED AND STRENGTHENED COMPONENT OF THE PREVIOUSLY SUBMITTEDINTEGRATED-PROJECT PROPOSAL. THIS CHANGE WAS MADE DUE TO THE ABRUPT RETIREMENT OF A SENIOR CO-PDFOR HEALTH REASONS. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS AIMED AT HELPING ADDRESS THE UNDERUTILIZATION ANDCONSEQUENTLY LOW MARKET VALUE OF SWEETPOTATO IN THE U.S., AND THE NATIONAL-TREND-BUCKING SHARPDECLINE OF SWEETPOTATO PRODUCTION IN TEXAS THROUGH DEVELOPMENT OF AN IMPROVED PURPLESWEETPOTATOVARIETY OF HIGHER MARKET DEMAND AND NEW TOOLS FOR FURTHER BREEDING IMPROVEMENT OFPURPLE-SWEETPOTATOES. ITS SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE, 1) TO EVALUATE THE CULTIVATION POTENTIAL OF A NEWLYSELECTED PURPLE-SWEETPOTATO LINE, 2) TO DEVELOP A BACK-CROSS OR F2 MAPPING POPULATION SEGREGATINGFOR THE ANTHOCYANIN CONTENT AND FOR THE TEXTURE OF SWEETPOTATOES, 3) TO DEVELOP A GENOTYPING-BYSEQUENCING PLATFORM USING THE HOMOEOLOG-LOCUS-SPECIFIC OR -DIFFERENTIABLE COSII-AMPLICONMARKERS, AND 4) TO MAP QTLS MODULATING THE ANTHOCYANIN CONTENT (AND POSSIBLY THE TEXTURE) OFSWEETPOTATOES, AND IDENTIFY LINKED MOLECULAR MARKERS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO STRENGTHEN OUR PLANTGENOMIC RESEARCH CAPACITY, WHICH WAS ESTABLISHED WITH THE PARTIAL SUPPORT FROM A PRECIOUS CBGPROJECT, AND BUILD SOME 'SOFT' CAPACITY IN FORMS OF EFFECTIVE WORKFLOWS, PROCEDURES, AND SEQUENCEDATA ANALYSIS PIPELINES ETC. THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS AN INTEGRAL PART OF A R&D EFFORT IN VEGETABLESAND SPECIALTY CROP FOR THE RESEARCH ARM OF THE LAND-GRANT PROGRAM. IT IS ALSO IN LINE WITH THE NEEDAREA I."STUDIES AND EXPERIMENTATION IN FOOD, AGRICULTURAL, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND HUMANSCIENCES", AND WITH THE PRIORITY AREA OF "SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE" OF THE CBG PROGRAM.

POLLINATORS INCLUDING HONEYBEES AND WILD BEES ARE CRITICAL FOR AGRICULTURAL FOOD AND CROP PRODUCTION. THEY ARE WORTH INVESTIGATION TO IMPROVE FARM PERFORMANCE, ECONOMY, AND YIELD OF AN ORGANIC FARM.
