THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO BUILD AN INTEGRATED FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION CAPACITY AT VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY (VSU) THROUGH COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS WITH DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY (DSU) AND UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND EASTERN SHORE (UMES) TO REDUCE POTENTIAL FOODBORNE ILLNESS FROM PRODUCTS SOLD AT DELMARVA FARMERS' MARKETS. WE HOPE TO FILL KNOWLEDGE GAPS IN FOOD SAFETY BY TRAINING FARMERS AND PREPARING THEM FOR FSMA COMPLIANCE. PROJECT SUCCESS WILL FACILITATE ESTABLISHMENT OF MULTI-DISCIPLINARY INSTITUTIONAL COLLABORATIONS TO DEVELOP WORKFORCE OPPORTUNITIES INVOLVING STUDENTS' HANDS-ON TRAINING AND DIRECT GOOD AGRICULTURAL AND HANDLING PRACTICE (GAP/GHP) IN COMMUNITY BASED FARMERS' MARKET SETTINGS TO IMPACT FARMERS, VENDORS, AND MARKET MANAGERS. OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN THE FOOD SAFETY AND MICROBIOLOGY (FSM) PROGRAM AT VSU AND EXPAND THE RESEARCH AND EDUCATION CAPACITY AT DSU AND UMES. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE VSU STRATEGIC PLAN AND THE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH STATION MISSION AND DIRECTLY ADDRESSES THE NIFA-CBG PROGRAM PRIORITY AREA: FOOD SAFETY.

NANO-ENABLED AGRICULTURAL FERTILIZERS AND PESTICIDES HAVE A GREATER POTENTIAL FOR DIRECT, MASSIVE INTRODUCTION OF MANMADE NANOMATERIALS INTO THE ENVIRONMENT THAN ANY OTHER USE OF NANOPARTICLES. HOWEVER, OUR CURRENT UNDERSTANDING OF NANOMATERIAL FATE AND TRANSPORT IN THE AGRICULTURE ENVIRONMENT REMAINS LIMITED. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS DEVELOP AN INTERDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH PROGRAM TO GAIN INSIGHT INTO THE PHYSICAL, CHEMICAL AND BIOLOGICAL PROCESSES THAT CONTROLLED BY PROPERTIES OF NANOPARTICLE, SUCH AS SIZE, COATING AND AGING. THE RESEARCH IS STRUCTURED AROUND FOUR TASKS: 1, DETERMINATION OF NANOPARTICLE DISSOLUTION RATES AS A FUNCTION OF SURFACE SIZE, COATING AND AGING EFFECT; 2, ELUCIDATION OF KEY ASPECTS OF NANOPARTICLE-PLANT-SOIL INTERACTIONS IN RHIZOSPHERE SOIL; 3, IDENTIFICATION OF THE FUNDAMENTAL PROCESSES CONTROLLING NANOPARTICLES TOXICITY TO SOIL MICROBE IN AGRICULTURAL SOILS; 4, EVALUATION OF THE FUNDAMENTAL PROCESSES CONTROLLING NANOPARTICLES RETENTION IN DYNAMIC TRANSPORT SYSTEM IN AGRICULTURAL SOILS. THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED THROUGH THIS PROJECT REGARDING THE RISKS RELATED TO UTILIZING NANO ENABLED AGROCHEMICALS WILL PLAY A KEY ROLE IN GUIDE NANOPARTICLES SAFE DESIGN, ADMINISTRATION, REGULATION AND RESPONSIBLE APPLICATION. INTEGRATED WITH PLANT SCIENCE, SOIL SCIENCE AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHEMISTRY PROGRAMS, SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL INCREASE UAPB'S RESEARCH CAPACITY ON NANO ENABLED AGRICULTURE DEVELOPMENT FOR SUSTAINABILITY.

THE AGRICULTURAL RELATED DISCIPLINES ARE NOT GRADUATING ENOUGH 'QUALIFIED' GRADUATES SUFFICIENT TO FILL THE NEEDED POSITIONS IN THE INDUSTRY AND GOVERNMENT, AND THE ANIMAL SCIENCE DOMAIN IS NO EXCEPTION. THEREFORE, THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A PARASITOLOGY LABORATORY FOR THE NEWLY LAUNCHED ANIMAL AND BIO-HEALTH SCIENCES (ABHS) PROGRAM'S CAPACITY TO ENHANCE THE TRAINING OF UNDERREPRESENTED MINORITY STUDENTS. THE PROJECT IS CONCEPTUALIZED BASED ON MULTIDISCIPLINARY AND COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS TO REINFORCE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING WITH THE STATE-OF-THE-ART SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTATION AND EQUIPMENT BEING REQUESTED. THIS EFFORT IS BELIEVED TO IMPROVE CURRICULA DELIVERANCE OF THE PARASITOLOGY COURSE, HENCE IMPROVE ON THE RECRUITMENT OF HIGH QUALITY STUDENTS IN THE ABHS PROGRAM. THE FACULTY PREPARATION COMPONENT OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ENHANCE HANDS-ON TEACHING CULMINATING INTO EXPERIMENTAL LEARNING ON FEED FORMULATION, ANALYSIS OF NUTRITIONAL COMPONENTS AND THEIR IMPACT ON THE PARASITES IN RUMINANTS. A BODY OF KNOWLEDGE TO ENRICH THE OVERALL ABHS COURSES, CONTRIBUTES TO THE CURRICULA TRANSFORMATION IN THE AGRICULTURAL AND AGRICULTURE-RELATED EDUCATION IN TUNE WITH THE ADVANCES OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY. HENCE, DEVELOPMENT OF A PLATFORM TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR TRAINING STUDENTS IN LEADERSHIP SKILL DEVELOPMENT,WILL SIGNIFICANTLY IMPACTOVER 100 ABHS STUDENTS AND OVER 20 HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS THROUGH THE DIFFERENT PROGRAMMING, DURING THE LIFESPAN OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL AID IN ACHIEVING USDA-NIFA STRATEGIC GOALS TO ENSURE THE DEVELOPMENT OF HUMAN CAPITAL IN DIVERSE WORKFORCE THROUGH RESEARCH, EDUCATION, EXTENSION, ENGAGEMENT PROGRAMS IN FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES TO SUPPORT SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS.

US LAND GRANT UNIVERSITIES PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN MAINTAINING OUR COMPETITIVENESS GLOBALLY IN AGRICULTURE INDUSTRY. IT IS NECESSARY TO TRAIN FACULTY, STAFF AND STUDENTS IN INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURE TO MAINTAIN OUR PREEMINENT STATUS IN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND TRADE. THIS STUDY ABROAD OPPORTUNITY TO JAMAICA IS DESIGNED TO EXPOSE PARTICIPATING STUDENTS AND FACULTY TO AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION, POLICY, RESEARCH, AND SUSTAINABILITY ISSUES IN THE CARIBBEAN REGION. THE CORE EXPERIENCE INVOLVES A STRUCTURED THREE WEEK STUDY TRIP THAT ALLOWS MAXIMUM INTERACTION BETWEEN OUR STUDENTS AND INSTITUTIONS AND INDIVIDUALS IN JAMAICA IN THE AREAS OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES. THIS PROJECT WILL PLAY A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN BUILDING THE TEACHING CAPACITY OF PROGRAMS AT THREE PARTNER UNIVERSITIES IN THE US. A NEW COURSE IN INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURE WILL BE DEVELOPED AND TAUGHT AS PART OF THIS PROGRAM. THE VISION OF THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY AT DSU AND THE SCHOOL OF AGRICULTURAL AND NATURAL SCIENCES AT UMES AND TUSKEGEE UNIVERSITY INCLUDE ACHIEVING EXCELLENCE THROUGH INTERNATIONAL COLLABORATION IN RESEARCH, EDUCATION AND EXTENSION BY INVOLVING FACULTY AND STUDENTS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE 36 STUDENTS AND 3 FACULTY EXPOSED TO INTERNATIONAL FIELD EXPERIENCE IN JAMAICA, STUDENTS PREPARED FOR GLOBALLY COMPETITIVE WORKFORCE AND SERVE AS AMBASSADORS FOR AGRICULTURE. DSU, UMES AND TUSKEGEE UNIVERSITY FACULTY WILL BE BETTER EQUIPPED TO TRAIN STUDENTS OF THE TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY, AND THREE INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURE COURSES WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR SHARING AMONG THE PARTNERING INSTITUTIONS.

URBAN FOREST/WOOD WASTE-STREAMS (UFWWS) IN MARYLAND (MD) REPRESENT POTENTIAL RAW MATERIAL SOURCES FOR PRODUCING PLATFORM CHEMICALS THAT CAN BE CONVERTED TO HIGHER VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS FOR ITS EMERGING BIO-ECONOMY. THE CURRENT PRACTICE OF LANDFILLING URBAN/WOOD WASTE-STREAMS IS EXPENSIVE (TIPPING FEES) AND EVENTUALLY RESULTS IN LONG-TERM ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEMS. FURTHER, CURRENT PRODUCTS FROM THIS RESOURCE ARE HIGH-VOLUME, LOW-VALUE PRODUCTS SUCH AS LANDSCAPE MULCH, SOIL CONDITIONER, ANIMAL BEDDING, COMPOST ADDITIVE, ETC. A MULTIDISCIPLINARY COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH EFFORT BETWEEN THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND EASTERN SHORE (UMES) AND A SCIENTIST FROM WEST VIRGINIA UNIVERSITY'S DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES WILL ADDRESS THIS PROBLEM THROUGH THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: A) ESTIMATE AVAILABLE UFWWS IN 60 TOWNS/CITIES IN MARYLAND; AND B) DEVELOP ALTERNATE LOW-VOLUME, HIGH-VALUE NOVEL BIO-ENERGY/BIO-PRODUCTS FROM THESE WASTE-STREAMS TO MEET MD'S EMERGING BIO-ECONOMY MARKET. THIS PROPOSAL RESPONDS DIRECTLY TO THE RESEARCH NEEDS OF FORESTERS, ARBORICULTURALISTS, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, RESEARCHERS, AS WELL AS DIRECTLY ADDRESSES ONE OF THE HIGH PRIORITY AREAS OF THE CAPACITY BUILDING GRANT PROGRAM - BIOENERGY/BIOFUEL AND NATURAL RESOURCE. THE PROPOSEDRESEARCH SEEKS TO UPGRADE THE RESEARCH CAPABILITY OF THE URBAN FORESTRY PROGRAM AT UMES BY PROVIDING EXPERIENTIAL RESEARCH TRAINING TOUNDERGRADUATE, GRADUATE STUDENTS, AND A POST-DOCTORAL FELLOW.FINDINGS FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL BE DISTRIBUTED THROUGH SEVERAL MECHANISMS: FACT SHEETS, POSTER AND CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS, REFEREED JOURNAL ARTICLES, UMES URBAN FORESTRY WEBSITE, TO STAKEHOLDERS (MARYLAND DNR, ARBORISTS, FOREST PRODUCTS UTILIZATION COMPANIES, ETC.).

ALABAMA A&M UNIVERSITY'S DEPARTMENT OF BIOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES HAS A HISTORY OF ACTIVE RESEARCH AND ENGAGEMENT OF THE UNDERGRADUATES IN OUR PROJECTS. THIS HAS HELPED US WITH STUDENT LEARNING, RECRUITMENT, AND RETENTION. FACULTY FROM THE DEPARTMENT HAVE NOW PARTNERED WITH THE SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION'S FOREST GLOBAL EARTH OBSERVATORY (FORESTGEO), A NETWORK OF SITES IN 24 COUNTRIES, TO: (1) INCREASE MINORITY STUDENT HANDS-ON PARTICIPATION IN CUTTING-EDGE RESEARCH IN FOREST SCIENCE, THEREBY (2) OPENING CAREER PATHS IN FOREST SCIENCE AND MANAGEMENT FOR OUR GRADUATES, AND (3) TO ACCOMPLISH (1) AND (2) THROUGH OUR PAINT ROCK FOREST DYNAMICS PROJECT, A LONG-TERM EDUCATIONAL AND FOREST RESEARCH SITE/FACILITY ESTABLISHED IN A PROTECTED FOREST RESERVE OWNED BY THE NATURE CONSERVANCY AND LOCATED JUST 30 MINUTES FROM CAMPUS. THE RESEARCH FACILITY WILL CONSIST OF AREAS FOR MANIPULATIVE EXPERIMENTS AND TWO 25 HA PERMANENT RESEARCH PLOTS IN WHICH ALL TREES WILL BE INDIVIDUALLY IDENTIFIED, MAPPED, AND MEASURED THROUGH TIME TO RECORD FOREST DYNAMICS IN RELATION TO ENVIRONMENTAL GRADIENTS AND CHANGING CLIMATE. WE CHOSE THE LOCATION BECAUSE THE RESERVE HARBORS ONE OF THE MOST DIVERSE TREE COMMUNITIES IN NORTH AMERICA, RIVALING THE DIVERSITY OF SOME TROPICAL FORESTS. THIS PROPOSED PROJECT HAS ALREADY ATTRACTED SEVERAL NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL COLLABORATORS. THE PARTNERSHIP WITH THE SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION'S FORESTGEO IS PARTICULARLY NOTEWORTHY. FORESTGEO WILL PROVIDE OUR STUDENTS WITH OPPORTUNITIES TO PARTICIPATE IN TRAINING WORKSHOPS AT SITES AROUND THE WORLD, ENABLING THEM TO RECEIVE ADVANCED TRAINING IN FOREST SCIENCE, MANAGEMENT, AND CONSERVATION, GIS, AND BIG-DATA ANALYSIS FROM THE WORLD'S TOP EXPERTS IN FOREST SCIENCE.

THE PRIMARY PROJECT TYPE OF THIS INTEGRATED PROPOSAL IS TEACHING/EDUCATION, WHICH RESPONDS DIRECTLY TO THE TEACHING AND RESEARCH NEEDS IDENTIFIED BY ACADEMIA, PRODUCERS/FARMERS, PROCESSORS AND CONSUMERS. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A SUSTAINABLE COLLABORATIVE, INTEGRATED MODEL AMONG FOOD AND NUTRITIONAL SCIENCES (FNS), CHEMICAL ENGINEERING (CE) AND EXTENSION TO SCALE-UP THE PROCESSES AND PRODUCTION OF A SWEETPOTATO SYRUP, A MODEL, WHICH WILL FACILITATE TRAINING OF UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS, PROFESSIONALS, PRODUCERS, PROCESSORS AND CONSUMERS. IN AMERICA, SWEETPOTATO PRODUCTION HAS INCREASED SUBSTANTIALLY OVER THE LAST 15 YEARS AND PER CAPITA CONSUMPTION INCREASED NEARLY 80%. THE INCREASED CONSUMER DEMAND FOR SWEETPOTATO IS ASSOCIATED WITH THE EMERGING HEALTH BENEFITS OF ITS CONSUMPTION; THIS IS EXPECTED TO GENERATE ADDITIONAL CONSUMPTION, AS WELL AS A GROWING DEMAND FOR PROCESSED SWEETPOTATO PRODUCTS. SPECIFICALLY, THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL: I) TRAIN UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS IN FOOD SCIENCE ENGINEERING PRINCIPLES, AND THE PRODUCTION AND PROCESSING OF A PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED SWEETPOTATO SYRUP; II) OPTIMIZE THE PROCESS, PRODUCT AND EVALUATION OF AN EXISTING SWEETPOTATO SYRUP; III) DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A FOOD SCIENCE ENGINEERING CERTIFICATE RESIDENT AND ON-LINE COURSE FOR STUDENTS AND PROFESSIONALS; AND IV) DEVELOP AND CONDUCT EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS AND TRAINING MATERIALS TO EDUCATE SMALL AND LIMITED RESOURCE SWEETPOTATO PRODUCERS, PROCESSORS, EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS, AND CONSUMERS IN THE ALABAMA BLACK BELT COUNTIES TO ENHANCE PRODUCTION, VALUE ADDITION, PROCESSING, AND CONSUMPTION OF SWEETPOTATO. A FOOD SCIENCE ENGINEERING CERTIFICATE COURSE (FSEC) WILL BE DEVELOPED AND OFFERED. INTEGRATED, TEAM-TAUGHT COURSES IN FOOD SCIENCE AND CHEMICAL ENGINEERING WILL BE OFFERED ON-LINE AND IN-CLASS. FSEC WILL TARGET PROFESSIONALS ALREADY EMPLOYED IN THE FOOD INDUSTRY OR THOSE INDIVIDUALS INTERESTED IN JOINING FOOD AND FOOD-RELATED AND/OR ENGINEERING AND RELATED INDUSTRIES. GRADUATE STUDENTS FROM FNS AND CE WILL BE EXPECTED TO DEVELOP THESES CENTERED ON THE PRODUCTION AND PROCESSING OF PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED SWEETPOTATO SYRUP. ONE THRUST OF THE PROPOSED MULTIDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH IS TO DEVELOP A ROBUST SYSTEM AND ITS RELATED ENGINEERING PROCESSES TO PRODUCE A LARGER BATCH OF SWEETPOTATO SYRUP, WHICH CAN BE TESTED AND EVALUATED AS A PRECURSOR FOR COMMERCIALIZATION. OUR INTENT IS TO MORE EFFECTIVELY LINK TEACHING, RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS TO PROVIDE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO LIMITED RESOURCE AND UNDERSERVED FARMERS AND CONSUMERS, WHICH WILL MAXIMIZE PROFITS AND BENEFITS FROM THE SWEETPOTATO VALUE CHAIN. THE FSEC, A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT AMONG FNS, CE AND EXTENSION WILL BE CONTINUED AS A RESIDENT AND ON-LINE OFFERING AT TU. OUR CONTINUATION PLAN INCLUDES RETENTION OF THE NUTRITION AND WELLNESS COORDINATOR TO STRENGTHEN ACTIVITIES (INCLUDING THE SWEETPOTATO SERIES) GEARED TOWARDS THE PRODUCERS/FARMERS, PROCESSORS, AND CONSUMERS. THE SUSTAINABLE, CONTINUATION PLAN ALSO INCLUDES SCALING-UP OTHER SWEETPOTATO PRODUCTS SUCH AS THE BEVERAGE, CEREAL AND BREAD FOR THE GRADUATE RESEARCH COMPONENT OF THIS PROJECT AND THUS CONTINUE TO ENHANCE THE SWEETPOTATO VALUE CHAIN.

MEAT GOAT PRODUCTION CAN BE A SUSTAINABLE ALTERNATIVE OR A COMPLEMENT TO TRADITIONAL LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION SYSTEMS SUCH AS BEEF CATTLE PRODUCTION OR OTHER DECLINING AGRICULTURAL ENDEAVORS. MOST GOATS ARE HIGHLY SUSCEPTIBLE TO INTERNAL PARASITES WHICH RESULTS IN HIGHER INPUT COST, LOWER PERFORMANCE RATES, AND DIMINISHED CHANCES OF PROFIT. SIMILARLY TO CATTLE MANAGEMENT, MOST GOAT PRODUCTION SYSTEMS IN THE SOUTHERN US ARE DEPENDENT ON PASTURELAND. HOWEVER, CATTLE ARE FAR LESS SUSCEPTIBLE TO INTERNAL PARASITISM THAN GOATS. MOST OF ALABAMA IS CHARACTERIZED AS FORESTLAND SUPPORTING THE TIMBER INDUSTRY THAT GENERATES $13 BILLION ANNUALLY. FOREST WILDFIRES ARE A CONSTANT THREAT, PARTICULARLY IF UNDERSTORY PLANT GROWTH IS NOT CONTROLLED. THE OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT ARE (1) TO DEMONSTRATE THE USE OF FOREST LAND IN THE PRODUCTION OF MEAT GOATS, (2) TO EDUCATE FOREST LANDOWNERS ON THE BIOECONOMIC POTENTIAL OF INCORPORATING MEAT GOAT PRODUCTION INTO FOREST LAND MANAGEMENT, AND (3) TO DEMONSTRATE THE IMPACT OF GOAT GRAZING ON SOIL FERTILITY AND UNDERSTORY VEGETATION GROWTH. THIS PROJECT WILL TEACH AN ALTERNATIVE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM TO GOAT AND FOREST MANAGERS. THIS EXTENSION PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NIFA PRIORITY AREA OF GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY AND AGRICULTURAL BIOSECURITY. THIS PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE THE MEAT GOAT INVENTORY IN ALABAMA. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE CAPACITY AT AAMU BY RECUPERATING A WOODED RESEARCH PARK AREA THAT HAS BECOME UNUSABLE BECAUSE OF UNCONTROLLED VEGETATION GROWTH AND TURNING IT INTO AN ACTIVE DEMONSTRATION SITE. THE ABILITY TO TRAIN LIMITED RESOURCE PRODUCERS WILL BE ENHANCED.

SMALL AND MINORITY FARMERS ARE LOOKING FOR NEW, ORGANIC METHODS TO CONTROL WEEDS AND PESTS IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION. TO INCREASE SMALL FARM ECONOMIC EFFICIENCY AND SUSTAINABILITY, CENTRAL STATE UNIVERSITY (CSU) IS SEEKING FUNDS TO DEVELOP FIELD EQUIPMENT WITH THE SMALL FARMER IN MIND. AN ALL-IN-ONE ORGANIC WEED AND PEST CONTROL SYSTEM WITH INTERCHANGEABLE COMPONENTS FOR VARIOUS FIELD TASKS WILL BE DEVELOPED AND TESTED. A PROTOTYPE FOR KILLING WEEDS WITH DIRECTED ENERGY IN SOYBEAN FIELDS WAS DEVELOPED THROUGH A PREVIOUS CBG GRANT, "TRANSITION AND DEMONSTRATION CAPACITY: NON-CHEMICAL TECHNOLOGY WEED DISRUPTION IN AGRICULTURE" (2014-2017; LOWELL C (PI), MORRIS A (CO-PI)). A SUBSTANTIALLY NON-INVASIVE ORGANIC WEEDING METHOD USING RAPID UNNATURAL DUAL COMPONENT SELECTIVE ILLUMINATION PROTOCOL (RUDCIP, PATENT #US8872136) WAS APPLIED IN THE PREVIOUS PROTOTYPE, AND OUR APPROACH WAS SHOWN EFFECTIVE TO REMOVE UNWANTED PLANTS AND DECREASE WEED GERMINATION. WORKING WITH INDUSTRY PARTNERS, THE NEW EQUIPMENT USING RUDCIP WILL BE COMBINED WITH ORGANIC PEST CONTROL AGENTS AND STATE-OF-THE-ART CONVOLUTIONAL NEURAL NETWORKS (CNNS) FOR AUTOMATED WEED AND CROP DISEASE CONTROL. THE NEW SYSTEM IS SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED TO BE COST-EFFECTIVE FOR SMALL FARMS. THERE IS NO EQUIVALENT ORGANIC SMALL FARM PRODUCT IN THE U.S. AVAILABLE TODAY. THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY FOR CSU TO FACILITATE AN IMPORTANT AGRICULTURE SYSTEM/TECHNOLOGY, EXPAND FACULTY AND STUDENT OPPORTUNITIES, AND PREPARE FOR EFFECTIVE INTRODUCTION THROUGH EXTENSION WITHIN AN EXISTING AND EXPANDING COHORT. IT WILL IMPACT STUDENT PREPARATION FOR CAREERS THAT INTERSECT ORGANIC FARMING, PRECISION AGRICULTURE, ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE, COMPUTER VISION AND MACHINE LEARNING.

HUMAN DECISIONS ABOUT THE MANAGEMENT OF WATER AS A RESOURCE HAVE SIGNIFICANT ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIETAL CONSEQUENCES. THE FLOW OF WATER BETWEEN HUMAN AND NATURAL SYSTEMS INVOLVES MANY COMPLEX AND INTER-RELATED PROCESSES, MANY OF WHICH ARE NOT FULLY UNDERSTOOD. AN EXAMPLE OF UNFORTUNATE CONSEQUENCES THAT CAN RESULT FROM POOR AND UNIFORMED MANAGEMENT OF WATER RESOURCES WAS THE DECISION BY OFFICIALS IN FLINT, MICHIGAN TO SWITCH THE SOURCE OF THEIR WATER SUPPLY FROM LAKE HURON TO THE FLINT RIVER. THIS ACTION CAUSED CORROSION OF PIPES IN THE DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM, RESULTING IN HIGH LEVELS OF LEAD IN THE PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY AND CREATED A CRISIS SITUATION FOR THE CITIZENS OF FLINT.EACH COMMUNITY HAS A UNIQUE COMBINATION OF CONDITIONS THAT AFFECT HOW IT'S NATURAL WATER RESOURCES AFFECT, AND ARE AFFECTED BY INTERACTIONS BETWEEN THE NATURAL AND HUMAN ENVIRONMENT. THE EMERGING, INTERDISCIPLINARY FIELD OF SOCIO-HYDROLOGY SEEKS TO UNDERSTAND THE DYNAMICS HUMAN-WATER INTERACTIONS AND FEEDBACKS. IN THIS INTEGRATED, COLLABORATIVE PROJECT, WE PROPOSE TO BUILD NEW CAPACITY AT FLORIDA A&M UNIVERSITY TO CONDUCT RESEARCH AND EDUCATION ON SOCIO-HYDROLOGY. THE PROJECT INVOLVES BOTH RESEARCH AND EXTENSION COMPONENTS. THE RESEARCH COMPONENT WILL USE THE CITY OF TALLAHASSEE AS A CASE STUDY SITE, AND WILL FOCUS ON DELINEATING THE INTERACTING PATHWAYS OF WATER AS IT TRAVELS BETWEEN HUMAN AND NATURAL SYSTEMS. INDICATORS OF HUMAN INPUTS TO NATURAL SYSTEMS WILL BE IDENTIFIED. INDICATORS INCLUDE THE PRESENCE OF CONTAMINANTS SUCH AS HEAVY METALS, NUTRIENTS, CONTAMINANTS OF EMERGING CONCERN AND MICROPLASTICS. A DEMOGRAPHIC ANALYSIS BE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE IF DISPARITIES EXIST IN TALLAHASSEE WITH RESPECT TO DRINKING WATER AND SURFACE WATER QUALITY. THE EXTENSION COMPONENT OF THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE DEVELOPMENT AND DELIVERY OF WATERSHED RELATED EDUCATIONAL/OUTREACH MATERIALS AND SCHOOL CURRICULUM MATERIALS, AND THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A CITIZEN SCIENCE WATERSHED RESEARCH LAB.THE KNOWLEDGE AND INSIGHTS GAINED FROM THIS STUDY WILL:BENEFIT THE CITIZENS OF TALLAHASSEE BY PROVIDING NEW KNOWLEDGE TO DECISION MAKERSBENEFIT CITIZENS OF TALLAHASSEE AND SURROUNDING REGIONS BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR CITIZENS TO PARTICIPATE DIRECTLY IN WATER RESOURCE RESEARCHBENEFIT THE FAMU CAMPUS COMMUNITY BY PROVIDING EXPERIENTIAL AND CLASSROOM OPPORTUNITIES TO STUDENTS, AND NEW RESEARCH AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES TO FACULTYCREATE AND GROW A NETWORK OF RESEARCHERS AND STAKEHOLDERS DEDICATED TO MAKING INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT THE USE OF WATER RESOURCESCONTRIBUTE TO THE KNOWLEDGE BASE IN SOCIO-HYDROLOGYPROVIDE RESULTS AND TECHNIQUES THAT WILL BE TRANSFERABLE TO COMMUNITIES WITH SIMILAR CHARACTERISTICS OF HYDROLOGIC SETTINGS, WATER RESOURCE NEEDS, AND DEMOGRAPHIC PROFILES

THE GLOBAL FOOD CRISIS TRIGGERED THE ELEVATION OF FOOD SECURITY AS A PRIORITY ISSUE ON THE INTERNATIONAL POLICY AGENDA. THE SITUATION ENFORCED AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITY TO CHANGE THEIR GLOBAL REGULATORY FRAMEWORK FOR FOOD IMPROVEMENT, RAISING TOPICS FOR MODERNIZATION OF BREEDING STRATEGIES. CURRENTLY, THE PREDOMINANT VINIFERA GRAPE FACES SEVERE PRESSURES FROM PATHOGENS AND A RAPIDLY-CHANGING ENVIRONMENT. THEREFORE, THE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF NATIONAL GRAPE INDUSTRY WILL DEPEND ON NEW GENETIC RESOURCES THAT CARRY APPROPRIATE ADAPTIVE TRAITS. MUSCADINE GERMPLASM HOLDS DISTINCTIVE HORTICULTURAL/PRODUCTIVE CHARACTERISTICS THAT CAN BE VITAL FOR GRAPE INDUSTRY SUSTAINABILITY. DESPITE THE RAPID EXPANSION IN MUSCADINE PRODUCTION, THE INDUSTRY FACES MAJOR DRAWBACKS THAT CAN COMPROMISE ALL GAINS ACHIEVED TOWARDS SUSTAINED GROWTH AND COMPETITIVENESS. THIS IS LARGELY DUE TO LACK OF GENOMIC INFORMATION AND SHORTAGE IN QUALIFIED WORKFORCE, IN WHICH BOTH ARE CRUCIAL FOR APPLYING RECENT TECHNOLOGIES. THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON DEVELOPING A DYNAMIC RESEARCH/TRAINING PROGRAM OF "GRAPE GENOMICS AND NEXT-GENERATION BREEDING" SERVING AS A CENTRALIZED RESEARCH UNIT AND STUDENT TRAINING PLATFORM THAT CAN SUSTAIN REGIONAL INDUSTRY AND BUILD HUMAN CAPACITY BY CONDUCTING RESEARCH TAILORED TO MATCH INDUSTRY NEEDS, AND IMPROVING TRAINING, EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AND LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT AT FAMU. IN THE COURSE OF THIS PROJECT, CO-FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS OF THE MUSCADINIA AND VITIS WGS ALONG WITH OTHER NGS-DERIVATIVE TECHNOLOGIES WILL BE APPLIED TO IDENTIFY CRITICAL GENETIC FACTORS COORDINATING STENOSPERMOCARPY FRUIT-SET PROGRAM. THE RESEARCH STRATEGY WILL UTILIZE INTEGRATED CUTTING-EDGE OMICS-TECHNOLOGIES AND COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY TO ACCELERATE THE ROUTINE DELIVERY OF INNOVATIVE VALUE-ADDED CULTIVARS, CARRYING DESIRABLE TRAITS CAPABLE OF OVERCOMING THE EXISTING AND FUTURE CHALLENGES IN VITICULTURE INDUSTRY.

IMPAIRED GUT HEALTH DUE TO INTERNAL PARASITISM AND BACTERIAL INFECTIONS ARE THE MAJOR HEALTH CHALLENGES THAT REDUCE PROFITABILITY OF SMALL RUMINANT PRODUCTION IN UNITED STATES AND WORLDWIDE. THE SITUATION IS CONFOUNDED BY RAPID DEVELOPMENT OF RESISTANCE TO ANTI-PARASITIC DRUGS COUPLED WITH CURRENT SCOURGE OF ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE TO MANY ANTIBIOTICS. CURRENTLY RESISTANCE TO ALL THE MAJOR CLASSES OF ANTHELMINTICDRUGS HAS BEEN REPORTED AND THERE IS ALSO A GLOBAL WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION (WHO) CALL FOR REDUCTION OF ANTIBIOTICS USE IN FARM ANIMALS. THERE IS THEREFORE AN URGENT CALL FOR RESEARCH TO EVALUATE AND VALIDATE EFFECTIVE ALTERNATIVE ANTIMICROBIAL AND ANTI-PARASITIC PRODUCTS. ADDITIONALLY, THERE IS AN INCREASING DEMAND BY CONSUMERS FOR ORGANIC AND NATURALLY RAISED PRODUCTS. AS POTENTIAL OPTIONS, THE GENERALLY REGARDED AS SAFE (GRAS) MICROORGANISMS OR PROBIOTICS HAVE SHOWN GREAT PROMISE WITH ANTIBACTERIAL AND ANTI-PARASITIC EFFECTS, IMPROVING PERFORMANCE AND FINAL PRODUCT QUALITY IN A NUMBEROF FARM ANIMALS. HOWEVER,A SIGNIFICANT GAP KNOWLEDGE EXISTS ON WHETHER SIMILAR BENEFITS ARE ACHIEVABLEIN SMALL RUMINANTS. THEREFORE THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE THE EFFECT OF EARLY ADMINISTRATION OF PROBIOTICS ON OVERALL HEALTH AND PERFORMANCE OF MEAT GOATS UNDER PASTURE. NEWBORN ANIMALS WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED ORALLY WITH DIFFERENT STRAINS OFPROBIOTICS AND THE EFFECT ONOVERALL HEALTH AND PERFORMANCE EVALUATED OVER THE GROWING PERIOD. ADDITIONALLY THE EFFECT OF PROBIOTIC SUPPLEMENTATION ON PRODUCT QUALITY AND SAFETY AT SLAUGHTER WILL BE EVALUATED.BY ESTABLISHING A HEALTHY GUT MICROBIOME AT BIRTH, PROBIOTIC STRAINS MAY HAVE POTENTIAL TO INHIBIT HARMFUL GUT BACTERIA AND PARASITES AND IMPROVE THE OVERALL HEALTH AND PERFOMANCE OF MEAT GOATS. THE PROJECT WILL EVALUATE AND DEVELOP SUSTAINABLE DISEASE AND PARASITE STRATEGIES THAT IMPROVE HEALTH,INCREASE MEAT GOAT PRODUCTION PROFITABILITY, ENSURE THE SAFETY AND QUALITY OF THE GOAT MEAT THAT CAN READILY BE APPLIED BY PRODUCERS.

THE QUALITY OF WATER AVAILABLE FOR DRINKING CAN HAVE MARKED IMPACT ON THE LEVEL AND EFFICIENCY OF LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION. RUMINANTS FREQUENTLY CONSUME WATER MODERATE TO HIGH IN TOTAL DISSOLVED SALTS (TDS), TERMED AS SALINE. BECAUSE OF THE EXPECTED INCREASING IMPORTANCE OF HIGH-TDS DRINKING WATER IN THE FUTURE, IT IS IMPERATIVE TO GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF FACTORS AFFECTING THE UTILIZATION OF BRACKISH/SALINE WATER BY RUMINANT LIVESTOCK SPECIES SO THAT MOST APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES CAN BE IDENTIFIED AND ADOPTED. EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE RESPONSES OF GOATS, SHEEP, AND CATTLE TO DIFFERENT LEVELS OF TDS IN DRINKING WATER AS VARIED BY WATER SOURCE AND NACL ADDITIONS; IDENTIFY FACTORS AFFECTED BY DRINKING WATER HIGH IN TDS THAT MAY AFFECT PERFORMANCE OF RUMINANT LIVESTOCK, SUCH AS CHANGE IN FEED INTAKE, RUMINAL CONDITIONS, DIGESTION, BLOOD CONSTITUENT LEVELS, AND(OR) ENERGY METABOLISM; AND DETERMINE WATER INTAKE BY AND REQUIREMENTS OF GOATS, SHEEP, AND CATTLE AND HOW THEY VARY WITH WATER TDS CHARACTERISTICS. INFORMATION WILL BE DISSEMINATED THROUGH PRESENTATIONS AT SCIENTIFIC SOCIETY MEETINGS, PEER-REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL ARTICLES, UNDERGRADUATE ABSTRACT PRESENTATIONS, EXTENSION WEBSITES AND MEDIA, AND EXTENSION.

THE USDA-NIFA'S INNOVATIVE RESEARCH SUPPORT TO 1890 INSTITUTIONS HAS FUELED NUMEROUS AGRICULTURAL ADVANCEMENTS THAT HAVE ENHANCED THEIR INFRASTRUCTURES. THESE SUSTAINABLE INTEGRATIVE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES DROVE RESEARCH EFFORTS TOWARDS PRODUCTIONS RESULTING IN HIGHER YIELD AND DISEASE RESILIENCE. CURRENTLY, OF SPECIFIC INTEREST TO PRODUCERS, SMALL-SCALE FARMERS AND STAKEHOLDERS ARE ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY CROP PROPAGATION METHODS. HENCE, LEVERAGING NEW AND EXISTING TECHNOLOGIES TO INFLUENCE BIOLOGICAL PROCESSES IN INCREASING PLANT BREEDING EFFICACY IS KEY TO ADDRESSING THESE INTERESTS. PLANTS EXPOSED TO MAGNETIC FIELDS HAVE SHOWN A VARIETY OF GROWTH RESPONSES. ALTHOUGH MAGNETIC FIELD EXPOSURE EFFECTS TO STIMULATE GROWTH ARE WELL-DOCUMENTED, THE IMPACT OF MAGNETIC FIELD EXPOSURE EFFECTS IN PLANTS IS NOT WELL-UNDERSTOOD. THUS, A COMPREHENSIVE UNDERSTANDING OF BIOMAGNETIC RESPONSES IN PLANTS NECESSITATES NEW IN-DEPTH APPROACHES. OUR PRELIMINARY MAGNETIC FIELD EXPOSURE STUDIES RESULTED IN INCREASED BIOMASS PRODUCTION IN DIFFERENT PLANT SPECIES THUS SERVING AS A PLATFORM FOR OUR PROPOSED RESEARCH. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) SCREEN CANDIDATE PLANT GROWTH RESPONSES BASED ON OVERALL BIOMASS PRODUCTION AND SELECTED PHYSIOLOGICAL GROWTH PARAMETERS; 2) IDENTIFY THE EFFECTS OF MAGNETIC FIELDS IN PLANTS BY TRANSCRIPTOME AND METABOLIC PROFILING AND CHARACTERIZE HOST RESPONSES TO PATHOGENS IN EXPOSED PLANTS; 3) ANALYZE THE IMPACT OF A SIMULATED MARS' MAGNETIC FIELD ON GERMINATION AND PLANT GROWTH. THE PROPOSED STUDY HAS THE POTENTIAL TO 1) CONTRIBUTE TO FUNDAMENTAL UNDERSTANDING OF MAGNETIC FIELD EFFECTS ON CROP DEVELOPMENT; 2) PROVIDE STAKEHOLDERS AND CROP PRODUCERS WITH A VIABLE, SAFER OPTION FOR ENHANCING PLANT BREEDING EFFICACY; 3) PROVIDE STUDENT EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING IN FANH WITH HOPES OF PRODUCING HIGHLY-SKILLED AGRICULTURAL WORKERS; 4) CREATE NEW INSIGHT IN ON THE EFFECTS OF EXTRAPLANETARY MAGNETIC FIELDS ON PLANT BREEDING AS WE CONTINUE TO EXPLORE SPACE TRAVEL; 4)IMPROVE THE EXISTING RESEARCH INFRASTRUCTURE AT A HISTORIC 1890 RESEARCH AND TEACHING INSTITUTION.

THE ENERGY INDEPENDENCE AND SECURITY ACT OF 2007 (EISA) REQUIRES AN AGGRESSIVE SCALE-UP OF CELLULOSIC BIOFUELS AS PART OF THE RENEWABLE FUEL STANDARD (RFS) PROGRAM, WITH A PRODUCTION TARGET OF 39.7 BILLION L YR-1 (10.5 BILLION GAL YR-1) BY 2020. HOWEVER, CELLULOSIC BIOFUEL PRODUCTION IS CURRENTLY LESS THAN 10% OF THE 2016 GOAL SET BY EISA. THIS PRODUCTION GAP IS PRIMARILY DUE TO THE COST OF CONVERSION TECHNOLOGIES CURRENTLY BEING COMMERCIALIZED. TWO SPECIFIC BARRIERS ARE THE PROHIBITIVE COSTS OF CELL WALL DEGRADING ENZYMES AND OF BIOMASS PRETREATMENT, BOTH REQUIRED BY EXISTING TECHNOLOGIES AND FEEDSTOCKS. A MAJOR STRATEGIC GOAL IN MAKING COST-COMPETITIVE AND SUSTAINABLE FUELS AND CHEMICALS FROM LIGNOCELLULOSIC BIOMASS IS TO REDUCE THE COST OF CELLULOLYTIC ENZYMES AND BIOMASS PRE-TREATMENT WHICH IN TURN HAS LIMITED COMMERCIALIZATION OF BIOMASS FUELS AND CHEMICALS. ONE WAY TO SUBSTANTIALLY REDUCE THESE PRODUCTION COSTS IS TO CO-EXPRESS LIGNOLYTIC AND CELLULOLYTIC ENZYMES IN TRANSGENIC DEDICATED BIO-ENERGY CROPS AT LEVELS THAT ARE HIGH ENOUGH TO SIMULTANEOUSLY DECONSTRUCT AND HYDROLYZE LIGNOCELLULOSIC BIOMASS. BRACHYPODIUM DISTACHYON (BRACHYPODIUM), A MODEL SYSTEM FOR GRASS RESEARCH WILL BE USED TO TEST OUR MULTIPLE GENE TECHNOLOGY. METABOLIC ENGINEERING OF BRACHYPODIUM TO EXPRESS HYPERTHERMOPHILIC CELLULOSE AND LIGNIN-HYDROLYZING ENZYMES REQUIRED FOR BIOMASS DECONSTRUCTION TO FERMENTABLE SUGARS COULD REDUCE OR ELIMINATE THE NEED TO PRE-TREAT THE BIOMASS AND ADD MICROBIAL CELLULOTIC ENZYMES DURING BIOMASS CONVERSION. THE AIMS OF THIS PROJECT ARE: 1) TO DESIGN AND CONSTRUCT CONSTITUTIVE SINGLE AND MULTI-GENE EXPRESSION CASSETTES WITH CODON-OPTIMIZED, ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM TARGETED HEAT OR MANGANESE INDUCIBLE GENES FOR DEGRADATION OF CELLULOSE AND LIGNIN ; 2) TO TRANSFORM BRACHYPODIUM PLANTS WITH THESE CASSETTES, RECOVER, AND EVALUATE TRANSGENIC TISSUES, AND PLANTS FOR CELLULOSE, LACCASE OR LIGNIN PEROXIDASE EXPRESSION AND CORRESPONDING ENZYMATIC SPECIFIC ACTIVITY; 4) TO COMPARE THE CELLULOSE AND LIGNIN COMPOSITION OF BIOMASS OF PARENTAL AND TRANSFORMED LINES; 5) TO EVALUATE THE SACCHARIFICATION, AUTO-HYDROLYSIS, MICROPYROLYSIS OF THE ENGINEERED BIOMASS AS WELL AS EVALUATE THE FERMENTABILITY OF THE SACCHARIFIED SAMPLES. 6) DEVELOP AN EFFICIENT AGROBACTERIUM TRANSFORMATION SYSTEM FOR MISCANTHUS X GIGANTEUS; 7) TO TRAIN A NEW GENERATION OF MINORITY STUDENTS IN ADVANCED BIOFUEL RESEARCH, MOLECULAR BIOTECHNOLOGY; 8) TO INCREASE CAPACITIES FOR BIOTECHNOLOGY AND BIO-ENERGY RESEARCH AT DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY. DEPENDING ON THE OUTCOME OF THIS FEASIBILITY PHASE, FUTURE WORK WILL INCLUDE INCREASING THE ACTIVITY OF THESE ENZYMES IN BRACHYPODIUM THROUGH ENZYME EVOLUTION, CHARACTERIZING THE BEST TRANSGENIC LINES FOR BIOFUEL PRODUCTION AND EVALUATE THEIR FIELD PERFORMANCE. THIS APPROACH WILL BE TRANSFERRED TO MISCANTHUS X GIGANTEUS, A HIGH BIOMASS-YIELDING ENERGY GRASS AS A STRATEGY TO DEVELOP NOVEL GRASS WITH ENHANCED BIOPROCESSING CHARACTERISTICS ONCE VALIDATED IN MODEL BRACHYPODIUM.

TUSKEGEE UNIVERSITY, DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY AND UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND EASTERN SHORES PARTNERED TOGETHER WITH EARTH UNIVERSITY AND TROPICAL AGRICULTURE RESEARCH AND HIGHER EDUCATION CENTER IN COSTA RICA TO DEVELOP AND ENGAGE STUDENTS AND FACULTY IN STUDY ABROAD FOR EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING PROGRAM. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES VALUABLE OPPORTUNITY TO STRENGTHEN CAPACITIES AND CAPABILITIES TO BROADEN AND STRENGTHEN STUDENT TRAINING IN FOOD SYSTEM AND ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT AIMED AT PRODUCING SOCIETY READY, AND GLOBALLY COMPETENT, COMPETITIVE GRADUATES. THE FOUR WEEK STUDY ABROAD PROGRAM WILL ORIENT STUDENTS TO INTERDISCIPLINARY, PARTICIPATORY RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ON TROPICAL FOOD SYSTEMS AND INCREASE AWARENESS OF CENTRAL AMERICAN CULTURE. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) BUILD EDUCATIONAL, RESEARCH, AND EXTENSION PARTNERSHIPS WITH COSTA RICAN PARTNER INSTITUTIONS TO ENHANCE STUDENTS' GLOBAL COMPETENCE AND PROFESSIONAL OPPORTUNITIES; 2) DEVELOP AN INTERNATIONAL ENRICHMENT SCHOLAR EXCHANGE AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING PROGRAMS FOR OUR STUDENTS AND FACULTY; 3) COMPARE THE AGRICULTURAL, AND CULTURAL VALUES OF COSTA RICA WITH THOSE OF THE UNITED STATES, WHILE EXPOSING STUDENTS TO THE IMPLICATIONS OF FOOD, AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES IN CENTRAL AMERICA; 4) LINK THE STUDY ABROAD PROGRAM TO JOINT TEACHING AND RESEARCH INITIATIVES IN THE US AND COSTA RICA PARTNER INSTITUTIONS; 5) USE THESE PARTNERSHIPS TO BUILD STRONGER PIPELINES FOR MINORITY STUDENT RECRUITMENT INTO VARIOUS PROGRAMS. THE STUDENTS WHO PARTICIPATE IN THE PROGRAM WILL UNDERSTAND ABOUT THE CRITICAL NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL ISSUES PARTICULARLY, NIFA'S STRATEGIC GOALS OF GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY AND HUNGER, FOOD SAFETY, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, CONSERVATION, CLIMATE CHANGE EDUCATION, BIOENERGY, AND SUSTAINABLE RURAL ECONOMIES

THERE ARE INDICATIONS THAT THE AGRICULTURAL RELATED DISCIPLINES ARE NOT PRODUCING ENOUGH 'QUALIFIED' GRADUATES SUFFICIENT TO FILL THE NEEDED POSITIONS IN THE INDUSTRY AND GOVERNMENT, AND FOOD SCIENCE IS NO EXCEPTION. THEREFORE, THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP THE NEWLY LAUNCHED FOOD SAFETY AND PROCESSING CONCENTRATION'S CAPACITY BY INTEGRATING THE APPLICATION OF NANOTECHNOLOGY IN ACTIVE AND INTELLIGENT PACKAGING TO FACILITATE THE TRAINING OF UNDERREPRESENTED MINORITY STUDENTS. THE PROJECT WAS CONCEPTUALIZED BASED ON THE NOTION THAT TEACHING AND RESEARCH ARE MUTUALLY COMPLEMENTARY HENCE INTEGRATED TO REINFORCE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING WITH THE STATE-OF-THE-ART SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTATION BEING REQUESTED. THIS WILL FACILITATE THE RECRUITMENT OF HIGH QUALITY STUDENT IN THE FOOD SCIENCE PROGRAM. FACULTY PREPARATION IN THE APPLICATION OF ACTIVE AND INTELLIGENT PACKAGING WILL ENHANCE THE STUDY OF CONTROLLED RELEASE OF ANTIMICROBIALS PACKAGING OF REFRIGERATED MEAT. THIS WILL PROVIDE A BODY OF KNOWLEDGE TO ENABLE CURRICULAR DEVELOPMENT AND ENHANCEMENT RELATED COURSES. THIS IS PARTICULARLY SIGNIFICANT IN IMPROVING THE QUALITY OF EDUCATIONAL DELIVERANCE THUS WITH ANTICIPATED CURRICULAR TRANSFORMATION IN AGRICULTURAL AND AGRICULTURAL RELATED EDUCATIONS IN TUNE WITH THE RAPID ADVANCES IN SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY. BUILDING CAPACITY FOR SUSTAINABLE TRAINING OF MINORITY STUDENTS IN LEADERSHIP SKILL DEVELOPMENT AND THE CUTTING EDGE TECHNOLOGIES WILL PROVIDE ANTICIPATED LONG TERM IMPACT ON 20 FRESHMEN, 20 HIGH SCHOOL INTERNS IN SUMMER WORKSHOPS, 150 AND 50 REGULAR UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS, RESPECTIVELY, ENROLLED IN RELATED FOOD SCIENCE COURSES. THIS PROJECT WILL AID IN ACHIEVING USDA-NIFA SIX STRATEGIC GOALS AND OBJECTIVES IN THE AREA OF HUMAN CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT.

THE DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES WILL CREATE A NEW M.S. IN FCS WITH A FOCUS ON SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP. THIS PROGRAM WILL BE IMPORTANT FOR THE INSTITUTION, ALLOWING FOR A PROGRAM EXTENSION, ENROLLMENT GROWTH, IMPROVEMENTS IN A TEACHING CAPACITY, AND A GREATER CONNECTION WITH COMMUNITY AND INDUSTRY PARTNERSHIPS.THE M.S. IN FCS WILL CREATE GRADUATE OPPORTUNITIES IN AREAS NOT CURRENTLY AVAILABLE IN THE DEPARTMENT IN PROGRAM AREAS OF CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES, FASHION MANAGEMENT AND ENTREPRENEURSHIP, AND HOUSING. THE PROGRAM WILL BE INNOVATIVE ACROSS THE UNC SYSTEM AND OTHER 1890 INSTITUTIONS, DUE PRIMARILY TO THE FOCUS ON SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP, AND WILL ALLOW THE INSTITUTION TO GROW ENROLLMENT FROM SOURCES PREVIOUSLY UNTAPPED.THE M.S. IN FCS WILL CREATE ENDURING IMPROVEMENTS IN A TEACHING CAPACITY AT NC A&T THROUGH THE DESIGN AND DELIVERY OF CURRICULA AND THE ESTABLISHMENT OF PARTNERSHIPS FOR RESEARCH, OUTREACH, AND STUDENT RECRUITMENT. CURRICULA WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH PRACTICAL DISCIPLINARY SKILLS AND SKILLS IN SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP. PARTNERS WILL WORK WITH THE DEPARTMENT TO OFFER RESEARCH MENTORSHIP, EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, COURSE ENHANCEMENT AND DELIVERY, STUDENT RECRUITMENT, AND PROGRAM FEEDBACK.THE SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP FOCUS IS AN IMPORTANT PART OF THE DESIGN OF THE M.S. IN FCS AND IS AN IDEAL FIT FOR THE DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES AT NC A&T. THE FCS DISCIPLINE WAS FOUNDED ON THE PREMISE THAT IMPROVEMENTS IN INDIVIDUAL QUALITY OF LIFE WILL POSITIVELY IMPACT THE FAMILY, HOME, AND BROADER SOCIETY. LEADERS IN FCS MAKE CONTRIBUTIONS TO SOCIAL REFORM AND BUSINESS THROUGH THE APPLICATION OF THEIR RESEARCH-BASED EXPERTISE AND ALREADY OFFER MUCH TO THE SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP DISCOURSE. IN ADDITION, THE UNIVERSITY, AS THE LARGEST HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGE AND UNIVERSITY (HBCU), WAS FOUNDED TO ENSURE EQUAL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR A HISTORICALLY UNDERREPRESENTED, DISADVANTAGED SEGMENT OF THE POPULATION. AS A MINORITY-SERVING INSTITUTION, NC A&T IS ALMOST DESTINED TO OFFER PROGRAMS THAT FEATURE CONCEPTS OF SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP.STUDENTS WHO GRADUATE FROM THE M.S. IN FCS WILL HAVE ADVANCED RESEARCH SKILLS THAT ALLOW THEM TO RECOGNIZE AND CAPITALIZE ON OPPORTUNITIES THAT CAN HAVE THE GREATEST IMPACT ON THE PEOPLE AROUND THEM. SKILLS OBTAINED IN THE PROGRAM WILL IMPROVE CAREER POTENTIAL FOR STUDENTS AND WILL EXTEND THE IMPACT OF THE PROGRAM OFF CAMPUS.

SAFFRON (CROCUS SATIVUS L.) IS THE MOST EXPENSIVE SPICE AND HAS POTENTIAL HEALTH BENEFITS. CURRENTLY, SAFFRON PRODUCTION IS CONCENTRATED IN MEDITERRANEAN COUNTRIES. ADULTERATION OF THE IMPORTED MATERIAL IS A SERIOUS ONGOING PROBLEM; THUS, DOMESTIC CULTIVATION SHOULD BE SERIOUSLY CONSIDERED. A SURVEY WAS CONDUCTED AT THE 2017 SMALL AND LIMITED-RESOURCE FARMERS CONFERENCE AT KENTUCKY STATE UNIVERSITY (KSU) AND 68% OF RESPONDENTS EXPRESSED INTEREST IN SAFFRON CULTIVATION AND WANTED TO KNOW MORE ABOUT THE SPICE. A SOIL SURVEY SUGGESTED SAFFRON CAN BE SUCCESSFULLY AND SUSTAINABLY CULTIVATED IN MANY PARTS OF KENTUCKY. THESE FINDINGS DEMONSTRATE THE NEED FOR AN INVESTIGATION ABOUT SAFFRON CULTIVATION. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROPOSED STUDIES ARE TO:1) INVESTIGATE PRODUCTION OF HIGH QUALITY SAFFRON, BY UTILIZING FIELD, HIGH TUNNEL, SHED, AND GREEN ROOF PRODUCTION SYSTEMS; 2) INCORPORATE BACILLUS SUBTILIS FZB24TO PROMOTE SAFFRON GROWTH; 3) MEASURE PHYSICAL STRESS IN AGRICULTURAL WORKERS ASSOCIATED WITH PLANTING AND HARVESTING SAFFRON; 4) INVESTIGATE THE ANTI-INFLAMMATORY PROPERTIES OF SAFFRON BY EVALUATING SUPPRESSION OF CCL26 (A BIOMARKER FOR ALLERGIC ASTHMA) SECRETION; 5) INVESTIGATE THE CAPACITY OF SAFFRON TO AID DIGESTION; 6) DEVELOP PRODUCTION COST ESTIMATES AND ENGAGE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO MARKET SAFFRON; AND 7) RECRUIT SMALL-SCALE AND LIMITED-RESOURCE FARMERS AND PROMOTE SAFFRON USES THROUGH EXTENSION ACTIVITIES, WEBPAGES, AND SOCIAL NETWORKING. THE MAIN MEASURABLE OUTCOMES EXPECTED FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: RECOMMENDATIONS FOR SAFFRON CULTIVATION IN KY, THE DEMONSTRATION THAT DOMESTICALLY CULTIVATED SAFFRON CAN ACHIEVE QUALITY AND BIOACTIVITY COMPARABLE TO IMPORTED SAFFRON, THE NUMBER OF PARTICIPATING FARMERS AND STUDENTS, PRODUCTION COST ESTIMATES, AND MARKETING STRATEGIES.

CLEAN, ACCESSIBLE FRESHWATER DEPENDS ON WATERSHEDS THAT ARE INCREASINGLY THREATENED BY MUNICIPAL AND INDUSTRIAL ACTIVITIES. THE MANAGEMENT OF RIVERS REQUIRES THE ABILITY TO FORECAST ECOSYSTEM RESILIENCE FOLLOWING ENVIRONMENTAL DISTURBANCES. THE PRIMARY MECHANISM FOR MAINTAINING WATER QUALITY IN THESE ENVIRONMENTS IS THE MICROORGANISMS THAT LIVE IN SEDIMENTS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO BUILD BOTH RESEARCH AND TEACHING CAPACITY WITH REGARD TO FRESHWATER AND MOLECULAR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE AT WVSU. THE RESEARCH COMPONENT WILL MEASURE MICROBIAL ECOSYSTEM PROCESSES (CARBON AND NITROGEN CYCLING) IN RIVER SEDIMENTS THAT HAVE BEEN IMPACTED BY ENVIRONMENTAL STRESS, INCLUDING ORGANIC POLLUTANTS AND ACID MINE DRAINAGE. THE BIOREMEDIATION OF COMMON ORGANIC POLLUTANTS (SUCH AS POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC HYDROCARBONS) WILL BE TESTED IN DIVERSE RIVER SEDIMENTS AS WELL. MICROBIAL PROCESSES WILL BE STUDIED USING A COMBINATION OF GENE-BASED METHODS (GENOMICS) AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY. THE TEACHING COMPONENT OF THE GRANT WILL CREATE A NEW CLASS CALLED INTEGRATED MOLECULAR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE AS WELL AS WORKSHOPS FOR UNIVERSITY AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS. THE GRANT WILL PURCHASE A MASS SPECTROMETER TO MEASURE ORGANIC POLLUTANTS AND AS A MICROSENSOR SYSTEM TO MEASURE CHEMICAL GRADIENTS. THE FOCUS OF THE STUDY WILL BE THE KANAWHA RIVER WATERSHED, WEST VIRGINIA, WHICH HAS BEEN IMPACTED BY A VARIETY OF SEVERE MUNICIPAL AND INDUSTRIAL PROCESSES FOR MANY YEARS. THE PROJECT CREATES A UNIQUE CONJUNCTION OF FRESHWATER SCIENCE, ENVIRONMENTAL CHEMISTRY, MICROBIAL ECOLOGY, GENOMICS AND BIOINFORMATICS THAT WILL ADVANCE THE RESEARCH AND EDUCATION CAPACITY OF WVSU AND WEST VIRGINIA.

COMBINING GENOMIC RESOURCES WITH SPEED BREEDING WILL HELP ADVANCE BREEDING CYCLES IN PEPPERS, THUS FURTHER ACCELERATING THE INTROGRESSION PROCESS. IN A BREEDING CONTEXT, RAPID GENERATION ADVANCE TO HOMOZYGOSITY AFTER CROSSING WILL FACILITATE GENETIC GAINS FOR KEY TRAITS AND ALLOW FOR MORE RAPID PRODUCTION OF IMPROVED CULTIVARS BY BREEDING PROGRAMS. FRUIT WEIGHT, SHAPE AND COLOR ARE MAJOR TRAITS THAT DETERMINE THE YIELD AND QUALITY OF THE PEPPER FRUIT. FRUIT WEIGHT AND SHAPE ARE QUANTITATIVELY INHERITED TRAITS WITH LARGE NATURAL VARIATION IN CAPSICUM. HOWEVER, MOST STUDIES HAVE USED LOW-RESOLUTION MAPPING POPULATIONS OR LACKED FUNCTIONAL TESTS TO PROVE THE EFFECT OF POTENTIAL CANDIDATE GENES AND THEREFORE WERE NOT ABLE TO IDENTIFY THE UNDERLYING GENES. BY COMBING HIGH-RESOLUTION MAPPING, ENRICHMENT OF MARKERS IN THE QTL REGIONS USING NEXT-GENERATION SEQUENCING (NGS) TECHNOLOGIES AND THE IDENTIFICATION OF DIFFERENTIALLY EXPRESSED GENES BY TRANSCRIPTOME ANALYSIS, WE WILL IDENTIFY A SET OF CANDIDATE GENES FOR THE FRUIT SHAPE.

TECHNOLOGY HAS RAPIDLY TRANSFORMED THE TECHNICAL SOPHISTICATION OF THE FASHION INDUSTRY. NORTH CAROLINA A&T'S (N.C. A&T) FASHION MERCHANDISING AND DESIGN (FMD) PROGRAM CURRENTLY LACKS THE INDUSTRY STANDARD TECHNOLOGY AND RESOURCES NECESSARY FOR FACULTY TO ADEQUATELY PREPARE ITS STUDENTS FOR POSITIONS REQUIRING TECHNICAL SKILLS INCLUDING COMPUTERIZED PATTERN MAKING, TEXTILE DESIGN, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF ELECTRONIC GARMENT SPECIFICATION PACKETS AND VIRTUAL FLOOR PLANS. THESE TYPES OF SPECIALIZED SKILLS ARE REQUIRED AND IN DEMAND FOR ENTRY LEVEL EMPLOYMENT IN THE FASHION INDUSTRY. PREPARING FMD STUDENTS FOR THE MODERN JOB MARKET REQUIRES MEETING THE INDUSTRY'S EMPLOYMENT DEMANDS FOR GRADUATES WITH HIGH LEVEL TECHNICAL SKILLS. THE GOAL OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO BUILD CAPACITY TO IMPROVE STUDENT CAREER PREPAREDNESS AND STRENGTHEN THE FMD PROGRAM BY ENHANCING THE CURRICULUM AND TEACHING LABORATORIES.THE REQUESTED SOFTWARE AND ENHANCED CURRICULUM WILL CREATE PROGRAM CAPACITY TO MORE READILY AND EFFECTIVELY ALLOW N.C. A&T TO: 1.) COMPETE WITH HIGH PRODUCING IN-STATE AND NATIONAL FOUR YEAR INSTITUTIONS WITH STRONG APPAREL AND TEXTILE PROGRAMS, 2.) YIELD STUDENTS WELL PREPARED TO MEET INDUSTRY NEEDS, AND 3.) GARNER INCREASED CAPACITY TO ADDRESS THE CHALLENGES THAT AN EVER CHANGING INDUSTRY NEEDS TO ADDRESS.

THIS IS A STANDARDINTEGRATED (RESEARCH AND EXTENSION)PROJECT FOR THE 1890 CBG PROGRAM. A MAJOR CONCERN OF NURSERY PRODUCERS IS TIMELY AND EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OFDISEASES AND ABIOTIC STRESSES. ANOTHER CONCERN IS THE AVAILABILITY AND ESCALATING COSTS OF LABOR.THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TODESIGN, OPTIMIZE AND IMPLEMENT AN UNMANNED AIRCRAFT SYSTEM (UAS) THAT CAN OPERATE IN NURSERY SYSTEMS TO IMPROVETHE PRODUCTION AND PROFITABILITY OF NURSERY CROPS BY 1) EARLY DETECTION OF FOLIAR DISEASES AND ABIOTIC STRESSES, AND 2) REDUCE THE COST OF LABOR FOR DETERMINATION OF INDIVIDUAL TREE CRITERIA FOR SALE. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROPOSAL ARE: 1) DESIGN/BUILD AN UAS TO OPERATE WITHIN A NURSERY PRODUCTION ENVIRONMENT, 2) EVALUATE THE UASFOR EARLY DETECTION AND IDENTIFICATION OF FOLIAR DISEASES, DETERMINATION OF ABIOTIC STRESS FACTORS, AND PLANT GROWTH MEASUREMENTS, 3)ASSESS THE ECONOMIC IMPACT OF THESE TECHNOLOGIES ON NURSERY PRODUCTION COSTS AND PROFITABILITY,AND 4)TECHNOLOGY AND INFORMATION TRANSFER TO PRACTITIONERS.THIS PROJECTWILL RESULT IN AN UAS TO IMPROVE NURSERY PRODUCTION,WITH THE CAPABILITY TO MOVE ABOVE THE PLANT CANOPY, BETWEEN ROWS OF PLANTS, AND HOVER DIRECTLY BESIDE A PLANT TO COLLECTFOLIAR DISEASE, ABIOTIC STRESSAND PLANT MEASUREMENT DATAWITHIN A NURSERY PRODUCTION ENVIRONMENT. PRACTITIONERS AND STUDENTS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE AS WELL AS KNOWLEDGE OF UAS USES FOR NURSERY PRODUCTION. THE UTILIZATION OF THE UAS AND INFORMATION DELIVERY THROUGH EXTENSION PRODUCTS WILL INCREASE THE LIKELIHOOD OF ADOPTION BY NURSERY PRODUCERS AND SERVICE PROVIDERS BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR SMALL BUSINESS.

ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANT (AMR) MICROORGANISMS ARE A GLOBAL THREAT TO PUBLIC HEALTH. CONSUMER EXPOSURE TO ANTIBIOTICS IS COMMON IN THE UNITED STATES, BUT THEY HAVE NEGATIVE SIDE-EFFECTS, LIMITING THEIR HEALTHCARE APPLICATIONS. FOODS ARE BELIEVED TO SERVE AS VECTORS IN THE TRANSMISSION OF AMR TO CONSUMERS.FISHERY PRODUCTS ARE ESPECIALLY SUSPECT IN THIS RESPECT, AS CERTAIN DISEASE-CAUSING SPOILAGEBACTERIA SUCH AS AEROMONAS SPP. OR PSEUDOMONAS SPP. ARE KNOWN TO RESIDE ON AQUACULTURE PRODUCTS AND HARBOR STRONG POTENTIAL FOR AMR GENE TRANSMISSION AMONG CONSUMER GUT FLORA. PHAGE THERAPY IS AN EMERGING PRACTICE THAT SERVES AS A SAFER ALTERNATIVE-BACTERICIDE THAN ANTIBIOTICS.HERE, WE PROPOSE A MULTIDISCIPLINARY, COLLABORATIVE STRATEGY TO ISOLATE AND IDENTIFY NATURALLY OCCURRING BACTERIOPHAGES FROM AQUACULTURE WATER WHICH CAN BE COMBINED AND APPLIED TO FISHERY PRODUCTS AS AMR INHIBITION-AGENTS AND EXTENDERS OF SHELF-LIFE.THROUGH THE PROGRAM FOR HANDS-ON ALTERNATIVE GERMICIDE EDUCATION (PHAGE), WE WILL: 1) EXPLORE THE METAGENOMIC STUDY AND ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE GENES BY NEXT-GENERATION DNA SEQUENCING TECHNIQUES; 2) ISOLATE BACTERIOPHAGES THAT INFECT MULTIDRUG RESISTANT BACTERIAL STRAINS; 3) DEVELOP A PHAGE TREATMENT FOR APPLICATION DURING CATFISH PROCESSING; 4) ESTABLISH A FOODGENOMICS LAB; 5) DEVELOP SUMMER PROGRAMSASSOCIATED WITH PHAGE RESEARCH; AND 6) BUILD AN INTERDISCIPLINARY COLLABORATION THROUGH RESEARCH AND EXTENSION SERVICES TO DISSEMINATE THE OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT.AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, STUDENT ENROLLMENT AND RETENTION RATES AT DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY WILL INCREASE WHEN STUDENTS DIRECTLY ENGAGE WITH MODERNGENOMICS RESEARCH AND EXPAND THEIR CAREER OPPORTUNITIES IN THE FOOD INDUSTRY.

INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT (IPM) OF ARTHROPOD PESTS IS A HOLISTIC APPROACH TO SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE THAT FOCUSES ON MANAGING PESTS THROUGH A COMBINATION OF CULTURAL, PHYSICAL, BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL METHODS. IPM IS A CROP PROTECTION PRACTICE THAT IS COST EFFECTIVE, ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND AND SOCIALLY ACCEPTABLE. IT IS THE MOST IMPORTANT STRATEGY FOR MANAGING PESTS IN AGRICULTURAL CROPPING SYSTEMS; YET, TENNESSEE STAKEHOLDERS (I.E. GROWERS, SMALL FARMERS, COMMUNITY AND BACKYARD GARDENERS) ARE STILL LAGGING BEHIND IN ADOPTING AND IMPLEMENTING IPM FOR CROP PROTECTION. ALTHOUGH, BIOLOGICAL CONTROL (USE OF NATURAL ENEMIES OF THE PESTS) IS A KEY COMPONENT OF IPM, TENNESSEE HAS NOT EFFICIENTLY UTILIZED NATURAL ENEMIES TO MANAGE ARTHROPOD PESTS. SERVICES PROVIDED BY NATURAL ENEMIES CAN LOWER CROP MANAGEMENT COSTS BY REDUCING CROP LOSS AND THE NUMBER OF PESTICIDE APPLICATIONS NEEDED TO CONTROL PEST POPULATIONS. VARIOUS NATURAL ENEMIES EXIST IN CROP ENVIRONMENTS AND ADJACENT AREAS, AND A REDUCTION IN PESTICIDE USE HELPS THESE NATURAL ENEMIES TO SURVIVE AND SUPPRESS PEST OUTBREAKS AND RESURGENCES. HENCE, THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE AND PROMOTE IPM BY EDUCATION AND TRAINING STAKEHOLDERS TO INCREASE ITS USE IN TENNESSEE. WE PURSUE THIS GOAL VIA THE FOLLOWING SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES, (1) IDENTIFY STAKEHOLDER NEEDS AND ISSUES ON IPM AND BIOLOGICAL CONTROL OF ARTHROPOD PESTS THROUGH STATE-WIDE SURVEYS (2) EDUCATE AND TRAIN STAKEHOLDERS ON IPM (3) PROVIDE UP-TO-DATE AND NEW INFORMATION ON IPM TO STAKEHOLDERS. WITH EXPANDING ITS COUNTY INFRASTRUCTURE AND ACTIVE LEADERSHIP IN TENNESSEE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM, TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY IS UNIQUELY POSITIONED TO HOST THIS PROJECT.

THE GENERAL GOAL OF THIS PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE THE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, IMPROVE INSTRUCTIONAL DELIVERY SYSTEMS, AND INCREASE RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION OF STUDENTS IN ANIMAL SCIENCE THROUGH ESTABLISHMENT OF A LARGE ANIMAL TEACHING CENTER AT LANGSTON UNIVERSITY. SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO START A ANIMAL TEACHING CENTER OF BEEF CATTLE; TO PROVIDE MUCH NEEDED LARGE ANIMAL RECOURSES TO FACULTY AND STUDENTS IN ANIMAL SCIENCE TEACHING AND TRAINING; TO ENHANCE STUDENTS' INTEREST AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING IN ANIMAL SCIENCE; AND TO ULTIMATELY ENHANCE THE COMPETITIVENESS AND QUALITY OF ANIMAL SCIENCE STUDENTS FOR THE FUTURE ANIMAL INDUSTRY IN OKLAHOMA AND BEYOND. THIS THREE-YEAR PROJECT WILL FILL THE VOID OF LARGE ANIMALS AND COMPLEMENT OUR ALREADY RENOWNED SMALL RUMINANT PROGRAMS FOR ALL ANIMAL SCIENCE CLASSES AT LANGSTON UNIVERSITY. STUDENTS MAJORING IN ANIMAL SCIENCE AND ALL OTHER STUDENTS TAKING ANIMAL SCIENCE-RELATED COURSES OFFERED AT LANGSTON UNIVERSITY WILL BE PROVIDED WITH ON-SITE DEMONSTRATIONS AND HANDS-ON TRAININGS OF BOTH SMALL AND LARGE ANIMAL SPECIES. STUDENTS WILL HAVE OPPORTUNITIES TO WORK PART-TIME AND BUILD UP PRACTICAL ANIMAL CARE, MANAGEMENT AND HANDLING EXPERIENCES. ANIMAL SCIENCE STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN INTERNSHIPS IN THE LARGE ANIMAL TEACHING CENTER AND EARN CREDIT AS PART OF ACADEMIC REQUIREMENTS FOR GRADUATION.  OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH COMMITMENT OF THE SCHOOL OF AGRICULTURE AND APPLIED SCIENCE, THROUGH THIS 1890 LAND-GRANT INSTITUTION TEACHING CAPACITY BUILDING GRANT PROGRAM, WITH ENHANCED COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIP WITH THE 1862 LAND-GRANT INSTITUTION OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY, AND WITH THE STRONG SUPPORTS OF THE LU AGRICULTURE ALUMNI ASSOCIATION, THE OKLAHOMA BEEF COUNCIL, AND LOCAL ALUMNUS LIVESTOCK FARMERS. THIS TEACHING ENDEAVOR IS STRONGLY SUPPORTED BY LANGSTON UNIVERSITY THROUGH COMMITMENTS OF PASTURELAND, PERSONNEL RESOURCE AND STATE-OF-THE-ART TEACHING AND RESEARCH FACILITIES, AND THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE FOR GOAT RESEARCH. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE TEACHING CAPACITY OF THE SUBMITTING INSTITUTION AND FULFILL PART OF THE INSTITUTION'S LONG-TERM GOALS TO ENHANCE STUDENT ENROLLMENT AND RETENTION IN ANIMAL SCIENCE. STUDENTS WILL BE TRAINED IN A SERIES OF SEMINARS AND WORKSHOPS WITH ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY AND APPLICABLE SKILLS FOR THE FUTURE ANIMAL INDUSTRY.

CLIMATE CHANGE AND VARIABILITY HAVE SIGNIFICANT IMPACTS ON NATURAL RESOURCES, ENVIRONMENT, AND AGRICULTURE. ACCORDING TO THE NATIONAL CLIMATE ASSESSMENT (NCA), CLIMATE CHANGE WILL CONTINUE TO HAVE A SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON NATURAL RESOURCES, AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND THE ENVIRONMENT OVER THE NEXT FEW DECADES AND BEYOND. THE LATEST PREDICTION OF CLIMATE CHANGE FOR THE US WAS SUMMARIZED IN THE 3RD NCA REPORT IDENTIFIED THE FOLLOWING KEY ISSUES FOR THE GREAT PLAINS: (I) RISING TEMPERATURES ARE LEADING TO INCREASED DEMAND FOR WATER AND ENERGY WHICH WILL CONSTRAIN DEVELOPMENT AND STRESS NATURAL RESOURCES, (II) CHANGES TO CROP GROWTH CYCLES DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE HAVE ALREADY BEEN OBSERVED; AS THE TRENDS CONTINUE, THEY WILL REQUIRE NEW AGRICULTURE/LIVESTOCK MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, (III) COMMUNITIES WHICH ARE MOST VULNERABLE TO CLIMATE EXTREMES WILL BE STRESSED EVEN FURTHER BY MORE FREQUENT EXTREME EVENTS OCCURRING WITHIN AN ALREADY HIGHLY VARIABLE CLIMATE SYSTEM, AND (IV) EXISTING ADAPTATION AND PLANNING EFFORTS ARE INADEQUATE TO RESPOND TO THESE PROJECTED IMPACTS. THE POTENTIAL IMPACT OF SHORT-TERM AND LONG-TERM CLIMATE VARIABILITY ON TEMPERATURE AND PRECIPITATION POSE A GREAT CHALLENGE TO AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIONS AND SOIL AND WATER QUALITY. CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACT ON AGRICULTURE NEEDS TO BE ADDRESSED TO HELP FARMERS AND RANCHERS ADAPT TO THEM AND ALSO TAKE THE NECESSARY MEASURES TO MITIGATE THEIR EFFECTS. HOWEVER, LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE POTENTIAL IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON THE SUSTAINABILITY OF TEXAS AGRICULTURE. THESE RELATIONSHIPS AND INTERACTIONS BETWEEN CLIMATE, CROP PRODUCTION AND WATER QUALITY ARE COMPLEX AND CHALLENGING. IN ADDITION, CLIMATE CHANGE HAS A SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON PLANT HARDINESS ZONE (PHZ), WHICH WILL FURTHER IMPACT PLANT/CROPPING SYSTEMS, CROP YIELDS, AND SOIL AND WATER QUALITY. RESEARCHERS HAVE FOUND PHZ ARE EXPECTED TO CHANGE AS CLIMATE ZONES SHIFT NORTHWARD IN THE COMING CENTURY. THESE POTENTIAL CLIMATE CHANGES CAN ALTER AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, E.G., LOCATIONS OF FARMS OR CROPS, IRRIGATION METHODS AND NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT OR EXPECT LOWER CROP YIELD. THEREFORE, THESE ISSUES NEED STUDY USING INTEGRATED FIELD RESEARCH AND NUMERICAL MODELING APPROACHES.THIS INTEGRATED PROJECT IS AIMED TO STUDY THE POTENTIAL IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON CROP WATER REQUIREMENT, CROP YIELD AND SOIL AND WATER QUALITY. THIS PROJECT PRESENTS A CREATIVE APPROACH TO SOLVING SCIENTIFIC PROBLEMS AND ADDRESSES SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES: (I) GENERATE PROJECTED DAILY CLIMATE FORCING DATA USING COMBINED GLOBAL CIRCULATION MODELS (GCMS) & DOWNSCALING MODEL FOR THREE TIME PERIODS; 2030S, 2055S & 2090S AND DEVELOP PLANT HARDINESS ZONE MAP (PHZM) FOR THOSE THREE TIME PERIODS; (II) DEVELOP A WELL-EQUIPPED FARM TESTBED AT THE COLLEGE'S DEMONSTRATION FARM TO ENHANCE EXTENSION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES AND STRENGTHEN RESEARCH CAPACITY IN NATURAL RESOURCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES (NRES); (III) QUANTIFY THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON CROP WATER REQUIREMENT, CROP NUTRIENT AND SOIL AND WATER QUALITY FOR THREE MAJOR CROPS OF TEXAS (COTTON, CORN AND SORGHUM) AT BRAZOS RIVER BASIN (BRB); (IV) EVALUATE DIFFERENT ADAPTATION MEASURES AND RELATIVE CHANGE IN CROP WATER REQUIREMENT, CROP YIELD AND SOIL AND WATER QUALITY WITH AND WITHOUT ADAPTATION APPROACH AND EDUCATE AND TRAIN LIMITED RESOURCE, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS, RANCHERS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS ON OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT.THIS PROJECT DEALS WITH ONE OF THE MOST CRITICAL SCIENCE ISSUES AND ONE OF THE MOST VALUABLE NATURAL RESOURCES WHICH ARE CLIMATE CHANGE AND WATER, RESPECTIVELY. THIS PROJECT WILL HAVE A SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON THE UNDERSTANDING OF CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACT ON SOIL AND WATER QUALITY AND AGRICULTURE, ESPECIALLY FOR LIMITED RESOURCE FARMERS/RANCHERS AND UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS.

SORGHUM IS AN IMPORTANT CROP IN SOUTHERN CROPPING SYSTEMS AS IT IS USED AS FEED FOR THE BROILER INDUSTRY, FORAGEANDSILAGE FOR LIVESTOCK, AND FOR BIOETHANOL PRODUCTION. SORGHUM IS MOSTLY USED FOR ANIMAL FEED IN GEORGIA AND THE U.S. IS THE NUMBER ONE EXPORTER OF SORGHUM GRAIN IN RECENT YEARS. SINCE 2013, THE U.S. SOUTHERN STATES HAVE WITNESSED A NEW INVASIVE AND DEVASTATING PEST KNOWN AS THE SUGARCANE APHID (SCA) (MELANAPHISSACCHARI) WHICH SEVERELY REDUCES SORGHUM CROP YIELDS, FORAGE QUALITY, AND FEED CONSUMPTION. CURRENTLY, WE ARE USING VISUAL SCORING FOR SUGARCANE APHID PLANT DAMAGE SYMPTOMS, WHICH ARE EXTREMELY, LABOR AND TIME INTENSIVE. THEREFORE, THESE CONSTRAINTS IN FIELD PHENOTYPING HAVE NECESSITATED THE USE OF MACHINES FOR HIGH-THROUGHPUT PHENOTYPING THAT CAN INCREASE PRECISION IN PHENOTYPING FOR SUGARCANE APHID DAMAGE. THE DEVELOPMENT OF SUITABLEHIGH-THROUGHPUT (HTP)PLATFORMS SUCH AS ROBOTIC-BASED SYSTEMS CAN BE VERY POWERFUL ANDCURRENTLY,GROUND-BASED FLEETS OF ROBOTS ALLOW USTO MEASURE THE TRAITS OF INTEREST (ESP. APHID NUMBER OF WHICH APHIDS ARE FOUND UNDER THE LEAVES) FOR SUGARCANE APHID INFESTATION. WE AIM TO USE FIELD-BASED ROBOTIC SYSTEMS TO FACILITATE ACCELERATED PLANT BREEDING IN THIS PROJECT.THIS PROJECT IS FORMULATED ON HYPOTHESES THAT ADDRESS BASIC RESEARCH QUESTIONS INVOLVED IN APHID-SORGHUM INTERACTIONS. IT WILL INVESTIGATE THE UNDERLYING GENETIC CAUSES OF PLANT RESISTANCE TO THE SUGARCANE APHID. THEREFORE, WE AIM TO USE A DIVERSE SET OF LINES THAT UTILIZE THE ALLELIC DIVERSITY IN SORGHUM TO ENHANCE GENETIC RESOURCES FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF INSECT RESISTANT VARIETIES USING GENOME-WIDE ASSOCIATION STUDIES. CURRENTLY, ONLY ONE REGION OF THE SORGHUM GENOME ON CHROMOSOME 6 HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED TO CONFER RESISTANCE FROM THE LINE TX2783. PYRAMIDING OF MULTIPLE RESISTANCE GENES INTO SORGHUM CULTIVARS IS NEEDED FOR DURABLE SUGARCANE APHID RESISTANCE. IN THIS PROPOSAL, WE AIM TO IDENTIFY NEW REGIONS OF THE SORGHUM GENOME THAT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH RESISTANCE TO THE SUGARCANE APHID. THESE ASSOCIATED REGIONS WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE SO THAT NEW CULTIVARS OF SORGHUM WITH MULTIPLE RESISTANCE GENES CAN BE CREATED BY PRIVATE AND PUBLIC BREEDING PROGRAMS.IN SUMMARY, THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN FVSU'S RESEARCH AND EDUCATION IN THE FIELDS OF PLANT GENOMICS AND PLANT PROTECTION. THE LONG-TERM GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARETO:1) ESTABLISH A SORGHUM CORE COLLECTION AT FVSU BY OBTAINING ACCESSIONS FROM SEVERAL SOURCES COLLECTED IN THE COUNTRY AND, POTENTIALLY, ABROAD AVAILABLE AT GRIN; 2) IMPROVE FVSU'S RESEARCH CAPACITY BY ENHANCING LABORATORY AND GREENHOUSE FACILITIES FOR INSECT REARING TO ENHANCE PLANT BREEDING FOR INSECT RESISTANCE, AND IN THE PROCESS STRENGTHEN THE UNIVERSITY'S ACADEMIC AND RESEARCH CAPABILITIES WHICH WILL SERVE AS A MODEL FOR OTHER HBCUS; 3) USE ROBOTICS FORHTPOF FIELD GROWN PLANTS, WHICH WILL ALLOW THE INCORPORATION OF ROBOTICS IN FVSU BREEDING PROGRAMS; 4) EVALUATE AND IDENTIFY ACCESSIONS THAT ARE RESISTANT TOTHE SUGARCANE APHID; 5) IDENTIFY GENETIC MARKERS ASSOCIATED WITH SUGARCANE APHID RESISTANCE; 6) PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR ACADEMIC DEVELOPMENT TO FACULTY AND STUDENTS IN FSVU. THUS THE END RESULT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO HAVE SORGHUM CULTIVARS WITH LONG-TERM SUGARCANE APHID RESISTANCE BEING GROWN IN THE UNITED STATES.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO BUILD A CUTTING EDGE GENOME EDITING RESEARCH PLATFORM ACROSS 1890 CAMPUSES THROUGH INTEGRATING EXISTING DIVERSE FACULTY EXPERTISE. THROUGH COMBINING EXPERTISE AT 1890 UNIVERSITIES AND USDA RESEARCH LABORATORY, THIS PROJECT SEEKS (1) TO DEVELOP A SHARED CORE RESOURCE ON CROP GENOME EDITING TO DRIVE THE IMPROVEMENT OF AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY PROGRAMS AT 1890 UNIVERSITIES; (2) TO ESTABLISH CRISPR/CAS9 GENOME EDITING SYSTEM ON MAJOR CROPS SUCH AS SWEETPOTATO AND TOMATO; (3) TO DEVELOP GENOME-EDITED SWEETPOTATO AND TOMATO LINES WITH IMPROVED AGRONOMIC TRAITS; (4) TO DEVELOP EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH MODULES FOR MOTIVATING AND RECRUITING SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED STUDENTS TO PURSUE COLLEGE EDUCATION IN AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY AND (5) TO STRENGTHEN THE AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY PROGRAM BY PROVIDING A LEARNING AND RESEARCH ENVIRONMENT TO STUDENTS AT 1890 UNIVERSITIES. THE MECHANISMS OF SHARING-FACULTY EXPERTISE AND INSTRUMENT RESOURCES ACROSS 1890 CAMPUS AND USDA RESEARCH FACILITIES TO BE USED IN THIS GRANT WILL GREATLY ENHANCE THE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR ALL PARTICIPANTS IN THIS PROJECT. THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROJECT WILL NOT ONLY IMPROVE RESEARCH AND TEACHING ON AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY BUT ALSO BOOST ACADEMIC ENVIRONMENT FOR ALL ACTIVITIES RELATED TO ADVANCED BIOTECHNOLOGY ACROSS 1890 CAMPUSES.

ANTIBIOTIC RESISTANCE IS BECOMING A MAJOR HEALTH ISSUE IN THE UNITED STATES. COUNTRIES IN THE WORLDARE STRIVING FOR WAYS TO ELIMINATE THE MISUSE OF ANTIBIOTICS IN FEED AS GROWTH PROMOTERS AND ILLNESSPREVENTION INTERVENE IN LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION. ESSENTIAL OILS AND POLYPHENOLS ARE NATURAL COMPOUNDSTHAT CAN BE USED AS ANTIBIOTIC ALTERNATIVES, BUT THEIR USE IS LIMITED DUE TO THEIR SENSITIVITY TO HEAT ANDLIGHT, AND HARSH FLAVOR AND TASTE. MICROENCAPSULATION IS A PROMISING APPROACH TO PROTECT THESECOMPONENTS AND TO DELIVER THEM TO THE TARGET SITE IN THE INTESTINAL TRACT. THIS PROPOSAL FILLSKNOWLEDGE GAPS CRITICAL TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF ANTIBIOTIC ALTERNATIVES THAT WILL ENHANCE FOOD SAFETY,IMPROVE POULTRY PERFORMANCE THROUGH MODIFIED INTESTINAL MICROFLORA, AND ELIMINATE ANTIBIOTICABUSE. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED IN A SERIES OF LOGICAL, SEQUENTIAL OBJECTIVES SUPPORTED BY AN INDUSTRIALCOLLABORATOR. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE: 1). OPTIMIZE MICROENCAPSULATION FORMULA AND METHODS BYUSING NOVEL INGREDIENTS AS WALL MATERIALS; 2). INVESTIGATE THE DELIVERY EFFICIENCY AND RELEASINGPROFILE USING IN VITRO AND IN VIVO METHODS; 3). EVALUATE POULTRY INTESTINAL MICROFLORA AND GROWTHPERFORMANCE AFTER FEEDING MICRO PARTICLES THROUGH DIET. THIS PROJECT FITS INTO THE INSTITUTIONAL PLANAND CONFRONTS A LOCAL AND NATIONAL PRIORITY, CONCEIVING, DESIGNING AND EVALUATING NEW BIOPROCESSINGTECHNIQUES IN FOOD SAFETY. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE CBG PROGRAM PRIORITY AREAS, USDAPRIORITIES AND NIFA CHALLENGE AREAS IN FOOD SAFETY. OUTCOMES YIELDED FROM THE GRANT WILLSTRENGTHEN THE RESEARCH AND TEACHING CAPACITY IN 1890 UNIVERSITIES.

COMMON BEAN IS GROWN WORLDWIDE FOR ITS RICH NUTRITION INCLUDING PROTEIN, FIBER, IRON, FOLATE, AND OTHER MICRONUTRIENTS. THE ECONOMIC IMPORTANCE OF BEAN IN THE US IS ESTIMATED TO BE $1.5 BILLION. COMMON BEAN IS AN ESSENTIAL CROP FOR OVER HALF A BILLION PEOPLE IN LATIN AMERICA AND AFRICA. WORLDWIDE, DROUGHT HAS A SIGNIFICANTLY NEGATIVE IMPACT ON AGRICULTURE ESPECIALLY IN THOSE AREAS WITH LIMITED WATER SUPPLY. SEED PRODUCTION IN COMMON BEAN CAN BE AFFECTED SEVERELY BY DROUGHT CONDITIONS, WHICH ACCOUNTS FOR 73% LOSS IN CROP YIELD. MANY MARKET CLASSES OF THE BEAN ARE NARROW GENETICALLY, HENCE, RESISTANCE TO DROUGHT IS INADEQUATE. BREEDING MAY OFFSET THIS TO HELP IMPROVE CROP YIELD, HOWEVER, CHANGING CLIMATIC CONDITIONS AND INCREASED POPULATION NECESSITATE AN UNDERSTANDING OF EPIGENETIC MECHANISMS, WHICH PLAY A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN GENE EXPRESSION REGULATION IN RESPONSE TO EXTERNAL STIMULI LIKE DROUGHT STRESS. GIVEN THAT THE GENOME OF COMMON BEAN IS SEQUENCED, THERE WILL BE A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO USE CUTTING-EDGE TECHNIQUES COMBINED WITH OUR CURRENT KNOWLEDGE TO UNDERSTAND DROUGHT TOLERANT AND SENSITIVE RESPONSES AT THE MOLECULAR LEVEL. HENCE, IT WOULD BE IMPORTANT TO STUDY THE COMBINED EFFECTS OF GENETIC AND EPIGENETIC VARIATION TO EXPLORE RESOURCES FOR PLANT BREEDING PROGRAMS. STUDYING COMMON BEAN WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE DATA ON MOLECULAR MECHANISMS AND PATHWAYS IN DROUGHT RESPONSES, WHICH HAS BROADER IMPACT AND CAN BE APPLIED TO OTHER CLOSELY RELATED LEGUMES, SUCH AS SOYBEAN AND COWPEA. THE PRESENT PROPOSAL IS AIMED AT DEVELOPING RESOURCES FOR COMMON BEAN DROUGHT TOLERANCE. LATEST GENOMIC TOOLS WILL BE UTILIZED TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL CANDIDATE GENES FOR SUCCESSFUL COMMON BEAN BREEDING AGAINST DROUGHT STRESS. THE OUTCOME OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL AID IN (A) DISCOVERY OF NOVEL PATHWAYS AND GENES THAT MAY PLAY A ROLE IN COMMON BEAN DROUGHT TOLERANCE, (B) DEVELOP MOLECULAR PROFILES AND MARKERS FOR BREEDING DROUGHT-TOLERANT COMMON BEAN GENOTYPES, (C)DEVELOP DATABASES ENRICHED WITH EPIGENOMES AND TRANSCRIPTOMES TO AID BEAN GENETICISTS AND BREEDERS (D) TRAIN HIGH SCHOOL, UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS.

LANGSTON UNIVERSITY (LU) IS AN EDUCATIONAL HUB FOR MOSTLY UNDERSERVED STUDENTS FROM ACROSS THE COUNTRY. IT FOCUSES ON PROVIDING AN ARRAY OF KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND EXPERIENCES USING ITS BROAD RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES TO STRENGTHEN THE ACADEMIC GOALS AND MISSION. THE PRESENT PROJECT WAS DESIGNED TO SUPPLEMENT YEAR-ROUND STUDENTS WITH BROAD KNOWLEDGE, HANDS-ON SKILLS AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING PRIMARILY IN THE FIELDS OF BIOTECHNOLOGY AND HORTICULTURE, USING STATE-OF-THE-ART INFRASTRUCTURE AND FACILITIES THAT WERE DEVELOPED WITH NIFA'S FUNDING SUPPORTS, FOR THREE YEARS. IT WILL MOBILIZE EXPERTS AND SPECIALIZED RESOURCES FROM DIFFERENT PROGRAMS OF THE SCHOOL OF AGRICULTURE AND APPLIED SCIENCES. OVERALL, THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE 12 WELL-PREPARED GRADUATES WITH AGRICULTURAL-MULTIDISCIPLINARY, COMPETITIVE AND RESEARCH INVESTIGATIVE SKILLS AND EXPERIENCES. IN ADDITION TO ENHANCED RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE, THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ENHANCE STUDENT AGRICULTURAL KNOWLEDGE AND LEARNING-SOFT-SKILLS TO STRENGTHEN CLASSROOM THEORY AND EXPERIENCES. BESIDES ONSITE TRAINING, STUDENTS WILL BROADEN THEIR LEARNING EXPERIENCES AT OTHER RESEARCH AND ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS UNDER THE MENTORSHIP OF EXPERTS OF DIFFERENT BACKGROUNDS.
ADVANCING CAPACITY IN FANH SCIENCES THROUGH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT IN AND ABOUT ONLINE LEARNING, VIRTUAL REALITY, AND 360 VIDEO AT TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY

A PREVIOUS CBG PROJECT FACILITATED DEVELOPMENT OF A WEB-BASED NUTRIENT REQUIREMENT CALCULATION SYSTEM FOR GOATS, ABBREVIATED AS 'LINC' (LANGSTON INTERACTIVE NUTRIENT CALCULATION SYSTEM). LINC PROVIDES A SIMPLE AND USER-FRIENDLY MEANS OF DIET FORMULATION WITH NRC REQUIREMENTS. IT IS USED EXTENSIVELY THROUGHOUT THE WORLD BY RESEARCHERS, TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER PERSONNEL, PRODUCERS, AND TEACHERS. HOWEVER, ACCURACY OF TWO KEY 'CALCULATORS' ADDRESSING FORMULATION OF CONCENTRATE SUPPLEMENTS AND TOTAL MIXED RATIONS IS LIMITED BECAUSE OF THE LACK OF VALIDATED METHODS OF ADDRESSING POSITIVE AND NEGATIVE ASSOCIATIVE EFFECTS BETWEEN FEEDSTUFFS. THEREFORE, OBSERVATIONS FROM THE LITERATURE WILL BE COMPILED LARGELY BY UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AND USED IN META-ANALYSIS TO DEVELOP ACCURATE MEANS OF PREDICTION THAT WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO LINC. THERE ALSO WILL BE UPDATING WITH FINDINGS FROM OTHER RESEARCH IN THE LAST 15 YEARS TO CREATE LINC 2.0. USAGE OF LINC 2.0 WILL BE INCREASED THROUGHDEVELOPMENT AND EVALUATION OF A TECHNICAL TRAINING MANUAL AND MOODLE CERTIFICATION PROGRAM VIA STUDENT INTERNSHIPS, CREATION OF A CURRICULUM FOR FEEDS AND FEEDING CLASSES, AND ZOOM VIDEO CONFERENCES FOCUSING ON UTILITY FOR TEACHING, EXTENSION, AND RESEARCH. UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS WILL BE INVOLVED IN OUTREACH, INCLUDING ADVERTISING AND DISSEMINATION ON THE INSTITUTE'S SOCIAL MEDIA. LINC HAS BEEN AN IMPORTANT SUCCESS STORY OF THE INSTITUTE, PROVIDING A NOVEL EXAMPLE OF THE INTEGRATED NATURE OF RESEARCH, EXTENSION, TEACHING, AND INTERNATIONAL ACTIVITIES. HENCE, UPGRADING LINC TO LINC 2.0 WILL MARKEDLY IMPROVE CAPACITY IN EACH AREA AND CLIENTELE SERVICE AND WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH EXPERIENTIAL AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS OPPORTUNITIES FOR SUCCESSFUL FUTURE CAREERS IN U.S. AGRICULTURE.

GROUNDWATER AND SURFACE WATER QUALITY ARE CRITICAL AREAS OF RESEARCH FOR MANY REASONS, BUT PRIMARILY BECAUSE THESE WATER SOURCES ARE THE BASIS FOR ALL DRINKING WATER SUPPLIES AND IRRIGATION IN THE US.DRINKING CONTAMINATED WATER CAN HAVE SERIOUS HEALTH EFFECTS ON HUMANS.DISEASES SUCH AS CHOLERA, HEPATITIS, AND DYSENTERY MAY BE CAUSED BY CONTAMINATION FROM HUMAN AND ANIMAL WASTE. THE QUALITY OF GROUNDWATER AND SURFACE WATER IS DIRECTLY IMPACTED BY NATURAL AND HUMAN-MADE CONTAMINANTS. CONTROLLING THE EXPOSURE OF SURFACE AND GROUNDWATER TO THESE CONTAMINANTS, SHOULD IMPROVE WATER QUALITY. ACCORDING TO WATER QUALITY REPORTS, THE MAJOR SOURCES OF GROUND AND SURFACE WATER CONTAMINATION IN THE US, AND ESPECIALLY IN MISSOURI, ARE FROM MODERN AGRICULTURAL ACTIVITIES AND CONCENTRATED ANIMAL FEEDING OPERATIONS (CAFOS). THE CLEAN WATER ACT DEFINES CAFOS AS POINT SOURCES OF POLLUTION THAT ARE REQUIRED TO OBTAIN PERMITS TO DISCHARGE INTO RIVERS OR OTHER DRINKING SOURCES. ALL OTHER AGRICULTURAL SOURCES ARE CONSIDERED NONPOINT AND ARE NOT REGULATED UNDER FEDERAL LAW.NUMEROUS STUDIES OVER THE PAST DECADES HAVE DOCUMENTED THE FACT THAT RUNOFF FROM INTENSIVELY MANAGED CAFOS INCLUDE EXTREMELY HIGH LEVELS OF NATURAL ORGANIC MATTER (NOM), NUTRIENTS (PRIMARILY NITROGEN AND PHOSPHORUS), PATHOGENS, HORMONES, ANTIBIOTICS, SYNTHETIC ORGANIC CHEMICALS (USED AS CLEANING AGENTS, ALGAECIDES, ETC.), DISINFECTANTS (USED ON THE ANIMALS AND IN THEIR PENS), AND OTHER MISCELLANEOUS CHEMICALS, SUCH AS COPPER SULFATE (USED IN FOOTBATHS FOR COWS). DESPITE CURRENT BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), THE CONTAMINANTS FROM AGRICULTURE ACTIVITIES AND CAFOS CONTINUE TO FIND THEIR WAY INTO IMPOUNDMENTS AND STREAMS AS RUNOFF POLLUTION AND CONTAMINATE DRINKING WATER SOURCES. CONVENTIONAL PROCESSES INCLUDE DIRECT FILTRATION, COAGULATION-BASED TREATMENT, MEMBRANE-BASED SYSTEMS, AND ABSORPTION BASED SYSTEMS.HOWEVER, THESE METHODS RESULTED IN ONLY LIMITED SUCCESS. REGULATORS, ENVIRONMENTALISTS, AND THE AGRICULTURE ANDANIMAL FARM INDUSTRIES SHOULD ALL LOOK TO SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING TO EXPLORE POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS TO THIS CRITICAL PROBLEM AFFECTING HUMAN LIFE AND WATER QUALITY. FURTHER ADVANCES IN THE REMOVAL OF ORGANIC CONTAMINANTS FROM WATER RUNOFF SOURCES WILL REQUIRE THE DEVELOPMENT OF NOVEL APPROACHES AND MODALITIES FOR EFFECTIVE REMOVAL AND PURIFICATION. AS A POSSIBLE SOLUTION OUR HYPOTHESIS IS THAT MAGNETIC IRON OXIDE NANOPARTICLES COATED WITH COAGULANTS (HEREIN REFERRED TO AS MAGNETIC NANOSPONGES, MNSS) DUE TO THEIR INHERENT HIGH-SURFACE AREA WITH ACTIVE ABSORPTION CAPABILITIES WILL EFFECTIVELY REMOVE ORGANIC CONTAMINANTS (NOM AND SOCS) EFFICIENTLY AND COST-EFFECTIVELY FROM THE WATER BEFORE ENTRY INTO CRITICAL WATERWAYS.

ENTOMOLOGY CONTINUES TO FACE AN ALARMING DECLINE IN STUDENT ENROLLMENT. MINORITY STUDENTS ARE UNDERREPRESENTED IN MOST UNDERGRADUATE ENTOMOLOGY PROGRAMS, PROFESSIONAL SOCIETIES, AND THE US WORKFORCE. THE MAJOR REASONS ARE THE STUDENT'S LACK OF KNOWLEDGE OF AVAILABLE EMPLOYMENT, INADEQUATE FUNDING AND THE PERCEPTION OF A LACK OF CAREERS IN AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES. WE ALSO FOUND THAT POTENTIAL ENTOMOLOGISTS FROM MINORITY GROUPS ARE LOST TO SOCIETAL INFLUENCES AT A YOUNG AGE AND MANY OF THOSE THAT DO SURVIVE AND ENTER GRADUATE SCHOOLS FAIL TO THRIVE. IN ADDITION, THE LACK OF MENTORS AND CULTURAL BIAS HAVE HINDERED THE RECRUITMENT OF YOUNG ENTOMOLOGISTS. SINCE THE SHORTFALL BEGINS AT THE UNDERGRADUATE LEVEL, OUR RECRUITMENT EFFORTS SHOULD START BEFORE HIGH SCHOOL AND STUDENTS SHOULD BE OFFERED ENTOMOLOGY EXPERIENCES INCLUDING INTERNSHIPS AND SUMMER CAMPS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL DESIGN INNOVATIVE WAYS TO CREATE INTEREST AND ATTRACT COLLEGE, MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS IN THE DISCIPLINE OF ENTOMOLOGY. IT WILL PROVIDE A NEW PERSPECTIVE AND AN OPEN-MINDED UNDERSTANDING OF THE FIELD OF ENTOMOLOGY, ITS IMPORTANCE, AND PROFESSIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE TO GRADUATES.IT WILL CREATE A STUDENT-CENTERED LEARNING ENVIRONMENT WHICH INTEGRATES INTERACTIVE AND DIGITAL LEARNING TOOLS WHILE INCORPORATING PEER SUPPORT MENTORSHIPS, FACULTY AND GRADUATE STUDENT MENTORSHIPS. IT WILL ALSO INTERLINK AND ESTABLISH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT SKILLS AND PATHWAY FOR FUTURE ENTOMOLOGISTS AT EARLY AGE. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH AN ACTIVE RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION PROGRAM DESIGNED TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF MINORITY STUDENTS IN ENTOMOLOGY PROGRAMS AND ENHANCE THE UNIQUENESS OF THE UNDERGRADUATE STUDIES WHILE ENSURING THE PRODUCTION OF WELL-TRAINED STUDENTS FOR PROFESSIONAL CAREERS AND GRADUATE SCHOOLS IN THIS NEW MILLENNIUM.

ARKANSAS IS KNOWN AS THE BIRTHPLACE OF WARM WATER AQUACULTURE IN THE UNITED STATES. TODAY THE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY IN ARKANSAS HAS EXPANDED TO INCLUDE OVER 20 SPECIES OF FISH AND SHELLFISH. ARKANSAS IS RANKED SECOND IN TOTAL AQUACULTURE PRODUCTION AND RANKS FIRST IN THE PRODUCTION OF BAITFISH, SPORTFISH, LARGEMOUTH BASS, HYBRID STRIPED BASS FRY, AND CHINESE CARP. IN SUMMERY AQUACULTURE HAS HAD A MAJOR IMPACT IN ARKANSAS, ESPECIALLY IN THE DELTA, WHERE THE MAJORITY OF AQUACULTURE PRODUCTION OCCURS. OF THE TWO LAND-GRANT UNIVERSITIES IN THE STATE OF ARKANSAS, THE UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS AT PINE BLUFF (UAPB) HAS THE ONLY AQUACULTURE/FISHERIES CENTER OF EXCELLENCE (AQFI) IN THE STATE. WE ARE THE ONLY STATE-SUPPORTED INSTITUTION OF HIGHER EDUCATION IN ARKANSAS THAT HAS STATEWIDE RESPONSIBILITY FOR BOTH RESEARCH AND EXTENSION IN AQUACULTURE AND FISHERIES. AS WE MOVE THROUGH THE 21ST CENTURY, A PROMINENT ADVANCEMENT IN AQUACULTURE HAS BEEN THE USE OF SELECTIVE BREEDING, STRAIN SELECTION, PLOIDY MANIPULATIONS, GENETICS, AND GENOMICS TO BOOST CROP PRODUCTIVITY AND QUALITY. A FOUNDATIONAL COMPONENT OF THE ABOVE-MENTIONED TECHNOLOGIES IS REPRODUCTIVE PHYSIOLOGY OF FISH (RPF). THE MAIN FRESHWATER AQUACULTURE PRODUCING STATES (MISSISSIPPI, ARKANSAS, ALABAMA, LOUISIANA, AND TEXAS), ALL HAVE MAJOR UNIVERSITIES WITH AQUACULTURE RESEARCH PROGRAMS AFFILIATED WITH THE INDUSTRY. AUBURN UNIVERSITY IN AL, MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY IN MS, LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY IN LA, TEXAS A&M IN TX, AND OF COURSE UAPB IN AR. OF THE ABOVE-MENTIONED AQUACULTURE PROGRAMS, UAPB IS THE ONLY ONE THAT LACKS A REPRODUCTIVE PHYSIOLOGY, FISH BREEDING OR AN AQUACULTURE GENETICS PROGRAM. UAPB DOES NOT HAVE THE TECHNICAL INFRASTRUCTURE OR RESOURCES DEVOTED TOWARDS A FISH REPRODUCTIVE PHYSIOLOGY, HATCHERY MANAGEMENT, SELECTIVE BREEDING OR A GENETICS PROGRAM. THIS LACK OF TECHNICAL INFRASTRUCTURE TO CONDUCT RESEARCH ON THE REPRODUCTIVE PHYSIOLOGY OF FISHES AT UAPB IS A GLARING DEFICIENCY. THIS INTEGRATED PROJECT WILL INVOLVE RESEARCH, AND EXTENSION AT UAPB. IT WILL ENHANCE SUSTAINABLE AQUACULTURE THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF RESEARCH CAPACITY IN REPRODUCTIVE PHYSIOLOGY OF FISHES. THE RESEARCH COMPONENT WILL INVOLVE XENOGENEICS, A NOVEL METHOD INVOLVING GERM CELL TRANSFER AND TRANSPLANTATION TECHNOLOGY TO PRODUCE BLACK CRAPPIE X WHITE CRAPPIE HYBRID FRY. THE CRAPPIE IS OF GREAT INTEREST AND COMMERCIAL IMPORTANCE TO THE SPORT-FISH INDUSTRY WITHIN ARKANSAS AND THE US. THE MAJOR OBSTACLE TO SUCCESSFUL CULTURE AND STOCKING OF CRAPPIE IS THEIR EXTREMELY HIGH REPRODUCTION RATE, WHICH CAN SOON LEAD TO OVERCROWDING AND STUNTING IN COMMERCIAL AQUACULTURE. HYBRID CRAPPIE ARE THE FIRST GENERATION CROSS BETWEEN A BLACK CRAPPIE MALE AND A WHITE CRAPPIE FEMALE. THIS RESULTING HYBRID DISPLAYS LIMITED REPRODUCTION AND INCREASED GROWTH. RESEARCH INDICATES THAT F1 HYBRID CRAPPIE GROWS FASTER AND WEIGH MORE THAN BOTH BLACK CRAPPIE AND WHITE CRAPPIE. HYBRIDS HAVE BEEN KNOWN TO GET AS LARGE AS 3 LBS., DEPENDING ON AVAILABLE FORAGE AND FEED. THE CURRENT METHOD OF HYBRID CRAPPIE PRODUCTION INVOLVES HORMONE INDUCED ARTIFICIAL SPAWNING TECHNIQUES. IN THIS METHOD, FEMALE WHITE CRAPPIE ARE INDUCED TO OVULATE WITH THE USE OF A SPAWNING AID. THE EGGS ARE HAND STRIPPED AND COLLECTED. AS MALE CRAPPIE DO NOT RELEASE THEIR SPERM WHEN STRIPPED BY HAND, BLACK CRAPPIE MALES ARE EUTHANIZED, THE TESTES ARE REMOVED AND MACERATED, AND THEN THE TESTICULAR MATERIAL IS MIXED WITH THE EGGS. WATER IS ADDED, AND THE SPERM AND EGGS ARE MIXED TO FERTILIZE. THIS ARTIFICIAL SPAWNING PROCEDURE IS LABOR AND TIME CONSUMING, CAN BE COSTLY, HAVE HIGH EMBRYONIC MORTALITY RATES AND LOW HATCH RATES. IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL PROVIDE AN INNOVATIVE METHOD FOR THE PRODUCTION OF HYBRID CRAPPIE VIA NATURAL SPAWNING. OUR GOAL IS TO DEVELOP A PROTOCOL FOR THE INTERSPECIFIC TRANSFER OF PRIMORDIAL GERM CELLS (PGCS) BETWEEN THE TWO DIFFERENT SPECIES OF CRAPPIE. WE WILL INVESTIGATE TWO APPROACHES FOR THE PRODUCTION OF HYBRID CRAPPIE: FIRST BY TRANSPLANTING BLACK CRAPPIE PGCS INTO TRIPLOID WHITE CRAPPIE MALES SO THAT THEY PRODUCE BLACK CRAPPIE SPERM, AND MATING THEM WITH NORMAL WHITE CRAPPIE FEMALES. THE SECOND APPROACH WILL BE TO TRANSPLANT WHITE CRAPPIE PGCS INTO TRIPLOID BLACK CRAPPIE FEMALES SO THAT THEY PRODUCE WHITE CRAPPIE EGGS, AND MATING THEM WITH NORMAL BLACK CRAPPIE MALES. IF SUCCESSFUL, EITHER OF THESE APPROACHES WOULD RESULT IN THE DESIRED HYBRID THROUGH NATURAL SPAWNING IN CULTURE PONDS. OUR APPROACH IS FIRST TO PRODUCE STERILE WHITE CRAPPIE MALE AND STERILE BLACK CRAPPIE FEMALE HOSTS. STERILITY WILL BE ACHIEVED BY TRIPLOIDIZATION. NEXT DONOR PGC STEM CELLS WILL BE OBTAINED FROM JUVENILE BLACK AND WHITE CRAPPIE BY HARVESTING THEM FROM THEIR GONADS. THE HARVESTED CELLS WILL BE ISOLATED, PROCESSED AND TAGGED SO THAT PGCS CAN BE IDENTIFIED. THE PGC'S WILL THEN BE CRYOPRESERVED FOR LONG-TERM STORAGE, OR TRANSPLANTED INTO THE GONADS OF THE STERILE TRIPLOID HOSTS. BLACK CRAPPIE PGC'S WILL BE TRANSPLANTEDINTO TRIPLOID WHITE CRAPPIE MALES AND WHITE CRAPPIE PGCS INTO TRIPLOID BLACK CRAPPIE FEMALES. THIS TRANSPLANTATION OF PGCS INTO THE HOST SHOULD REESTABLISH THE FERTILITY OF THE XENOGENEIC HOST. HOWEVER, THE HOST WILL PRODUCE GAMETES (EGGS AND SPERM) THAT OF THE DONOR. THE SUCCESS OF THE XENOGENEIC TRANSPLANTATION WILL BE EVALUATED BY LOOKING FOR THE PRESENCE OF THE TAGGED VIABLE PGC, 30,60 AND 90 DAYS POST IMPLANTATION BY SACRIFICING 2-3 FISH, DISSECTING THE GONADS, AND CHECKING FOR THE PRESENCE OF FLUORESCENCE OR BY USING REAL-TIME PCR (QPCR) TO DETECT THE PRESENCE OF DONOR GENETIC MATERIAL. CONFIRMATION OF XENOGENESIS WILL BE DONE BY INDUCED SPAWNING OF THE XENOGENIC BROODSTOCKS. SPERM FROM XENOGENEIC WHITE CRAPPIE MALES WILL BE USED TO FERTILIZE EGGS FROM WHITE CRAPPIE FEMALES, AND EGGS FROM XENOGENEIC BLACK CRAPPIE FEMALES WILL BE FERTILIZED WITH BLACK CRAPPIE MALE SPERM. THE PRODUCTION OF BLACK CRAPPIE X WHITE CRAPPIE, HYBRID FRY FROM EITHER OF THESE CROSSES WILL CONFIRM SUCCESSFUL XENOGENESIS. THE FOLLOW UP TO THIS WILL BE NATURAL RACEWAY OR POND SPAWNING OF THE XENOGENEIC BROODSTOCK WITH THEIR CONSPECIFICS TO PRODUCE A NATURALLY SPAWNED F1 HYBRID CRAPPIE POPULATION. A GOAL FOR THE FINAL YEAR OF THIS PROJECT WOULD BE TO ISOLATE CRAPPIE PGCS WITHOUT TAGGING THEM WITH GREEN FLUORESCENT PROTEIN (GFP). WE HOPE TO CHARACTERIZE IN DETAIL PGCS ISOLATED USING GFP TO IDENTIFY A DISTINCTIVE CHARACTERISTIC (I.E., SIZE, VOLUME OR OPTICAL DENSITY) THAT CAN BE USED AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO GFP. THIS WOULD BE A UNIQUE METHOD TO IDENTIFY AND ISOLATE PGCS IN CRAPPIE WITH THE POTENTIAL OF BEING USED FOR FUTURE RESEARCH WITH ANOTHER TELEOST. IF OUR PROTOCOL FOR THE PRODUCTION OF THE CRAPPIE HYBRID IS SUCCESSFUL, THIS WILL REPRESENT THE FIRST APPLICATION OF THIS BREAKTHROUGH TECHNOLOGY IN SPORT-FISH. AS THIS IS A RESEARCH AND EXTENSION INTEGRATED PROJECT, DIFFERENT STAGES OF SEED PRODUCTION, TRIPLOID PRODUCTION, HYBRID PRODUCTION AND NATURAL POND SPAWNING WILL BE DONE IN COLLABORATION WITH FISH PRODUCERS AND INDUSTRY STAKEHOLDERS. THE OUTCOMES FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE DISSEMINATED VIA A SERIES OF PUBLICATIONS, POSTERS, AND PRESENTATIONS. THE OUTCOMES FROM THE RESEARCH COMPONENTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE PRESENTED AND DISSEMINATED TO THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY BY PUBLISHING THE RESULTS, PROTOCOLS, AND DATA IN PEER-REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS. SEPARATE COMPONENTS OF THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILL BE SUBMITTED TO DIFFERENT JOURNALS BASED ON THEIR TARGET AUDIENCE AND FOCUSED DISCIPLINE. EXTENSION COMPONENTS WILL BE DISSEMINATED VIA EXTENSION PUBLICATION AND WILL TARGET LOCAL AQUAFARMERS, PRODUCERS, AND STAKEHOLDERS. UAPB EXTENSION PROGRAM WILL ALSO PUBLISH SEVERAL FACT SHEETS AND MANUALS ON THE PRODUCTION OF HYBRID CRAPPIE AND XENOGENIC CRAPPIE. THE ESTABLISHMENT OF DEMONSTRATION SITES AT UAPB AND SEVERAL COMMERCIAL AQUACULTURE FACILITIES WITHIN ARKANSAS WILL ALSO AID IN THE DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION.

AQUACULTURE IS THE FASTEST GROWING FOOD SECTOR IN THE WORLD, BUT FOR THIS INDUSTRY TO CONTINUE GROWING, SUSTAINABLE PACTICES AND IMPROVING PRODUCTIVITY ARE PARAMOUNT. THIS CAN BE ACCOMPLISHED, IN PART, BY INTEGRATING TWO MINIMAL EXCHANGE SYSTEMS, WHICH WILL BE BIOFLOC TECHNOLOGY (BFT) AND AQUAPONICS. WHILE THESE SYSTEMS ARE TRADITIONALLY SEPARATE, THERE IS THE POTENTIAL TO SYMBIOTICALLY INTEGRATE THESE THAT WILL MORE EFFECTIVELY RECYCLE NUTRIENTS, CREATE BETTER QUALITY PRODUCTS, ALLOW FOR YEAR-ROUND PRODUCTION AND INCREASE SUPPLEMENTAL INCOME TO FARMERS. A MAJOR DRAWBACK TO BFT IS EXCESSIVE ACCUMULATION OF BIOFLOCS THAT MAY NEGATIVELY AFFECT WATER QUALITY AND THE HEALTH OF THE ANIMAL. MEANWHILE, A MAJOR DRAWBACK TO AQUAPONICS IS INADEQUATE AVAILABILITY OF MICRO-NUTRIENTS LEADING TO LOWER PRODUCTION. THESE ISSUES CAN BE COST-EFFECTIVELY SOLVED BY REMOVING EXCESS BIOFLOCS TO BE MINERALIZED, AND THUS IMPROVE MICRO-NUTRIENT SOLUBILITY, WHICH IS THEN ADDED TO AQUAPONIC SYSTEMS TO IMPROVE PRODUCTIVITY AND SUSTAINABILITY. CATFISH AND SHRIMP WILL BE THE FOCUS AT UAPB AND KSU. THE RESEARCH PLAN INVOLVES FIRST DETERMINING THE OPTIMAL CARBON SOURCE TO CREATE THE MOST SUITABLE BIOFLOCS FOR MINERALIZATION FOLLOWED BY THE OPTIMAL AMOUNT OF EXCESS BIOFLOCS TO REMOVE WITHOUT NEGATIVELY AFFECTING WATER QUALITY OR ANIMAL PRODUCTIVITY. THE NEXT STEP WILL BE TO DETERMINE THE OPTIMAL DURATION FOR BIOFLOC MINERALIZATION BEFORE COMPARING THE EFFICACY OF MINERALIZED BIOFLOC OR ANIMAL WASTE TO AQUAPONIC PRODUCTIVITY. ESTABLISHING THESE SYSTEMS AND RESEARCH DIRECTION WOULD INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF UAPB TO RECRUIT AND TRAIN NEW STUDENTS, STRENGHTHEN COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH AMONG 1890 INSTITUTIONS, AND PROVIDE RESEARCH-BASED SOLUTIONS TO THE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY.

INCREASING FRESHWATER DEMANDS AND WASTEWATER DISPOSAL CHALLENGES HAVE DRIVEN THE NEED FOR REUSING RECLAIMED WASTEWATER. THE RECLAIMED WASTEWATER PROVIDES AN ALTERNATIVE WATER SOURCE TO MEET NON-POTABLE WATER DEMANDS SUCH AS AGRICULTURE AND LANDSCAPE IRRIGATION WHILE CONSERVING FRESHWATER RESOURCES. IN THE UNITED STATES, FLORIDA IS THE LARGEST PRODUCER OF RECLAIMED WASTEWATER. THE CAPITAL CITY OF FLORIDA-TALLAHASSEE HAS BEEN A PIONEER IN THE USE OF RECLAIMED WASTEWATER FOR FORAGE CROP PRODUCTION AND RECENTLY BEGAN USING RECLAIMED WASTEWATER FOR GOLF COURSE AND LANDSCAPE IRRIGATION. HOWEVER, IRRIGATION USE OF RECLAIMED WASTEWATER MAY HAVE SOME UNDESIRABLE IMPACTS ON SOIL AND FRESHWATER RESOURCES. THE HIGH CONCENTRATION OF SALTS AND OTHER HARMFUL CONTAMINANTS IN RECLAIMED WASTEWATER MAY DEGRADE SOIL QUALITY AND LESS PRODUCTIVE. THE USE OF RECLAIMED WASTEWATER FOR SPRAY IRRIGATION ON AGRICULTURAL CROPS AND PASTURE IN THE CITY OF TALLAHASSEE ELEVATED NITRATE CONCENTRATIONS IN THE GROUNDWATER OF FLORIDAN AQUIFER AND IS A MAJOR CONTRIBUTOR TO EUTROPHICATION IN WAKULLA SPRINGS, FL, WHICH IS FED BY THE FLORIDAN AQUIFER. THEREFORE, IT IS IMPERATIVE TO ENSURE THAT LONG TERM USE OF RECLAIMED WASTEWATER IS SAFE AND SUSTAINABLE FROM AGRICULTURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL STANDPOINT.THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS IMPACT OF RECLAIMED WASTEWATER IRRIGATION ON SOIL AND GROUNDWATER RESOURCES; AND BUILD HUMAN CAPITAL IN THE AREA OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES. WE WILL UNDERTAKE FIELD AND GREENHOUSE STUDIES TO ACCOMPLISH THESE GOALS. FIELD STUDIES WILL BE CONDUCTED ON A SPRAYFIELD IN TALLAHASSEE IRRIGATED WITH RECLAIMED WASTEWATER AND WILL INCLUDE ASSESSMENT OF CHEMICAL AND MICROBIAL PROPERTIES OF SOILS, NUTRIENT MOVEMENT IN SOIL, AND MONITORING GROUNDWATER QUALITY.
